1313111121122121111111111111111122112111.content:
When the group had reached The Crossroads, they had found a set of 4 meteors, still glowing with a bright green radiance, spread a fair amount apart from one another; everyone was relieved knowing the placement wouldn't accidently cause Sumia to grow too big. Robin and Maribelle got to work erecting barriers around the meteorites so the shards would stay in; the two read incantations from tomes to create bright blue spheres around the craters and then set the tomes to the ground like charms, allowing the barriers to stay up without anyone needing to keep the spell held. The duo came back to the others to confirm the barrier.

"Okay," Robin started, "The way the barriers work is that they're permeable by all that enter it, but won't allow anything to leave unless impact is felt. Once the stones hit the barrier, it should dissipate, allowing Sumia room to grow without injuring herself."

"You have a strategy for everything, don't you Robin?" asked Tiki, admiring the tactician's careful planning

"Ahem!" chimed Maribelle, "Forgive me if I'm being rude, but can we get this over with? I have a very important schedule ahead of myself for the week, and I don't wish to waste it out here."

"Understood." replied Tiki, not fazed by Maribelle's impatience. "Lady Sumia, are you ready?"

"Ready!" Sumia walked out from behind a carriage draped in a blanket covering her body, having disrobed herself for the experiment. She walked forward and stood facing Chrom, pulling the Exalt in for a quick hug and kiss before she did her part.

"You're not going anywhere you know." spoke Chrom with a smile.

"I know," responded Sumia, "Just one for the road, in case it's a while before we do this again." Sumia had thought how she would become pregnant with the Cynthia of her time as a giant, but she figured not to worry about it for now, Naga and Tiki knew what they were doing. Robin turned around so he wouldn't look at Sumia's body, being respectful of his friend's wife, as Sumia marched towards the meteor by herself and entered the barrier. As she faced the meteor, Sumia dropped the blanket from her body, exposing it to the world, and took a deep breath; she touched the smooth surface of the meteor and felt the rock rumble in return. In an instant, she was engulfed in a bright green light and watched the meteor shatter before her; the pieces flew in every direction and hit the barrier walls, keeping the shards constrained to the crater for easy collection. Soon, the barrier dissipated, leaving Sumia kneeling before a pile of rocks.

"Are you okay Sumia?" asked Chrom, concerned for his wife's well-being.

"I...I'm fine, it's just...Ugh..." Feeling a slight discomfort in her body, Sumia hugged herself and watched the world shrink before her, the trees dwindle smaller as she expanded. After a short while, Sumia stopped feeling the Earth shift under her feet, signaling a halt to her growth, and stood to her full height of 60 feet tall. "Amazing..." she said, feeling the breeze run through her hair, awestruck by her size. "This is nothing like seeing the world from the back of a Pegasus..."

"Amazing..." parroted Say'ri, admiring the sight. "It's not pleasant to feel, yet amazing to see. Those meteors truly are a strange enigma..."

"Uh," started Robin, "Can you please dress yourself Sumia? I really don't want to see you naked..."

"Oh!" gasped Sumia, "Sorry Robin! Just taking this all in! Let's just get out of this hole..." Sumia moved one foot out of the crater and prepared to move the other, ready to drape herself in Maribelle's curtains. As she took her step towards the carriages, she slipped on the blanket she dropped to the ground, causing her to trip forward and fall. "W-Whoa!!" Time seemed to slow for a moment as everyone watched the giant fall towards them, shock and panic on their faces, save Robin who wasn't watching. Tiki, Say'ri, and Chrom moved to the right, Chrom carrying Robin by his arm, and Maribelle jumped back to the left to avoid Sumia's body; they watched as Sumia's body crashed into the carriage carrying the curtains, her body left a dent in the ground on impact. The ground shook and everyone was knocked off their feet; Maribelle, who had jumped, had tumbled back the most, rolling down a crater and hitting her head against a hard surface. Sumia removed her head from the wreckage of the carriage and shook off the impact, everyone looked on to survey the damage to the area.

"Lady Sumia!" yelled Maribelle, frustration reaching a zenith. "Be more careful! I nearly broke my neck falling down!"

"Uh, Maribelle..." interrupted Robin, now watching the situation.

"Not now Robin! I've had it up to here with all these giants! I should be preparing for a Ball! Not-" Maribelle's ramblings were interrupted by a rumbling from behind her. She turned around and adopted a horrified expression as she saw what she hit; a meteor, ready to burst. "Uh oh..." The flash of green light up the crater and more shards scattered under the second barrier, allowing it to disperse as Maribelle began to expand. The group was treated to the sounds of ripping fabric for a short while as they saw the once-small noble expand as well; when the growth stopped, Maribelle grew to a massive 60 feet alongside Sumia, the pink horse-riding suit she wore during her time in the Shepherds now scattered across the ground, leaving Maribelle nude. "AIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIEEEEEEEEEEEEE!" screamed Maribelle, covering her privates with her hands, horrified at her new stature. "Look at me! I'm a freak! My favorite riding suit is in ruins! Ahhh!"

"Well, not how I expected it to go, but I guess we got our meteors." commented Tiki, taking everything in. Maribelle turned around and reached her hand out, grabbing Tiki and holding the Manakete between her fingers by her dress.

"You!" she cried, "You did this to me! I just wanted to stay at home, study law, and eat chocolate; now look at me!"

"Actually, you tripped on the impact, it's kind of Sumia's fault."

"I'll crush you!" yelled Maribelle at the Manakete. She fully grasped her hands around Tiki and prepared to crush her, Tiki only looked completely unfazed; in truth though, she was completely terrified on the inside.

"Honey!" shouted Robin, "Don't crush Tiki! We need her to get you two back to normal! Just put her down, please!" Maribelle gritted her teeth and huffed, she moved her hands to the ground and released Tiki before moving her hands back to cover herself.

"Thank you Robin." spoke Tiki to Robin in a solemn voice. She took Say'ri by her hand and drug her behind a tree; when she was out of sight, Tiki started shuddering and grasped Say'ri tightly by the waist of her dress, her teeth started chattering and she begun to feel physically ill. Robin ran over to his wife and began to stroke her thigh; he looked up at Maribelle's face, it went from a healthy peach to bright red, the woman bit down on her bottom lip and tears started to well in her eyes.

"Now I know things look bad," he started softly, his voice naturally relaxing his wife, "But we just need to take the meteor you hit with you too, and Naga can fix you right up. I promise that we'll get you at a manageable size before the Ball hits, and then you'll never need to touch your stone ever again if you don't want to; though I really hope you do use it sometimes, it just means more of you for me to love!" Maribelle sniffled a little and wiped the tears from her eyes, trying to get control of her mood better. "It's a little scary now, but just smile, we can get you back to normal too."

"T-Thanks Robin..." responded Maribelle. "I'd kiss you, but right now, I'm a little...indecent. Lady Tiki, please forgive me for my outburst." Tiki's shaking hand came from behind the tree, giving an "OK" sign to signify her forgiveness. "Lord Chrom, I hope I didn't startle you as well."

"N-Not at all..." replied Chrom with a faint blush upon her face. "It's just...You wouldn't happen to have bought extra curtains, would you?"

"Of course." replied Maribelle, embarrassed the Exalt laid eyes upon her naked body. "Lady Sumia, is there any you could spare for me?"

"You're in luck!" responded Sumia, grabbing the stacks of curtains from the tattered remains of the carriage. "It looks like if we just tie around our chests and loins, we can cover up enough for both of us!"

"Thank goodness..." Sumia extended a pile of curtains towards Maribelle and the two quickly got to work at tying the cloth to cover themselves, at least while they were at this size. When finished, the two looked like they wore strapless lavender swimsuits, their figures complemented what they wore well.

"Alright, on to Mount Prism next, right Tiki?" Tiki shook her head at Sumia's question, still trying to get over Maribelle's angry outburst. "Sorry I wrecked the carriage boys, you're going to have to ride with us." Sumia took Chrom by his cape and dropped him between her breasts, jiggling them playfully when he landed. "Don't worry Chrom, I promise not to trip!" Maribelle took Robin and Say'ri and sat them upon her shoulders together, she rubbed her hand across her arm and felt a little embarrassed at showing so much skin once the gravity of her situation set in. Tiki fully recovered from her fear and shifted to dragon form, ready to lead the charge.

"Alright, gather your shards or you're not getting small again." she commanded, the girls had followed orders and gathered their rocks, holding them like small piles of soil before beginning a march. "Alright, off to Mount Prism!"

1313111121122121111111111111111122112111.content:
Although calmed down, Maribelle was still dismayed at her plight and more than a little annoyed at Sumia.

"Why did Tiki choose someone as clumsy as you to be a giant?!"

Sumia answered quickly.

"It was either me or Cynthia, so I stepped forward."

Maribelle tsked.

"Yes well you better watch where you step and watched those clumsy feet of yours!"

Sumia hung her head.

"I'm sorry..."

Tiki flew closer and tried to reassure Maribelle.

"Naga should put you back to normal in no time."

Maribelle huffed.

"And if she doesn't?!"

They had never seen a dragon look nervous before, but Tiki managed it.

"I-I'll thinking of something."

Maribelle suddenly noticed Robin smiling.

"What are you smiling about?!"

"Oh nothing...."

Maribelle narrowed her eyes.

"Let me guess, you were thinking about how much easier the war would have been if we were this size."

Robin hung his head but smiled.

"You know me too well."

Maribelle growled.

"Must you be thinking of tactics at a time like this?!"

"I'm sorry it can't be helped. I have a naturual aptitude for it, but when I lost my memory it one of the things that kept me sane."

"Hmmph."

Chron nodded, though they didn't notice him till her spoke.

"He does have a point."

Maribelle groaned.

"Not you to!"

"I would not wish any in our army to be stuck this way, but if Tiki's plan works our defenses will be bolsted."

"Are you sure you aren't just saying that because of.... other benefits."

Chrom leaned back and relaxed further, placing his hands behind his head.

"Truth be told no, I was only thinking of our nation. But we might as well make the most of the situation we're in." He looked up at Sumia's magnified face. She smiled, but also blushed.

Seeing Maribelle still unhappy, Robin placed an arm on her shoulder.

"We should be there soon. It should be a simple matter to climb the mountain at your sizes. This time we are unlikely to have to deal with Risen."

"-But if we do we can crush them like the pests they are." Maribelle smiled. "Hmm.. I am starting to see the positives to this size."

"-Then."

"But I'm still eager to return to normal. Though if all goes well maybe I'll see what I can do with a giant stone. Just once, at least."
1313111121122121111111111111111122112111.title: On the road again

The townsfolk run away in fear and lock themselves in their homes
1313111121122121111111111111111122112111.content:
As the morning hit, Lucina and her party had already hit the road to the North Feroxi settlements, Flavia seeing them off as the rest of the feast's guests were collapsed on the floor of the palace. Like before, Lucina strode forward with Gerome & Minerva in flight at her side, and Owain & Severa's theater carriage in tow, however, Ophelia now joined the travels and drove the carriage while her father tried to dispel his hangover with coffee and medicine, while Cynthia allowed her Pegasus to freely fly at its leisure while the girl wrapped herself in Lucina's massive scarf.

"Urp..." croaked Cynthia, holding a hand to her head. "To think that a mere ale would trump the mighty Cynthia..."

"Cynthia, it's your fault, you shouldn't be drinking things you're not used to." retorted her sister. "Even Father rarely drinks, and he knows how to handle his alcohol."

"S-Sorry sis..." Cynthia burped lightly like she was about to vomit and relaxed herself in a laying position.

"You're just lucky Gerome and Ophelia were there to peel your sorry butts off the floor of the mess hall." curtly chimed in Severa. She gazed at Owain, rotating between sips of a hot mug and vulnerary vial, before continuing her lecture. "You especially should be ashamed, you're going to be a father soon! Just think what poor Ophelia was thinking while she was watching her Daddy chug one mug after another to prove his 'Hero's Worth'!"

"Yeah, I'm sorry about all that Severa..." Owain looked at his future daughter, whistling while handling the horses, and begged for her forgiveness. "Sorry to you too Ophelia, I'm sure you didn't travel back through time just to be a designated driver..."

"No worries Daddy!" beamed the young Sorceress. "I used to spend time with horses all the time back in the future, it makes me feel at home! And besides, I'm not going anywhere anyways, we'll have plenty of time together ahead of us!" Ophelia decided against telling Owain of his fate, but resolved to speak after her other self's birth, with Severa keeping the secret safe too; it was a definite boost to the girl's morale to get her burden off her shoulders.

"Thanks, you're a good daughter!" Ophelia nearly squealed at the compliment, getting flashbacks of happy 4-year old memories. "And hey, speaking of, how about that Gerome last night with the arm wrestling? He even slammed one guy through the table! Tough stuff!"

"Pathetic." replied Gerome. "I just wanted them off of Lucina. And that table slam was because he passed out and leaned forward mid-match."

"Regardless, it was very thoughtful of you Gerome, thank you." Gerome blushed a bit and cracked a smile at his wife's compliment. Lucina stood on her tiptoes to get a better view of the area and caught glimpse of a watch tower beyond a sea of trees; she could easily see smoke and assorted hay & wooden roofs in the clear weather of the day. "A town is just up ahead, we can ask around about the ruins there, someone has to know of the elixir story." Everyone felt a little charged up at Lucina's comments, feeling that they were nearing the end of their wild goose chase soon enough.

"And a bed," chimed in Cynthia, sneezing and burping a little, "I need a warm bed to nap off this headache..." When the group reached the edge of the town a short while later, they hid amongst the forest trees to determine their plan at Lucina's request.

"I don't mean to inconvenience you all, but could you all continue without me for now? I don't wish to scare the townsfolk with my size." Lucina took Cynthia from her rest on her shoulders and slid her into the carriage. "We might need to stop here for the night if Cynthia and Owain are too hung over."

"You let off too kind a presence to frighten someone, but I do see your point." replied Gerome. "Very well, but you won't be sleeping out in this cold forest tonight."

"I'll be fine Gerome, I promise."

"No, I'll see to it the town elder allows you some sort of shelter." Gerome got off Minerva's back and spoke command to the wyvern. "Stay with Lucina, keep her warm and keep her company until we get back." On command, the wyvern cuddled up alongside her mistress and blew puffs of smoke from her nostrils to keep her warm in the snow; noticing this, Cynthia's Pegasus moved over from its grazing and started nudging Lucina's thigh, as if to get in on the love. Gerome got onto the carriage and sat alongside Ophelia in the passenger's seat. "We'll be back, be safe." With that, they departed into town while Lucina kept hidden.

Despite being such a small town, the townsfolk seemed too much like city-dwellers, too busy to talk and hurrying along. The cart was stopped at the side of the main plaza as Gerome, Ophelia and Severa yelled for attention, much to Owain and Cynthia's headaches.

"We're looking for the town elder, where-"

"Excuse me! Sir! Do you know where-"

"Hey! Numbskulls! We're trying to find-" No response to all 3 travelers.

"This is beginning to wear thin," commented Gerome, "How are we supposed to find the village chief if nobody stops for us?"

"Have you tried something quieter?" asked Cynthia, distressed by the noise. Suddenly, a light went off in Ophelia's head at her aunt's words. She jumped out of the carriage and turned to the other riders.

"I got it!" she cried. "If words don't work, then actions!" She turned around to the busy public and opened her tome, shooting fireworks into the air from its pages; this caught the attention of some young children and houseparents. "Ladies and gentlemen!" cried the magician, "We have a wonderful magic show for you today! We ask for no money, just a warm bed to sleep in and your hearts & dreams! Just for a moment, I want you to think one thing; Whatever you believe is real, is real!" From there, the young magician began her acts, turning snow to bubbles, floating through metal rings, forming doves from snow angel indents, and drew in a large crowd of cheering onlookers; Gerome and Severa were amazed at the draw the entertainment magic provided, and were equally gladdened that their hunt had just gotten easier. At the end of her set, Ophelia pulled a beautiful bouquet of flowers from a young child's ear and gifted them to the girl, causing cheers to erupt from the crowd. "Thank you so much! You've all been a great audience!" An old man with a cane walked out from the crowd to greet the party.

"Bravo, young missy! You really lit up the town, and it's still day!" Ophelia bowed in turn, accepting the praise graciously. The old man turned to the rest of the group aboard the carriage. "Forgive me for the busy townsfolk, we have a small festival coming up in a few days. You say you needed a bed to sleep in? My name is Young Hubba, and I'm the elder of this village, pleased to meet you!" The group, minus Ophelia, had sworn they heard the name before, or one similar, but wrote it off.

"Your hospitality is appreciated, elder. My name is Gerome, this is Severa, and Ophelia. Our two friends in the carriage, Owain and Cynthia, have fatigued themselves to continue our journey as is, and therefore we require shelter. There is one more we wish to introduce you to, if you could come with us."

"Well sonny, I'm too Young to be called Elder just yet!" Hubba chuckled at his own corny joke, but got back on topic when he realized only he laughed. "Yes, well, I can definitely allow you all to spend the night here, but what kind of journey are you youngsters on? Care to give a young elder a story to hear?"

"Actually, it is related to our other companion; We wish to know if you know any information regarding the ruins up north. Specifically, one mentioned in a story about a shrin-" Gerome's words were cut off by a large yell from the edge of town, drawing the crowd's attention as they began to shuffle towards the source. Gerome looked panicked, realizing he might have been wrong when speaking to Lucina before. "Oh crap!" He jumped from the cart and dashed off to the edge of town.

"Hey! Gerome, wait!" Severa realized the urgency of his run, but her pleas for him to wait fell on deaf ears. When he got to the edge of town, Gerome watched as the crowd gathered around a portly man dressed in furs, looking out of breath and scared as a lanky farmer-type comforted him.

"Hunter Tell, what's wrong? You look like you done saw a ghost!"

"W-Wyvern! In-In Woods! A-And g-giant woman!"

"Why, that's crazy talk! Everyone knows there's no such thing as a g-g-giaaa..." The farmer was cut off as he saw Lucina's figure at the edge of the woods, looking equally as panicked as Gerome that she had been spotted. Minerva had crawled out from the woods and kept a low snarl, trying to control the crowd to keep panic from erupting and her master's wife from being hurt. After what seemed like forever, Lucina gulped and finally spoke.

"H-Hello everyone...M-May I come in?" The tension in the air was thick, Lucina, Gerome, and Minerva knew not what would happen and prepared for the worst.

Several townsfolk started screaming and shrieking, running from Lucina.

Lucina held up her hand.

"Wait!"

Many paid her no heed. Minerva growled at them only, exasperating the situation. Lucina bent gently stroked her just below the neck, encouraging her to stop, though her presence still unnerved the village. Gerome tried to block the way of any fleeing townsman, spreading his arms out and succeeding in stopping some.

He shouted to them.

"Hey! That's my wife!"

That stopped some more, and several other villagers looked at him curiously.

"You're wife?" "How do they-"

The death glare Gerome gave persuaded that villager not to finish his question.

Lucina sighed loudly, drawing attention back to herself.

"I know my appearance might be alarming, but I assure you, as will my companions, that I am as human as anyone else."

She had the villagers curiosity, if nothing else. A few had fled, but most eyes were on her.

"But how?" One villager asked.

As strange as the situation was, Lucina was familiar with public speaking, and couldn't help but relax.

"I was once a normal human. I even thought as Khan Basillo's champion, before I assisted, then joined the Ylisse army. A few days ago strange rocks fell from the sky and landed near where I live. Somehow they caused me to grow to this size. I mean all of you no harm." She raised her out stretched palms. "I seek only a curse for my condition"

They looked at her, expressions varying from curiosity to confusion to incredulity.

"What kind of cure could we have? We're just peasants!"

"I have heard legend, known to you as a children's story about a hunter who unwittingly sought treasure that led to his downfall. I seek the shrinking Elixir so that I may return to my normal human size. If any would help me, then I would be forever in your debt. If my presence disturbs you then I will gladly depart once I receive directions."

1313111121122121111111111111111122112111.content:
"Ah! So that's what it is then, huh missy?" Parting the crowd with his words, Young Hubba came forward, not particularly shocked or frightened by Lucina's size, with Lucina's extended family in tow, cart and all. "Yup, I can see why you'd want that shrinking elixir from the story. As far as I'm aware, it's just a story, but if ya need some directions, I could always point you folks to the exact ruins from the tale." Lucina looked ecstatic at the elder's words.

"You could?!" she cried, lunging forward slightly and frightening some of the crowd. "Oh please, do tell us if you know!"

"Welp, I can certainly see you're excited!" chuckled the old man. He pulled out a folded map from his person, decorated with drawn pictures of temples, marked areas, and little facts, almost like a brochure, and held it up for Lucina's viewing. "Yup, around here, we got a lot of ruins from stories, it's kinda like a tourist attraction, so I drew up these little maps here with the rest of the town hall for the best viewing pleasure." He moved forward to hand Lucina the map, the girl squinted trying to read it, before handing it off to Gerome, deciding he could read it better. "What you folks are going to want are the 'Limestone Ruins', marked up a couple miles north from here. It's the big white-grey temple with the 8 pillars for an entrance, you can't miss it; it's a bit deep and has a couple booby traps in it, so be sure to be careful, I'm sure you can fit in it, Miss..."

"Lucina." answered back Lucina, finishing the sentence for the elder. She got up and bowed to him in return for his kindness. "Thank you for your help, elder. I'm sorry to ask further request of you, but our family members have fallen incapacitated and cannot journey with us as is, is there any way we may spend the night in your village?"

"Ask no more!" answered Hubba with glee, "The weather's cold outside, no way am I about to let you nice youngsters freeze out in the cold! I'll let you fellas stay at the hotel tonight for free, least I could do for your friend's magic show!" Ophelia held her rosy cheeks at the complement, feeling an ego boost.

"Oh, it was nothing!" she replied, head in the clouds. "Really, just some nifty little tricks!" Severa inched closer to slapping the humble into her daughter's head.

"As for you Miss Lucina," continued Hubba, "We could always let you use the town barnhouse to sleep in tonight, it's nice and warm so you don't have to lay in the cold, your wyvern could even stay with you too!" Minerva rubbed herself against Lucina's leg in response, happy to spend time with her mistress. "Just if you could, could you help us hang up a couple streamers in there before you tuck in for the night? We got the Festival Dance coming up soon."

"But Elder Hubba!" objected the lanky farmer-type, "We can't just be accepting in everyone so close to the Hunting Festival!"

"Oh pipe down you!" shouted back Hubba, waving his cane around. "First rule of our town: Never turn away a weary traveler, no matter who or what they are! And we could always use Miss Lucina's height to help us more than you could lying around that field of yours all day!" The farmer was defeated by the elder's response and folded his arms in a huff. Calmed a bit, Hubba returned back to talking with the giant princess. "Sorry about that, everyone's a bit tense so close to our local festival coming up. Let me see you folks to your staying quarters for the night, and then just ask us if you need anything else while you're staying."

"Thank you elder." replied Lucina, bowing once more. Carefully, she stepped around the crowd as she began to follow behind Young Hubba, with Gerome, Minerva, and the rest of the party in tow.

----------

"And done!" shouted Lucina as she hung the final streamer from the rafters of the barn. The whole place was set up to look like a fancy ballroom, but still had the farming village charm to it, the villagers clearly put work into their festivals. Night had just fallen, and Lucina finally got to seat herself on the floor of the barn; she sat down next to Gerome and Minerva, happy not to be seated in snow this time. "Elder Hubba was so kind to let us use the barnhouse to sleep for tonight, as well as give us a map to the ruins. I think we're reaching the end of our journey Gerome."

"Yeah..." grumbled Gerome in response. Lucina looked a little distressed at his reaction.

"What's wrong?" she inquired.

"It's those townspeople." he replied, fuming as he said it. "The elder was a nice enough man, but for those people to be treating you like a monster just got me angry is all." Lucina sighed, worried that Gerome would bust a vein just thinking about it.

"It's alright, Gerome. I don't mind their comments."

"I mind." he replied. His tone was harsh, but he decided to soften up as he continued. "I'm sorry, it's just that I think of you like I think of a treasure; precious and special. I can't help becoming furious if anyone were to hurt you, physical or not." Lucina sighed once more and grabbed Gerome swiftly, exciting some shock from the wyvern rider.

"Did you see that?" she asked her husband. "I'm a big girl now Gerome, I can fight my own battles." She gently let Gerome down before continuing. "It's not even just now, it was even during the war; I can't count how many times you put yourself in harm's way for me, I...no, we all could have lost you out there on the battlefield, I would never want to live with that."

"Mere flesh wounds couldn't end me."

"That's not the point Gerome." Lucina laid on her stomach, trying to get more down to earth with the rider. "My point is this: You've already done so much for everyone. Not just me, our family, our friends, everyone in the Shepherds, and you never took a break doing it." Lucina pulled off Gerome's mask and stared into his deep brown eyes. "The time of war is over Gerome, our nightmare from the future has ended. It's the dawn of a new era for us, an era of peace, there's no reason for you to be so tense anymore." Minerva came over to cuddle her master, licking his face as Lucina spoke to him. The princess smiled at the scene, thinking nothing else could be a more perfect illustration for her point. "We all love you Gerome, so just relax. We'll fix me eventually, I can just feel it now, and it's all thanks to you, as well as the rest of our family and friends." Gerome took all these words in, before sensibly chuckling to himself.

"It's funny, it was usually me telling you that you'll be normal again soon..." He placed his hand upon Lucina's cheek and rubbed it softly before locking lips with Lucina's massive pink lips in front of him. "I understand Lucina, I'll take it easy from here on out."

"Thank you, Gerome." Lucina tilted her head up a bit and looked through the shutters of the window; though night had fallen, it was still early, and the two were alone, save their trusted wyvern considered part of the family. "Say, Gerome?" began Lucina with a soft blush upon her face. "It's still a little early, and we're completely alone, so..." Gerome immediately picked up on the signals his wife was giving, and his face became red hot in response.

"Wait, you mean in here? Now?!" Gerome looked around, afraid at the idea of someone walking in on them. "Lucina, what if someone were to see us in here?!"

"I know, I know! I'm embarrassed too!" The full red blush on Lucina's face confirmed it, both she and Gerome looked like tomatoes; clearly the two were made for one another. "There's only one door leading into the barn, Elder Hubba told us, so if we just keep it locked, I'm sure we could..."

"Please don't say it!" Gerome took a moment to calm down before addressing his wife back. "Alright, I suppose if you want..." Gerome gave Minerva a hand signal and the wyvern blocked the only door to the barn, for extra measure, Lucina pushed a large wooden bar into a lock, completely sealing off the compound; the two were finally alone. "It's not that I don't want to..." started Gerome, "I just can't fathom the idea; How could we make this work at your size?"

"Well..." started Lucina in response, "Do you remember back in Ylisstol? What Severa told me?" Lucina bent down closer to Gerome and began whispering in his ear, the wyvern rider's face lit up like a firework at the words spoken.

"H-How does she even think something like that up?!" Gerome was clearly flustered at the suggestion, but was resolved to keep Lucina happy. "I suppose we could try, are you sure of this Lucina?"

"Not really..." she answered bluntly, face still reddening. "I just want to prepare in case this journey ends in failure." Gerome gave a light chuckle.

"Now you know exactly what I'm going to tell you." Lucina giggled back.

"Yes, yes, I know; 'Stay strong, I promise to get you back to normal again'.'" With that exchange, the two lovers began to disrobe themselves, moving in closer with each article of clothing they dropped. Lucina grasped Gerome after completely disrobing herself and moved her lips in for a deep kiss, meeting with Gerome's lips returning the action as she did, before moving Gerome lower down her body as she began to lay down. Minerva watched some of this, but fell out of interest quickly and nodded off to sleep, effortlessly blocking the door with her scaled frame and trying to block out the noise her masters were making, instead filling it with dreams of the old days of combat with Cherche and Gregor.

1313111121122121111111111111111122112111.content:
The next day, Hubba insisted the townsfolk prepare ameal for Lucina, despite her protests. She tried not to eat too much, but was grateful to the town, and Ophelia was happy to perform more magic tricks for much of the morning, before they had to depart.

The group left in good spirits, having had a great time. Lucina walked with a sping in her step, though still watched where she placed her feet. The end of her journey was near, she could feel it!

"Ha!" Owain placed an arm around Ophelia's shoulders. "Who would have though my daughter would be such a great performer? I mean I knew you'd inherit some of my flair, but you were incredible!"

Ophelia almost blushed, though she was much too brash to do so.

"Thanks daddy."

Severa rolled her eyes.

"Henry probably taught her everything she knows about magic."

"Hey I'm sure I helped to! I've been studying it now, I bet future me is a master sorcerer!"

Ophelia hugged Owain's arm.

"Yeah, you taught me a ton of cool stuff!"

Owain leaned closer to her.

"Like?"

"Yelling the names of spells with fire and passion!"

"Come on, I must have taught you some technical stuff to. Though I'm glad you know how important that is!"

"You would have but you left me in the Inv- uhhh orphanage when you fought for Nohr."

"Huh? Why would I do that."

"You said you had to fight for your friends."

Severa moved closed to the pair.

"What about me?"

"You to. You said someone had to watch over daddy or he'd go and get himself killed."

Owain turned to Severa, looking uncharacteristically serious.

"That does sound like you"

Severa folded her arms, but turned her head away so none could see the worry on her face.
"Hmmph..."

Lucina as barely listening to the conversation below, she was still smiling to herself, thinking about what she might do when she was back to her normal size. Gerome frowned.

"I don't want to kill your good mood, especially when I see you smiling like but...."

"But?"

"This "Shrinking Elixir" is just a legend from long ago. Not only do we not know if it exists or if it is in these ruins, we don't know that someone hasn't already taken it or it hasn't expired."

Lucina's smile dampened a little, but she nodded.

"I know. The thought had occurred to me. There is the possibility this expedition will be fruitless. If that is the case, we will seek a cure elsewhere and if that fails... well, if their is one thing I have learnt on this journey, it's that their are plenty of good people who will treat me as human being no matter what happens, and that I have friends and family I can count on no matter the circumstances. If I am truly to live my life as a giant, I can bear that, as long as I am surronded by people who care about me."

1313111121122121111111111111111122112111.content:
After a relatively quick journey, Tiki's party had reached the summit of Mount Prism. There they stood in the marble halls of the Temple of Naga; the sight was all too familiar for Chrom, only mere months ago he stood here, taking part in the Awakening Ritual to bless Falchion with Naga's power, and now he stood to bear witness to the creation of a new magic stone. Tiki kneeled before the effigies to her mother once again, and even without vocal request, the fiery hologram of Naga had shown itself once more; everyone watched in awe and revere at the Goddess' magnificent visage.

"Tiki, my child, welcome back." Naga scanned the room and took note of the giant Sumia and Maribelle, each holding a pile of rock, and Chrom & Robin in tow with them. "I see you have completed your quest, twicefold in fact. I also see you bring the Exalt and Blood of Grima with you; greetings to you both, I hope you all have been well since our last meeting." Robin frowned a bit as Maribelle let him and Say'ri off her shoulder, right as Naga was, he tried his hardest to forget the fact he was destined to become a harbinger of death before Lucina changed everything. "Now then, I believe we should start the ritual. It's been ages since a procedure like this was held, I may not be able to guarantee success, forgive me. From the two of you, which shall go first?"

"Lady Sumia was first after all," commented Maribelle, gracefully playing up her friend, "Please, allow her to go first."

"But Maribelle," asked back the Queen, "Didn't you say you wanted to get small as soon as possible?"

"Don't get me wrong dear," she replied, "It's not that I enjoy this, it's simply that I'd rather observe for now in case anything were to go wrong." Sumia looked in shock and started shuddering, fearing for the worst at Maribelle's somewhat rude comments. "Ah! Forgive me for speaking out of term, my lady, think more of young Cynthia! You still need to be small to have her, correct?"

"W-Well, you're right about that..." Sumia took a deep breath and removed Chrom from her bosom, placing him to the floor; she adopted a look of determination. "Alright, let's do this!"

"Please, Queen of Ylisse, if you would step forward towards me, ahead of Tiki." Sumia obeyed Naga's command and stepped forward, finding herself in the middle of a circular panel featuring the Mark of Naga. With the wave of her hand, Naga had erected several yellow rings around Sumia, and like magnets, the shards of meteor had freed themselves from Sumia's person and intertwined with the rings, almost like asteroid belts.

"Lady Naga, what's going on?" asked Sumia, concerned for her safety.

"Worry not," replied the Divine Dragon, "This is simply part of the process. Tiki, may you join me in prayer? I shall transmit my thoughts and words to you, please follow along with me."

"Yes, O Naga." responded the Manakete. With a smile on her face and flick of the wrist, Naga had shot a light blue mark from a mirror upon Tiki's head; the Manakete's eyes glowed a bright blue in response. Tiki could see it - every thought in Naga's mind became hers as well, it would be a simple task to follow along the chant in this state; focusing upon Sumia, Tiki started off the ritual. "O spirits of our fallen brethren! Please take heed of this woman's curse! May you lend us your power, flowing across eons, so we may relieve her of her ailment! Hear the prayer of our people now! Transfer your powers to the accursed stone before you!" On that, both Tiki and Naga clasped their hands together and begun chanting in sacred ancient verse, completely in sync with one another; the ancient language confused everyone else present, but they assume it was working. Rapidly, the shards of meteor began to swirl around Sumia, while the rings passed light over her like a scanner; together, the two objects worked in tandem, forming almost a barrier of light and debris around Sumia's body.

"Is she going to be okay?" asked Chrom, stepping forward to support his wife. In response, Say'ri extended her arm to block Chrom from advancing further.

"Worry not, Lord Chrom," she spoke, "Have faith in Lady Tiki and Lady Naga. They know what they're doing." For a short while, the arcs of light and stone danced around Sumia before breaking from her person and crashing into one another marvelously, forming a large, yellow orb that floated in the air before her. Tiki dropped to her knees, eyes now normal, exhausted by the act, while Sumia stared at the orb in wonder.

"Take it," beckoned Naga, "It's yours. It is linked to your body, you and you alone will be able to use it." Slowly, Sumia extended her arm and grasped the orb tightly. In an instant, she was consumed by a bright yellow light, blinding all present.

"Sumia!" shouted Chrom, concerned for her safety. When he opened his eyes again, he was treated to the visage of his wife, now her normal size again, still draped in the makeshift curtain smallclothes and holding the stone in her hands; all had shrank to a manageable size. Chrom ran forward in glee, Sumia took notice and broke into a run too; both grasped one another in a big hug and Chrom spun Sumia around in the air, a sight touching for all.

"It worked!" cried Sumia, "It actually worked! Oh, I'm so happy! Lucina can become normal again!" Tiki fully recovered and rested her hand on Sumia's shoulder with a big smile on her face, and Sumia, in response, brought her in on the group hug as well. "Oh Tiki! Thank you for all of this! I don't know how to thank you properly enough!"

"Well," she responded, "A large feast would be a good start!" Everyone present giggled, the mood was definitely brighter than before.

"Now we can start with your other friends, three by my count." spoke Naga to Tiki. "I trust you have two masses of meteors for your hero and the other giant?" The mood came to a screeching halt at this, everyone's hearts dropped in shock at Naga's words.

"Two masses?" repeated Tiki. "Forgive me, O Naga, but did you just say we need another meteor?"

"Ah, I see I should've been more specific before." Naga shook her head and cursed herself for causing confusion. "Yes, the ritual creates individual stone for each person affected by this, but for this, I require a mass of meteorite and an individual affected by the meteor. The meteor doesn't need to be the same one grew with, it's the genetic mapping that's truly important." Tiki looked flabbergasted the most out of this, she thought this plan was a sure-fire solution to Lucina's problem.

"B-But Naga," she responded, "Our hero, Lucina, the meteor she grew with is scattered far across Wyvern Valley's forest floors. How can we shrink her and Maribelle at the same time?" Angered, Maribelle glared down at the apparition of Naga and loudly made her opinion known.

"So what?! We have to choose between me and Lucina now?! One of us will be stuck like this?! How on earth is that fair to either of us?!" Naga looked a little distressed, but could not properly sympathize due to her long time of seclusion from humans.

"I'm sorry, young lady. I did not mean to cause you any distress, I hope you can forgive me." Maribelle was further angered by this.

"I ask for action, and you give me mere words?!" she cried in frustration.

"Forgive me, they are but all I have..." Maribelle felt her anger fading by Naga's calming demeanor, but soon found that anger replaced by despair. She thought Lucina deserved to be small more than she did, but at the same time, couldn't stand the idea of her normal life now completely destroyed by a mere accident; it wasn't fair at all, and the implication of it all overwhelmed her emotionally.

"I...I don't believe this..." She touched her hands to her face, holding her cheeks in disbelief at the situation. "I just wanted a happy, normal life with Robin, a normal life in Themis. I...I..." Maribelle couldn't take it anymore, she felt tears break free from her eyes and placed her hands to her face to sob into. In an instant, Maribelle turned from the rest of the party and sprinted out of the temple, intent on finding a secluded spot to cry.

"Maribelle, wait!" Robin called out as he reached out to his fleeing, giant wife. Robin turned to the rest of the party and tried to quell the heavy mood put onto them. "I'm sorry guys, but Maribelle needs me right now. I'll calm her down and we'll be back, I promise." With that, Robin ran of the temple, trying to catch up to Maribelle's huge strides; despite his intent to calm everyone, Robin's words fell on deaf ears as the mood remained tense.

"I'm so sorry..." spoke Sumia, looking ready to cry. "It's my fault she became so huge, and now I'm small instead..."

"Don't blame yourself, please." responded Chrom, hugging Sumia tightly. "I promise I won't rest until everyone is normal again, I swear of it. Let's just be happy that this solution works, and we'll worry of the rest later."

"If it's anyone's fault, it's mine." commented Tiki. "I forced you all into this in a mad attempt to fix Lucina behind everyone's backs; I should take all the blame here." Shaking off her despair, Tiki turned to Say'ri. "Say'ri, I assume you would like to get back to normal size too, would you like to go next." Say'ri stayed silent for a little bit, guilty that she too would be normal while either Lucina or Maribelle would suffer, but answered anyways.

"Yes, Lady Tiki. Thank you and Lady Naga." Say'ri stepped between Tiki and Naga, and as Naga formed the rings around her and produced the small chunk of meteor she was previously offered, the ritual to shrink Say'ri begun, the mood now tense with depression over anticipation.

Lucina's smile widenened as she caught of something in the distnace, a run down, almost collapsed temple, clearly abonded for many years, if not centuries. At her height she was the first one to see it.

"I think that's it!"

Cynthia flew closer, then quickly flew back.

"Yep! Looks like the old temple to me."

Gerome flew closer, looking at the map. He checked the landscape.

"I think we're in the right place."

Owain pumped his fist into the air and shouted.

"Good then, LET'S GO TREASURE HUNTING!"

Lucina raised her hand.

"Wait, we need to be careful. We've been warned there will be traps."

Owain laughed.

"Pfft after hundreds of years you really think any of them will still work?"

Cynthia bristled, glaring down at him as though he had spoken some blasphemy.

"Don't you read any stories? Abondend ruins and temples always have working traps!"

Gerome yelled at her.

"This isn't an adventure story!"

Lucina kept her composure, even she stepped towards the temple.

"While it is likely many of the traps set will have broken down, some may still be dangerous. Aside from traps, the building itself could prove hazardous. For all we know it could be falling apart. There is also the possibility of Risen hiding inside."

Cynthia sliced the air with her hand.

"Ha! If we come across any risen will slice them apart, like we've done a hundred times already!"

Lucina frowned.

"I know but please be careful, if you lower you're guard at the wrong moment....."

Owain sighed.

"I get it, bad stuff could happen We're not greenhorns!"

Gerome huffed..

"She's saying don't get overconfident you fool!"

Lucina looked down to him.

"Gerome there's no need for that."

"Sorry."

Owain smiled, as though Gerome had caused no slight at all.

"No hard feelings. And I get what you mean, we'll watch our backs."

Lucina nodded.

"Good."

The finally reached the temple and hit there first problem. Lucina was easily able to force the doors open, but even bending down their wasn't enough room for her to enter, she tried crawling or sliding through, but she was just too big, and her every attempt brought down more dust and debris. "Maribelle? Where are you?" Robin trekked nearly a mile and a half around the mountain woods looking for Maribelle, evidently it wasn't hard for her to make distance from the rest of the group at her size. He feared for the worst, afraid Maribelle may have hurt herself all alone or ran down to the local village to frighten everyone in her outburst; Robin knew she was a smart, level-headed, and resourceful woman, but she was prone to making horrendously rash decisions when not in the right state of mind, and now was a perfect example of that state of mind. Robin cursed under his breath, blaming himself for not planning ahead for a scenario like this. "It might take days to find her, even weeks, if she keeps on the move...! As he was about to beat himself up even further, Robin heard a soft sobbing sound coming through the trees; expecting breakthrough, he followed the noise into a grove, and found Maribelle, sitting alone and bawling into her hands by a small lake. She stared at her reflection in the pool of water for a short while before breaking back into crying, not content with her situation. Carefully, Robin walked up, not wanting Maribelle to run on him again. "Maribelle?" he calmly spoke.

"Go away!" she shouted in response, waving her hands in Robin's general direction. "I'm a monster! Leave me alone!" Robin wasn't going to give up; he strode over to Maribelle while she was turned and laid his hand upon her thigh, prompting the young noble to look down at him.

"Now look," he started, "I won't pretend I know how you feel, but you need to keep calm, we can handle this situation."

"Handle it?!" cried Maribelle in response. "You heard Tiki, we need another one of those wretched rocks, and Lucina's is long gone! There's nothing left for me! I'm stuck like this!"

"Now don't say that," Robin replied, trying to calm Maribelle down, "Lucina's still looking for that shrinking elixir, maybe then she-"

"Don't you get it?!" shouted Maribelle. "There is no elixir! It's a child's fairy tale! The chances of her finding it are slim to none!"

"Now that's not true! It's a legend, but all legends have base-"

"Robin," Maribelle choked out, "Just leave me be! I'm not normal anymore! A freak like me, I don't deserve to be your wife, just please take my fortune and marry another-"

"Alright, now that's enough!" Robin screamed at the top of his lungs, startling Maribelle; she'd never seen him take charge in quite this fashion before. He climbed up to her legs and stared directly into her face. "I'll let you shoot down all of my attempts to cheer you up as you must, but I'll be damned if I'll stand here and let you tell me to give up on our marriage! You're the woman I fell in love with, there's no way I'm leaving you! Ever!"

"Robin, I..." Maribelle didn't know what to say, she was dumbstruck by Robin's words and crude tone towards her, yet captivated by the words he spoke from the heart.

"Now I don't care what size you are; 5 feet, 60 feet, 300 feet, whatever - I will do absolutely everything in my power to make this work! If you want to be normal again, I'll go to Valm and pick up every piece of gravel I can find looking for meteor shards! And if you'd rather stay large, I'll cook every meal for you and do every single one of your chores, even if my arms give out on me!" Robin closed the distance between him and Maribelle and grabbed a wall of skin, hugging her stomach as tight as he could. "Brady and Morgan need a loving Mom to grow up around, and gods be damned, you are that Mom; so please stop this foolish talk of us leaving you, we're your family!" Maribelle's eyes watered up quickly; she grabbed Robin with both of her hands and brought him directly to her face.

"Robin!" she cried, as she began nuzzling him against her cheek and sobbing intensely, touched by the words he spoke. Happy that he finally got through to her, Robin hugged her face and felt a warm, fuzzy sensation inside his being; Robin knew on instinct it was the same love he felt when he first proposed to Maribelle.

After what seemed like hours of crying and hugging, though truly only 40 minutes or so, Maribelle had finally calmed herself down to a manageable mood. Robin sat upon her shoulder, and the two stared upon the lake together, watching the water glimmer in the closed-off dome of tree leaves and branches.

"Robin," Maribelle started, "Forgive me for being so brash before. It was unbecoming of me."

"No worries," replied the tactician, "I probably would've done the same thing if I were you." Maribelle scoffed at the idea, beginning to laugh heartily.

"You?!" she spat out between fits of laughter, "You would've acted all 'Now let's just think this through,' and shuffled around everyone as if you were playing human chess!"

"Hey, I don't sound like that..." Robin recoiled at Maribelle's shots she took, but was happy his wife was back to her old, joyful, and pompous self. "Now, I don't want to get you upset again, but are you okay to come back to the Temple now? Would you like to try and become normal again?"

"It's fine," Maribelle replied, "Forget about me, give my stone to Lucina."

"You're fine with that?" Maribelle stared out into the lake, watching the pool of water sparkle as she spoke.

"When I ran away," she began, "I was thinking purely of what would happen to me. I operated on the logic that Lucina would be small, I never did think that she didn't deserve it over me, especially after all the poor girl's been through. I've had my children already, but what if Lucina wanted some herself? Now how is that fair to take the gift of a family away from her?"

"I see your point," Robin replied, "But what about the Ball? Weren't you excited for that?" Maribelle looked a little sorrowful, but quickly shook off the feeling.

"No no, if there was anything I learned from the war, the value of life comes far over anything else, we could always entertain ourselves at home instead, I'm sure Brady and Morgan would get a kick out of having a giantess for a mother!" She stared at Robin before continuing. "Besides, imagine what I could accomplish at this size! Shipping would become a joke, the harvest would be easy, and have you seen my body in these sheets? I could become the world's largest fashion model with my physique and collection of fine cloths! If I weren't a celebrity in Themis by now, I'll soon become the largest woman they've ever heard of; quite literally in fact!" Robin smiled at his wife's conclusions, happy how quickly she turned a terrible situation into a good one.

"Now that's the woman I fell in love with! I'll help you at every step of the way!" Robin hugged Maribelle's neck, and in response, the woman stroked her husband's white hair with her pointer finger. "Would you like to go back now?"

"No, I'd rather stay here with you, just the two of us. I know it is selfish of me, but I rather enjoy not having that green-haired menace near me." Robin agreed to Maribelle's words and continued to watch the lake with her, intent on making small-talk with her. "Though," began Maribelle, "I know I said all that, but I wouldn't mind being small again once in a while. You did mean what you said when you said you'd pick up all the gravel in Valm for me, right?"

"Of course," replied Robin with no hesitation, "Anything you want, I almost killed myself for you, remember? Even so, I'm sure Lissa would be fine with growing in order to give you a shrinking stone." Maribelle's expression turned from joy to shock.

"Excuse me?!" she cried, before plucking Robin from her shoulder. "Just because I'm fine with this doesn't mean Lissa would! There's no way I'd want her to become like this!"

"But Maribelle," protested Robin, "You know how Lissa is, she'd probably like being big. Are you sure you wouldn't consider it?"

"Absolutely not!" she replied, "My treasure is not to come near those accursed rocks! If you're going to get someone, why not Cordelia? The woman's already freakishly huge to begin with, what's another couple feet?"

"That's a little mean to say you know." answered Robin. "And besides, you know she's insecure about her, uh, 'assets', I don't think there's a breastplate big enough to cover her up."

"Oh please, she could just tear a house out of the ground and wear that as a bra if that's what she's so worried about!" Maribelle thought for a moment, before coming to another conclusion. "Well what about dear Ricken? He was always complaining about being so short all the time."

"That'd just cause more problems, because then Nowi would try to get big to match her husband, and we'd have a giant dragon on our hands. Now how scary would that be?" Maribelle laughed at Robin's thought, imagining a large Nowi flying over Ylisse, trumping even Grima in size.

"Alright, I see your point! Then, how about..." From that point on, the couple sat together and discussed scenarios of if different Shepherds became giants, laughing as the scenarios ran through their heads, but being fearful of the ideas of Tharja or Anna towering over buildings. In any case, Robin had been successful in cheering his wife up, and managed even to make her enjoy the idea of life as a giant; if one thing was clear, it was that the two truly loved each other deeply.

Despite the warm feelings between them, a part of Robin was still in tactian mode. He could not completely stop the part of himself that likes to come up with plans.

"What if we find another stone piece?"

Maribelle scoffed.

"How would we manage that?!"

Robin was undeterred by her reaction.

"It is likely more fell, and at your size, it would be easier to search a wider area, or see if any remain at Wyvern Valley."

Maribelle shook her head.

"And what good would that do? Either you would only take my place, which I could not endure, or I would grow to an even more gigantic size, and to a scale where neither Naga or Tiki would be able to assist me!"

"We could ask. I would never act recklessly and risk the ones I care about, least of all you."

"Thank you but no thank you, I can endure living like this."

"We have nothing to lose just asking Tiki."

Maribelle carefully picked Robin up and placed on her shoulder. She got up slowly, ever watchful of her husband.

"I suppose... but would she even know? She still hasn't figured this out."

"It is still worth asking her."

"True." Maribelle smiled. She started walking back to mount Prisim as quickly as she could, while still being mindful of her surrondings, as well as her husband. "You always know exactly what to do, no matter the situation."

"Not always, but given time, reasonble thought and the assitance of good friends, one can make a better future."

Maribelle rolled her eyes but smiled.

"Cheesy.... but quite accurate."

Maribelle soon reached mount Prisim again. Everyone was still there, Naga, Tiki, Chrom, Sumia and Say'rii, now restored to her former size. Despite this, the mood was decidely somber.

"Oh Maribelle...." Tiki said, unable to think of anything better.

Sumia tried to run to Maribelee, but tripped.

"Maribelle, I'm sorry I took away your one chance to be normal size-"

Maribelle waved her hand, as thought it was nothing.

"Stop that, I don't hold it agaisnt you. None of us were to no. And thanks my wonderful husband." She stroked him with a finger. "I realized my life is not over, even if I am to remain like this. I will still have my family and friends and I can still be a wife, mother and model!"

"Huh?"

Maribelle swelled with pride.

"No matter what happens, we always make the best of it, and no one is better at than the two of us! My size is not merely a curse, it brings advantages with it."

Tiki looked up at her and smiled.

"That is wonderful. I feared I had failed you."

"Of course not! Besides Robin has pointed out there might be hope of restoring my size."

Robin sat up and all eyes were drawn to him..

"It is possible there maybe more stones at Wyvern vallery, or that the meteorites may have fallen elsewhere. If Maribelle were to retrieve another set of shards, would you be able to make her a stone?"

Tiki frowned.

"But if Maribelle tried to retrieve more fragments, she could grow even larger."

"We know, but the stone would still make her human size, correct?"

Everyone turned to Naga expectantly, Maribelle especially leaning in. Naga paused in thought for a moment.

"I am not sure. In all my time I have never seen anything like this. If a second meteor did affect, I do not know if one stone would be enough."

Maribelle groaned.

"So we're back to square one... I suppose I can live at this size if I must.." Everyone looked at her, clearly surprised and note entirely believing her current reaction. Maribelle continued. "I know I reacted badly at first, but that was only when I believed my life was over."

Robin clenched his fist.

"If only there was a way of knowing what effect a second exposure to a meteor fragment would have. For all we know it may only affect someone once."

"But we can't risk that. I would not, nor would I allow other to do so."

Chrom walked towards Maribelle.

"There is still hope. If Lucina finds the exlir there may be enough left over-"

Maribelle sighed.

"I doubt that."

Tiki spun round to Naga.

"Lady Naga, how likely do you think it is?"

She blinked.

"Shrinking... Elixir?"

Tiki sagged.

"So you have not heard of it...."

Chrom filled her in.

"From what Lissa told me its a fable where a greedy hunter finds an Elxir that shrinks him out of existence. Do you think such a thing would exist?"

Naga took another moment to consider this.

"Anything is possible, but I cannot say. Humans have so many legends. A surprising manner contain truth, even those that seem impossiable and yet... even if this Elixir existed there is no guarantee it would still be there or that it would still function."

Waiting on her family's results, Lucina sat outside the temple, leaning against a sturdy white pillar and rubbing her hands next to a large bonfire made of dead trees. She thought it had been a while since they entered, dusk finally taking over the sky, and couldn't help but worry of their status since she was physically unable to enter with them. Minerva cuddled up against her mistress, snuggling her scales against the soft wool of Lucina's huge scarf, the girl looked down and giggled in turn. Lucina gave a sneeze, prompting the wyvern to puff flames from her mouth to relieve her mistress of the chilly air.

"Thanks Minerva." responded Lucina with a smile, moving closer to the bonfire as she spoke. The girl reached down and wrapped both her hands around Minerva's body, hoisting her up like a small puppy and resting her upon her lap; the wyvern lowered its head and gave a purr-like bellow when pet. "I bet you're worried about Gerome, aren't you girl?" The dragon nuzzled her head into Lucina's lap in response, a sign of agreement. "I'm worried too, Gerome's resourceful, as are everyone else, but for this temple to contain such a concoction as a shrinking elixir, it must be full of traps or creatures. Severa's in no condition to fight or run either, and it distresses me to think Ophelia could watch her mother get hurt again for my sake." Lucina looked down & distressed, having no comforting words to ease her wandering mind, and Minerva couldn't help but feel powerless, being unable to speak her thoughts.

The wyvern leapt from Lucina's lap and grabbed a large burning branch from the bonfire with her jaws; shaking off the flames, she bought it close to Lucina, expecting her to pick up on the signals. "What's this?" asked the princess, holding the burnt wood close to her face, "Do you want to play fetch?" Minerva flared her nostrils in response, confirming Lucina's thoughts as correct; the princess smiled and turned around from the fire, eyeing the open snowy area of the ruins. "Alright girl, are you ready? Go fetch!" Lucina threw the branch with such strength that it disappeared from the horizon, into the darkness; Minerva immediately took off like a jet after it, intending to bring it back to her mistress. Eventually she did, receiving a pet from Lucina before the princess repeated the process again; this went on for a long series of reps, and each time Lucina threw, her mind seemed to ease itself from the stress of worrying about her family. "This was your intent, wasn't it Minerva?" thought Lucina, admiring how smart and caring the wyvern was, "Thank you so much for being with me, I don't know what I'd do without you or Gerome in my life!" The wyvern picked up on Lucina's thoughts as she viewed her face; Lucina could've sworn that as she played with the dragon, she could see the strong, rock-like mandibles of Minerva's jaw contort into a smile, an unknown phenomenon for a dragon to do.

----------

The team of warriors journeyed through the dark ruins, hands upon their sheathed weapons, carefully eyeing anything that may seem out of sort. Already, the team have encountered several traps and secret passages, and while most had been unearthed and activated, some spike traps and trapdoors had found themselves either reset or constantly active; while it was but a mere tiny obstacle for the stamina-strong Gerome & Owain and naturally acrobatic Cynthia and Ophelia, Severa found herself in a pickle in her state of pregnancy, and required Ophelia to levitate her through the obstacles present, of which her daughter happily obliged. Walking through a passage lit by a floating fire spirit, summoned from Ophelia's black magic, the heroes felt they neared the end of the temple, and looked for indication of treasure around, hoping the elixir would be among the treasures.

"My sword-hand trembles," begun Owain, "The sprits of fallen warriors possess me! They speak to my soul - The sacred elixir is bound to be within this very chamber!"

"Really?" asked Severa flatly. "You're going to make a gig out of this? This deep down? Can't you just take things seriously for one second?"

"Mommy's right." chimed Ophelia, exciting some surprise from Severa.

"See, even our daughter thinks you're loone-"

"For the spirits of demons lurk these halls! The darkness beckons to take us in our search, but I have embraced it! I promise to guide you through its malicious desire Daddy, so we may find the treasure it protects!" Owain looked charged up by Ophelia's display, matching her wavelength of excitement, while Severa palmed her face at the two, embarrassed by their actions.

"You two are right." started Gerome, scanning the mostly empty rectangular room they were in. "There's something here." Cynthia moved her hands to her weapons, one on Falchion, another on her lance, and took the stance of a tiger, ready to pounce on prey.

"Alright, bring out all the ghosts and the demons!" she cried, "I'll slice 'em all to ribbons, then cut 'em up some more and make confetti for my grand entrance to the boss monster!"

"I didn't mean that." responded Gerome, slightly annoyed by the display. "This room is hiding something. Look, it's empty, yet decorated ornately, with a small breeze of air coming through. If I had to guess, this was a place of worship for whoever designed it, it must have a secret room made to store treasure for this purpose."

"Alright, Mr. Archaeologist," shot back Severa, "Then where is this room? And how do we get inside? These walls are solid last time I checked."

"I don't know," responded Gerome, "I'm just making conjecture based upon what I see." Gerome beckoned Ophelia closer to him, bringing the flames closer to him as he inspected a pillar, rubbing his hands across the limestone. "There must be some sort of mechanism in place to open up a chamber, if I had to guess. We'll have to search stone after stone, to look for a switch."

"But that's gonna take hours!" cried Cynthia, bored by the lack of action. "I want Lucy back to normal as much as the rest of us, but can't we just break stuff instead and look for small crevices like that? It's gotta be much faster!" Pouting, Cynthia leaned against a statue of an ancient idol, and in response, it sunk into the wall, throwing Cynthia off her feet and making her crash to the floor. Upon this activation, the whole party watched as a section of wall opened up, revealing a golden chamber that flooded the room with radiant light; gold, jewels, and ornate jars filled the room, and the centerpiece that sat upon a pedestal in the middle of the room was a worn goblet, with signs of being moved before. The party was awestruck by the discovery, not expecting a result of this caliber.

"Is that the elixir?" asked Gerome. He tried not to show it, but was overjoyed at the prospect of Lucina's cure near arm's reach.

"It's so...golden." remarked Owain, awestruck by the goblet's luster.

"Woo-hoo! We found it! I'm gonna go test it out!" Cynthia got up and began running to the goblet. As Cynthia got close to Severa, the raven-haired mercenary shoved the royal blood to the floor before stamping her foot upon her back, pinning Cynthia to the ground. "Oww! Let me go Severa! What the heck was that for?!"

"You moron!" shouted Severa, "Think back to the story; The guy shrank to the size of an insect after he chugged the elixir, do you want to make a problem out of a solution after we fix up Lucina?!"

"Of course not!" protested the Pegasus Knight, "I just wanted to make sure this stuff works is all! I don't want anything else happening to Lucy after we came this far in, you know?"

"Release her Severa." At Gerome's command, Severa huffed and backed up, giving Cynthia some room to get up. Gerome got closer and put his hands on Cynthia's shoulders, speaking to his sister-in-law calmly to get his words through. "I want Lucina back to normal like the rest of us, she's my wife, but it defeats the purpose of the journey if we make you too small to handle in exchange for Lucina's shrinking. Do you understand, Cynthia?"

"I guess," pouted Cynthia, "But couldn't we just find a meteor and get me big again like that?"

"You raise a good point, but we still don't know exactly what those things are or where they came from. I don't want any negative side-effects on you either, if there are any, you're my family too after all." Cynthia's eyes got big and the girl let out a small squeal, thinking Gerome's words were adorable.

"Alright, when you put it that way, we'll surprise her with whatever this stuff does!" Gerome broke conversation with Cynthia, and the 5 heroes began to walk towards the goblet together in order to bring it back to Lucina. The gold and jewelry they walked through was enticing, mainly to Severa, but they stayed focused on their mission, closing the distance between themselves and the fabled elixir. They all leaned in together, making sure no traps would possibly activate, and gazed into the mouth of the goblet.

Owain looked around.

"I don't see any around here."

"hey it's fine! Let's get it back to her."

Nothing happened.

"...No."

"Lissa's story implied the elixir would work immediately, but that could have just been narrative convenience.

Lucina tensed up.

"We should still wait, just in case."

They waited, Lucina's companions watching her for the slightest change, but after half an hour nobody saw any change.

"Have we come all this way for nothing?"

"Maybe it was just a hoax. For all we know you just drank some out of date wine."

Cynthia fidgeted.

"Maybe we just need to keep waiting." She sounded like she was trying to convince herself as much as anyone else.

Lucina tried to force a smile.

"I suppose so... but what if I'm."

Gerome placed a hand on her.

"You said it yourself, you still have your family, you still have your friends and you still have me!"

"Thank you... I'm sorry to have brought you all here for nothing."

"We can't give up!" Cynthia said. "We still don't know for sure.."

Lucina sighed.

"I can still hope, but I must also face the inevitable truth. Everything I know about magic tells me that it either activates immediately or not at all."

"Maybe this is just a dud, maybe there's another lying around?"

Gerome gritted his teeth.

"I doubt it..."

Severa smiled.

"It couldn't hurt to give the temple another once over, while bringing back some of that fine jewlerry."

Gerome whirled around.

"You're going to loot the temple? At a time like this?!"

"Hey there not using it, it's no different than we take a choice weapon from our enemies."

"Thank you, all of you." Lucina.
