131312211211.content:
The trio look up at the moon. It's vibrant yellow shined down on them. Cynthia looked at her literal big sister. The moonlight struck her and made her stand out. She wish she could say something, but she was too enamored to say something.
At least, until Lucina let loose a yawn. To Lucina, all of that running made her tired. To Owain and Cynthia, it was a huge scare for them.

"Ack! Lucy!" Cynthia whined, "That was loud!"

"Sorry, Cynthia," Lucina apologized, "It's just that after all of this running, I'm just a bit..." Her head bobbled up and down as she tried to stay awake.

"Well, a hero needs to rest eventually," Owain commented, "Let's settle here until the sun begins to radiate its light upon us once again."

"Agreed." Lucina nodded. She took off her straps and laid Falchion aside, still keeping it close in case of an ambush. She folded up her cape and made it into a pillow of sorts and laid down on it. She would rather not do this, but with nothing to cushion her head, she has to make use of something. She looked up at the sky and eventually lulled to sleep.

"Psst, sis," a voice whispered into her ear, "I want to talk." Lucins opened her eyes and slowly turned her head towards Cynthia.

"Mmh, what's wrong?" She muttered, still drowsy.

"Owain is talking in his sleep...again..."

"Why not move somewhere else?"

"It was the only comfortable spot!"

Lucina thought for a moment. She looked at her tiny sister, and not long after, she got an idea.

"I think I know another comfortable spot." Lucina smiled before plucking Cynthia off the ground. She dragged her and carefully placed her on her chest.

"Wow, Lucy, you sure have developed over the last few years!" Cynthia complimented as the warmth of Lucina's chest enveloped her.

"E-Enough... You're making me embarrassed..."

"Hehe, oh well. Good night, sis!" Cynthia closed her eyes and quickly fell asleep. Soon, Lucina followed suit.

The sun began to rise in the horizon. As it did, the moon began to lose its glimmer, and so did the glow on the bracelet Lucina had equipped. With the loss of shine came a loss of power, and soon, Lucina began to shrink back to normal height. Unlucky for Cynthia, she fell off and hit the floor during the process. Abruptly awakened, she turned around to see Lucina shrink back to her normal size. I wouldn't take long for the princess to stir awake.

"Morning, Lucy!" Cynthia happily greeted.

"Good morning, Cynthia." Lucina reflected as she sat up. She looked at her bracelet to see that the glow has faded. In fact, she just noticed that she's back to her normal size. She got up quickly to compare herself.

"I'm back to normal..." she muttered as she conpsred her height to Cynthia.

"CYNTHIA. LUCINA." A distant voiced called to them. The two turned their heads towards the source of the voice.

Sumia, their mother. She was on her pegasus, and was arriving at high speed.

"Mother..." the two uttered as they watched her land and dismount her pegasus.
131312211211.title: Princess Cushion

1313122112111.author_name: This site is dead.I wana leave
1313122112111.content:
“Where you have been?!” Sumia shouted, as she ran towards the trio as Lucina had ever seen her run before.

“Sorry mother….” When she was hanging out with Owain and Cynthia, and when she was turned into a giant, she never even though how worried her parents might. Now that she had, a pang of guilty hit her stomach. She wanted to tell Sumia everything but how was she going to explain it? It seemed too unbelievable.

Cynthia and Owain clearly didn’t know what to say either, shuffling their feet and trying not to look Sumia in the eyes. It was rare to see them both fall silent.

“Your father and I were worried about you! We sent the whole and a squadron of pegasus riders to look for you! We thought you might have been kidnapped or worse!” Sumia paused to catch her breath, calming down as she did so. “I know the three of you can take care of yourselves but there are dangers out there even for you. I even heard people speak of a giant wondering into town! I wasn’t even sure such things existed.”

That was it, Lucina knew that was her chance to explain herself. She took a deep breath.

“Mother… you might not believe this but that giant was me.”

“What?!”

“It was because of the bracelet.” Lucina raised her. The bracelet was not glowing and showed no signs of being magical, even as Sumia inspected it again. “After the sun set the bracelet glowed and I found myself growing until I was larger than a house. I panicked, both at my sudden size and the people mistaking for a monster, so I took Cynthia and Owain in my arms and fled as fast as I could.”

“Which is actually really fast!”

“I intended to wait till the morning and then return to the castle. But with everything going on I did not think about how worried you or father might be.” Lucina hanged her head. “Sorry.”

Sumia’s eyes were wide with surprise, but she listened to Lucina’s tale without interruption. She looked Cynthia and Owain’s faces to see how they reacted to this.

“Sorry Lucina I didn’t know that bracelet was cursed! Can you get it off?”

Lucina gritted her teeth and tried to pull it off, but it would not budge. “It seems stuck to me.”

Sumia gripped Lucina in a tight hug.

“Oh Lucina I’m sorry I got you a cursed bracelet!”

“You had no way of knowing. Hopefully someone at the castle will be able to remove it.”

“Still I am sorry to put you through that!”

“It wasn’t your fault, you couldn’t have known.”

Let’s head back. Lucina you can ride with me, Owain and Cynthia I’ll get two riders to bring you back.”

Cynthia leaned forward, clearly surprised at how calm her mother was.

“Wow mom I’m surprised how well you’re taking this!”

Sumia smiled.

“I would have though such a story was far fetched, but I know you are not one to make up tall tales. After everything We’ve gone through I can believe Lucina.”

Lucina suddenly felt bad about doubting her cousin’s fanciful tales. Is it possible he really did travel to another and take part in a war she never knew about? She decided not to dwell on it, right now she this bracelet to worry about. She hoped someone at the castle would be able to help her
1313122112111.title: Anger born of worry

13131221121111.content:
The air flowed through Lucina smoothly, fluttering her hair and cape. Both she and Sumia made their way back to Ylisstol at a quick, but steady pace. Lucina looked at the ground to see how small everthing was. The trees, the road, the plains, and the greens and fields plowed, everything looked so small, the only difference being that her two feet weren't touching the ground. She estimated that they were flying around 300ft high, but it was a rough guess she had to go off of. Still, she had something in her chest, something she wanted to know ever since the fiasco last night.

"Mother..." Lucina asked her. Sumia peered around her shoulder.

"Yes, sweetie?"

"Do you think...if I were to control the power this bracelet has-"

"People wouldn't call you a monster?" Sumia finished, "Lucina, you are special. I'm sure whoever saw you were in a state of panic as well and couldn't process that it was you."

"Yes, but..." Lucina shivered a bit, "Cynthia, Owain, and I theorized about the bracelet. About how when the moon waxes closer towards a full moon..."

"Lucina, please..." Sumia paused her, "I am just as confused as you are, but really, keep that attitude of your up any further, and you might faint on the spot!" They both giggled a bit, even if the setting is not appropriate. "Still, save the questions when we get back home..."

A couple minutes later, they arrive at the training grounds in the castle. Sunia ordered a couple of pegasus knights to ferry Lucina's friends back towards the castle, and from there, the two made their walk around the castle. How it felt good to be home, even though the slew of events lasted only a couple of hours. Eventually, the two came across someone Sumia knew not too long ago. He was sitting on the floor, tasting the various sweets and pastries he had properly laid out on a blanket.

"Oh, hey, Gaius." Sumia meekly called out. Lucina's eyes flared up upon hearing his name.

"Oh, hey, Sumia." Gaius responded, his tone more mellow than usual.

"So, um, about the bracelet..."

"Blue filled me in. He had a suspicious feeling I was involved since you told him about Lucina's gift yesterday. Combine that with a scout's report last night, and well, you can piece it together."

"You're going to help me remove this, right?" Lucina demanded as she walked closer to the sweet tooth thief.

"Whoa, Butterfly, I only opened the box," Gaius defended himself, "The box didn't have a label that read 'DANGER: UNCONTROLLABLE ARTIFACT'."

"It's fine, Gaius, you shouldn't worry about it," Sumia curiously responded with a faint smirk on her face, "But at the moment, I'll have to focus on Lucina with her dilemma, so I'm afraid your sweet will-"

"Alright, Stumbles, fine, I'll help," Gaius dejected, "Just tell me what I need to do."

"Thanks, Gaius," she smiled, "I promise I will make it up to you once this is all over. Now then, can you tell me where Chrom is right now?"

"I think he's in the library with Specs. Said something about wanting to learn more about the bracelet, but you know how well he is with books." Lucina and Sumia looked at each other and laughed.

"Well, anyway, I'll see you later, and thanks."

"Take care, Sumia." Gaius waved as both she and Lucina walked away. To his surprise, Lucina stopped shortly after and turned towards him.

"Let me tell you something, Gaius," Lucina said in a nearly menacing tone, "If you want to know what it feels like having someone taller than a building chase after you, come see me once the sun has set. You will know how powerful this 'gift' you gave to my mother is." With that said, she turned back around and catched up with Sumia. Gais, meanwhile, turned back towards his stache and thought to himself.

"What did I get myself into?"

131312211211111.content:
They headed to the library, Gaius taking nervous glances at Lucina with every step.. Miriel was surprised to see the three of them together, as she had never seen Lucina and Gaius spend much time together, aside from on the battlefield.

Lucina recounted the events that had unfolded. During the strangest parts of her tale, Miriel fidgeted with her glasses, less taken aback than others had been but still clearly puzzled.

“I would not expect such an artefact to exist outside of children’s tales, but you are not known to speak falsehoods.”

“Yes, my mom said the same thing.” Only less verbose.

Sumia frowned.

“So does that mean even you haven’t read anything like this?”

Miriel nodded.

“Precisely. Though it does not mean such a thing is undocumented, merely that I have not encountered it. I read more than many but even I have not read every tome in existence.”

Lucina gritted her teeth.

“Oh.. I was hoping you would know a way of removing this bracelet.”

“Have you tried striking it with your Falchion?”

Lucina blinked, hardly believe she hadn’t thought of that herself. Perhaps it was the stress of her situation? Maybe it was because this had hit her so suddenly that she hadn’t had the chance to approach this in a cool headed fashion..

“I hadn’t thought of that… thank you.” She drew the Falchion, glad she kept it at her side.

“Wait Lucina what if you miss?!”

She spread her legs out, instinctively assuming her battle posture.

“Please trust me mother, I am a practised swords-woman. And I will strike with care. ” She held the bracelet out and raised the Falchion with her other hand but she did not immediately strike. She studied it for half a minute before brining the sword down. With a balance of speed, force and precision, Lucina brought the blade down, only for it to bounce off with a load clang.

“Impossible! The Falchion didn’t even dent it!” Lucina checked the blade and the bracelet, relieved to see at least her sword was unharmed.

“It must be woven with powerful magic indeed. Could I see the bracelet again?.” Lucina sheathed her sword and walked over to Miriel “I will check under myths and legends.”

“If there’s anything I can do to help let me know.” Lucina said.

Sumia hung her head.

“I feel so powerless…”

“We’ll just have to hope there’s something in here that can help.”

Gaius sighed. He didn’t look forward to helping out with what might be hours or days of research. but dared not argue. Lucina’s earlier words lingered in his mind, Lucina was one of the Shepard’s strongest fighters and even at her normal size was fearsome when angered he didn’t even want to think about what a giant angry Lucina would be like.

Lucina still bemoaned her plight. BUt she wondered... if she couldn't get this bracelet off her could she find a way to control it? She concentrated but nothing happened. Perhaps it's power only activated at night or perhaps she didn't know how to tape into it yet? She hoped they would find something of use before nightfall

1313122112111112.content:
"*pant* What time is it..." Cynthia whined as she dropped a makeshift wooden sword on the ground. Ever since Sumia left, Cynthia and Owain sparred for a while. Unfortunately for them, it came at the cost of having little to distract themselves with. Thank goodness there was a river nearby, so they wouldn't faint upon hunger or thirst. The two were used to such occasions in the past, but this is really taking a toll on her body ever since she agreed to help her cousin with his next play.

"Umm," Owain spitted out, "Around four...?"

"What's taking them...so long...?"

"Maybe they found a breakthrough in Lucina's Sacred Lunar Bracelet?" Owain was doing his best to keep the mood up, but between the exhausting heat and vigorous training, his facade was beginning to slip. He looked up at the trees, imagining Lucina towering above them.

"Say, Owain..." Cynthia said as she took a swig from her canteen, "About Lucina as she was huge."

"...Yeah?" Owain responded. He doesn't know why, but he's got a pit in his stomach as if he knew what she was going to ask.

"Did you, umm...feel overwhelmed?" She looked down at the ground, only to gaze her eyes at the trees Owain was looking at.

"Overwhelmed? I think anyone would feel that way upon seeing a giantess."

"No, not like that," Cynthia denied as she shook her head, "I sensed something. A great amount of power."

"So you felt it too..." Owain said as he wiped some of the sweat from his forehead, "I knew Lucina was powerful, but it seems the bracelet gave her something enormous."

"Do you think it's the Brand of the Exalt-?"

"Amplifying its intended use?" Owain cutted off as he turned his head towards Cynthia, with Cynthia doing the same to him.

"Owain..." Cynthia muttered as her voiced quivered slightly, "I-I'm scared for Sis. What if the bracelet makes her too big? What if she begins to hurt other unintentionally..."

"Stay strong, Cynthia. I'm sure the magnificent scholars back at home will have an answer soon enough." Owain patted his hand on Cynthia's back to ease her fears. After all, Lucina has endured many hardships ever since she took up her father's sword. She has leaded everyone to combat the menace that plagued their future, went back in time to avert the doom and change the stars of destiny. Without her, Owain couldn't imagine what would happen.

"You're right. Sis is strong! No way will she let an evil artifact hurt the people she loves! SHE WILL LEARN TO CONTROL-"

"My, Cynthia, keep your voice down." A voice told her. She turned around to see the source, only to see a pegasus knight she knew very well.

"Oh, hi, Cordelia!" She waved at her as the duo approached her.

"Hey Cordelia," Owain greeted, "So how is-"

"I'm fine, if that's what you're asking..." A bitter voice rang out.

"Oh, Severa..." Cynthia frowned as the red-haired churl got off the pegasus she was riding.

"What? You're still upset over that one time I curb-stomped your-"

"Shut up!" Cynthia yelled, "You knew I'm not the best at using an axe, anti-hero!"

"ANYWAY," Cordelia raised her voice in a commanding tone, "I'm sorry for being late. Chrom filled me in on what happened-"

"Which I had to remind her constantly by the way." Severa interrupted.

"And he told me to get some supplies for Lucina! Tonight is a half-moon, so I made sure to stock up on extra!" Cordelia quickly re-railed. Owain and Cynthia rolled their eyes at what Severa was implying.

"Well, as long as we make it there before sundown, I think we can control the situation and help Lucina control her awesome power!" Owain affirmed.

"We can make it there by dusk, sure!" Cordelia reaffirmed, "I just need to pass by a village to pick up a research report about the bracelet Lucina is wearing."

"That sounds great, let's go now!" Cynthia said. The others nodded and hopped on, with Owain riding with Severa, and Cynthia with Cordelia. Not long after, they departed towards the village Cordelia mentioned.

"By the way, Owain," Severa yelled as she turned her head, "Once this is all over, you're giving me that bracelet. I'm not letting Lucina have all the fun being gigantic!" Owain flinched at the idea. Severa is always in a bad mood, but what if that attitude carried over as a giantess? Taming her at normal size was difficult enough, but for a 30ft tall Severa? He dreaded for that day to come.

"I'll think about it!" Owain responded. Severa flipped her hair and smiled.

"I'll remember that~!"

13131221121111122.content:
Back at the castle library everyone noticed the sun would soon be setting. Books were open all around them, but everyone in the library was dejected. Lucina gritted her teeth

“All this research and nothing….”

Miriel rarely showed much emotion, but she too gritted her teeth.

“Strange I excepted one of these tomes to have the knowledge we seek. Or maybe we haven’t investigated enough.”

Gaius took another lollipop out of his pocket, despite the amount he had gone through he somehow managed to avoid running out

“Specs if we didn’t find it now what makes you think we’ll find later? You know these books better than any of us.”

Lucina leaned over.

“Isn’t there anyone who could help us?”

Miriel nudged her glasses.

“Humans are unfamiliar with arts of transmutation. You would be best seeking someone more versed in the art of body shifting?”

Lucina looked at everyone else in the Library, hoping someone would be able to translate.

“What’s she saying?”

Sumia thought about it for a second.

“I think Miriel is saying to.. of course Tiki! Tiki might have seen a bracelet like this.”

“Or know how to get that bracelet off Lucina.” Gaius said.

Lucina smiled.

“Or be able to forge a stone that could let me control the Bracelet’s power! Thank you Miriel.” She noticed the sun was close to setting. “Now we had better leave your library before nightfall.”

Sumia placed a hang on Lucina.

“Well we didn’t manage to find what we looking for but we have a lead.”

“True. If anyone can help us, it’s likely Tiki. Now we have to get out of here!.

On the way out they ran into Owain and Cynthia.

“We’re back!”

“And we got supplies.”

“Thank you, though it’s only going to be a few hours…. I hope” Lucina’s stomach rumbled.”Hmm I hadn’t stopped to eat, I should get something before night falls.”

“Yeah if you get hungry AND big you could drain the castle larder.” Owain nudged her. “Uhh sorry.”

“It’s fine I just need to get to a safe spot and-”

Lucina had not been quick enough. The sun had set and the moon started to rise. As its light hit Lucina she felt a familiar sensation. She knew what was coming. But this time the sensation felt stronger than before. Everyone stared as she rose higher and higher and Lucina realised she was fast exceeding her previous size. Everything seemed much smaller than last time and those around her back away.

“Woah Lucina you’re extra big this time!”

“It must be because of the phase of the moon...”

Judging by the relative size of everything, Lucina estimated she was roughly twice the the size she was last night. Would this get worse with each night? If she was this big now then just how big would she be. Would she dwarf all of Ylisse?

How did this happen to her? That bracelet, all of this started with that accursed bracelet.. that Gaius gave Sumia! This was all his fault! He had to pay for this.

“GAIUS!” Lucina screamed. She brought her boot down at him, which the thief only narrowly managed to avoid. “YOU DID THIS TO ME!”

The sight of a gigantic and enraged Lucina was every bit as terrifying as Gaius had imagined but was she actually trying to kill him?!

Lucina felt several tugs at her leg.

“Lucina stop! He didn’t mean to do this!” “And even if he did he’s still a Shepard!”

“Get off me!” With one swing Lucina effortlessly threw them and stomped after Gaius. Gaius had already started running, but with her size, Lucina had no trouble closing the gap.

Sumia, Owain and Cynthia chased her.

“Lucina! This isn’t you! Snap out of it!” Owain called her her.

Lucina paid him no heed. Gaius wasn’t thinking of where he was only going, only in running away from her as fast he could, yet he soon found himself cornered. He gripped his blade. Even if Lucina were her normal size he wouldn’t fancy his chances against her.

“L-Lucina I’m sorry I didn’t mean to do this please don’t kill me!”

Lucina raised her foot again. Her family ran after

“Lucina!” Sumia called. “Don’t do this! I don’t know what happened to you but you’re still human! The Lucina I know, the Lucina who is my daughter would never do this!”

Lucina flinched, suddenly feeling a stabbing pain in her head. She clutched it. “You’re right…. What am I doing? I-I’m sorry Gaius… I’m a danger to others, I have to get out of here.”

Lucina stepped away from Gaius and before anyone could stop she ran, bounding over the castle walls, which were only waist high to her

13133.content:
Lucina laid back against the soft grass of the field where the Shepherds has set up camp. She heard the younger Shepherds, the ones who followed her through time, all doing their own thing, though most were training. She yawned as she began to fall asleep.

It wasn’t long but it felt much longer, Lucina opened her eyes and gasped as she looked around. Moments ago everything was fine and now, everything around her was huge. She leapt to her feet and looked around trying to determine the best course of action.

The ground quaked as someone walked nearby. “Lucy?!” Morgan called as she walked, unaware of the tiny princess on the ground.

Lucina gazed up at the giant Morgan, her eyes filled with a mixture of fear and relief. If she could get the young tactician’s attention, she might be saved. “Morgan!” She called as she flailed her arms to get Morgan’s attention.
13133.title: Tiny Lucina

choices: Go to another Shepherd for help
131331.content:
Morgan stopped in her tracks and let out a defeated sigh. She and Lucina had planned to hang out as best friends would. But the young princess wasn’t anywhere to be found. The young Tactician glances at the ground, noticing something very small flailing about. “Huh?” She kneels down to get a better look.

Lucina sees Morgan kneel and breaths a sigh of relief. She feels the young Tactician’s fingers wrap around her and lift her up to eye leave. Morgan looks over the tiny princess, shock fills her expression as she recognizes Lucina. “Lucy?” Morgan questions as she holds the tiny princess in her palm.

“Yeah, it’s me.” Lucina responds as she looks up at Morgan.

“How did this—-“ Morgan began before stopping.

Lucina shook her head. “I don’t know, Morgan. I was fine one moment. Nodded off for a split second then next thing I knew, I was tiny.”

Morgan nodded as she stood slowly, being extra gentle with Lucina.

The sorceress sighed as she made her way into her tent, clenching her fists until her nails left marks in her palms. She was frustrated, but she couldn't stay mad at her beloved for too long. It wasn't Robin's fault. The tactician simply didn't know what they wanted.

"It wasn't entirely a waste of time," Tharja said to herself, looking down into the clump of hair in her hand. It took all the self control not to tamper with the lock of snow white hair. Tonight her plan would be completed, and the tactician would be only hers instead of always being by the blasted exalt Chrom. Oh how she hated him, all he did was steal her precious Robin's attention.

She waited for nightfall before practically pouncing on an iridescent tome. Years of magic and mental preparation were required to even perform the most basic spells in the tome, but she knew it would be well worth it. Tharja read from the book, reciting the incantations until the room filled with a blue light that formed a circle in the center of the tome. She held up the lock of hair and dropped it into the seemingly bottomless hole.

In a quick burst of light, a tiny dart of energy darted out the tent, prompting the sorceress to follow it through the camp. Realizing it went straight into Robin's tent, a sickly sweet smile formed on her lips as she entered the tactician's living space and saw a shrunken ___________ on the cot.
132.title: Tharja's Bird Obsession

choices: Robin plays along until he finds an opportunity to escape.

The dark haired magician cupped the shrunken man in her palms, resisting the urge to rub her finger against the tiny form. She found it absolutely adorable that the tactician had passed out in his full outfit, massive cloak and all. Robin must have been so tired to even bother changing, or maybe he fell asleep reading and studying tactics. She just knew there was a reason she was obsessed with Robin, his boundless dedication was one of the many qualities the sorceress loved.

Just then the tiny form in her hand began to stir, which caught Tharja a little off guard as Robin was a known heavy sleeper. The shrunken man's shifts were a little jarring, completely different from Robin's average turning in his sleep.

"My head," Robin moaned, planting his hand against his throbbing forehead. "What happened?"
"Isn't it obvious, little man?" Tharja cooed.

The shrunken man's heart stopped for a few seconds right before he let out a bloodcurdling shriek as the idea of a massive Tharja finally registered in his mind.

"How did you get so big?"
"I didn't," Tharja nearly chuckled at Robin's naive question, "you're just small."

"But why!?" Robin shouted, backing away from the sorceress before stopping at the edge of Tharja's palm.
"So you could be with me."

Robin swallowed a lump in his throat, knowing fully well that the titaness could not be reasoned with. "But I'm married!" he tried to plead as she hoped personal boundaries would be respected at some level.
"You don't have to worry about that." Tharja argued.

The giant sorceress let go of her prized tactician after hearing soft, pitiful gasps from her chest. Smiling, she lifted the shrunken Robin to her face and blew a taunting kiss.

"Don't fret, my dear. As... heavenly as that demise might have seemed, I still have much planned for you."

Robin only groaned, knowing that the massive psychopath wouldn't even pull back on her attempt to court him. At times where he was backed up with little hope, he always thought of his wife, but he wasn't sure if he could even handle her at his current size. Then again, anyone would be preferable than Tharja.

Holding on to the thought, Robin kept calm as he was placed onto his tactics desk. He backed away, horrified as the model landscape only seemed to magnify Tharja's size. She towered over him and the model's pieces as she climbed on top of the desk, crawling towards him until her generous chest hung directly over him.

He made a mental note to propose the idea to his wife if her ever got out alive. Getting his mind out of the gutter, Robin quickly thought of an idea to get the sorceress to leave him alone just for a few minutes.

"Th-Tharja!" Robin called weakly, "I'm not that type of... I need... uh candle lights and flower pedals. Don't you want it to be err, special?"

Tharja paused her advancements, entertaining her cowering love's proposal.

"Well... It would make our first time more memorable."

If irony could kill, Robin would have died on the spot.

"Ooh," the sorceress moaned, "maybe I could start a bath just for the two of us." Tharja slowly got off the table, blowing a kiss to the tiny tactician before leaving the tent.

Robin, relieved but still frightened. shot up. And with a sense of urgency he bolted towards the edge. He furiously dug into his coat, forcing out a shimmering tome of Elwind. He took in a deep breath, calming his nerves enough to not miss the timing of his spell. He jumped off the table, a surreal experience that nearly paralyzed him until he suddenly remembered the lifesaving spellbook in his hand.

The tome easily slowed his fall, and Robin hit the ground with no serious injury. He sprinted towards the half open tent flap, regretting the agility training he had missed to study tactics. And at that point it finally occurred to him that his spouse must have been on night watch or else she would've shrunk along with him.

Thanking Naga, Robin desperately bolted out of the tent and into the shadows of the camp.

Taking a short break to recollect his wits. Robin quickly noted how difficult it would be to track down his beloved wife. There was a good chance he'd run into Tharja, or even some night crawling insects.

He shuddered at the thought of Tharja.

His mind came across a much safer option that involved finding his daughter, Morgan. And if was just like her father, she would be soundly asleep in her tent. He just had to hope she wasn't as sound of a sleeper as he was.

Feeling a little off put on exactly how small he was, Robin rushed three tents down from his, staring up at awe at the sheer height of the structure. He stepped inside the of the tent, hearing a familiar snore that could only belong to his daughter. He sighed at Morgan's carelessness, noticing a still lit, half burnt candle at her bedside.


Robin's daughter was lying face down, her head resting against one arm while her other arm hung over the cot. Robin stopped at the plush fingertips, marveling at their size as they easily dwarfed him. He pushed against Morgan's ring finger only to have it flick him back in a subconscious response. He was sent back by the force with only some of his pride damaged after being manhandled by his sleeping daughter.

He dug around his coat, pulling out a thunder tome. He sighed, knowing that his daughter wouldn't be too happy about being shocked awake. He felt the slight charge at his fingertips as he flipped open the tome. Grimacing at the idea of harming his child, Robin hoped his magical capabilities had scaled down with him.

"OW!" Morgan yelped, shooting up into a sitting position on her cot. She sucked on her finger, hoping to cool the burning sensation. She scanned the floor, her eyes lighting up in apparent interest. "What kind of bug bites like that?"

'Bug?" Robin said to himself, fearing the worst.

But before Robin could even call out, he was encased in a warm fleshy compress as two giant hands had cupped him in between. He was lifted up to a blown up version of his daughter's face, her lips curled into a slight smile.

"F-Father? Is that really you?" Morgan asked, "You're soooo teeny."
Robin couldn't help but chuckle at his daughter's innocent diction. "Yeah it's me."

If only I could find a way to shrink mom and Severa. Morgan thought to herself.

And from the look on Severa's face, Morgan figured that her sister was thinking the same thing.

It didn't really take the three too long to sleep once Severa blew the candle out.

Robin was the first to wake up, feeling a soft pressure on his back, and once his eyes opened, he realized he was pinned under his red head daughter's cheek. He forced himself out, rubbing out a small amount of drool out of his hair. There was a warm wave of humid heat at his back. He scrunched his face at his daughter's morning breath, but he figured it was better than whatever place he would have woken up in with Tharja.

He pushed against Morgan's cheek, shouting her name, but the girl was still sleeping. He pressed harder, eventually causing her to stir. A light shadow then loomed over the tiny Robin, and he slowly shifted to face the giant who held her arms close together.

"You might as well quit," Severa chided playfully, "you'll never wake her up." The giant lifted her father into her own hands before using her free hand to shake her younger sister awake.

"I'm keeping your father with me until you both prove that you are responsible enough."

Carrying her husband in her palm, Cordelia made her way back, her children following sheepishly behind. The siblings were silent, somewhat thankful that there mother had stepped in instead of someone else.

Severa groaned, "fine, we'll go see her later. Just don't say anything stupid and let me do the talking."

Robin found himself sitting on a stack of tomes, looking up at his wife who desperately scanned each book for a cure. He couldn't help but admire her, watching intently as Cordelia tossed another spell tome over her shoulder in frustration. The shrunken tactician counted his blessings, finding himself extremely lucky that his wife still cared for him at his most vulnerable.

His daughters on the other hand, seemed to take his affliction in stride. Sure, he loved them, but the full weight of the situation had't really dawned on them.

"Do you think we were hard on them?" Robin asked, kicking against the spine of a tome.
"Well they did almost have you sold to some stranger."

"I know, but... it truly was an accident."
"You have to be stern with them, Robin." Cordelia pressed. "You're letting them walk all over you, and that was before you shrunk."

"I can't really help it."
"I know. I can you get all weak when they play the Daddy's little girl card." Cordelia teased.

The pegasus knight couldn't help but find her tiny husband adorable. Before he shrunk, he had a certain charm to him that she couldn't place, and his new size seemed to amplify it.After a few minutes, she found herself ignoring the passages before her as her focus shifted to the shrunken tactician.

She plucked her husband between her fingertips. She giggled lightly as the tiny tactician struggled against her grip. He seemed to calm down after she flashed him a smile.

"You know what I just realized?" Cordelia asked, her voice low and husky.
"What?" Robin asked, still naive to her tone.
"From you running the Shepherds and my night patrols, it's been a while since we've had time alone."

"Oh," Robin piped, finally getting her drift. He was brought to her lips and into a quick, smothering kiss as Cordelia made her way to their shared cot.
"I'm a little tense from staying up all night. You mind giving me a little massage?"

Robin felt his knees nearly buckle from her voice, eager to treat his wife.

But just before Cordelia lowered herself onto the bed, there was a startled call in the distance.

"MOOOM!" The voice cried, getting closer by the second.

It didn't take too long for the two to realize that it was the cry of one of their daughters. Cordelia shot up, facing towards the door to tend to her child.

The inside of Tharja's tent was thrown into disarray as Cordelia all but tore apart the tent. She kicked at a stack of tomes in frustration, grunting just to release her building stress. Her search produced no results, making her nervous as the minutes went on.

"Mother?" A meek voice called, followed by a cautious head poking into the tent. "I think I've finally recovered from the last hex."

Cordelia froze in place, staring back at the enemy's daughter who was also solidly stiff.

"What hex?" Cordelia interrogated, stepping closer.

"N-nothing, Miss Cordelia! Forget I said anything. My mother doesn't test curses on me--what?"

"It's okay, sweetie." Cordelia comforted, "I know the sort of person your mother can be. What was the hex? Did it have anything to do with shrinking?"

Noire, a little worried from the pegasus knight's tone, swallowed the spit in her mouth nervously. She shook her head, "no, but she said she was going to test that one on me when I recovered from her sickness hex."

"Well," Cordelia sighed with a grisly tone, "she won't have to test it on you. It works."

The red head stuck her hand out, revealing her shrunken husband sitting on her palm.

"R-robin? Is that you?"

The tactician nodded grimly.

"Is there anything I can do?" Was all the archer asked. "Maybe I can convince my mother to try to change you back."

"Believe me we've tried." Cordelia shot back. Tharja won't be swayed. She has no incentive to change Robin back."

Robin paused, thinking his options through. He racked his brain, finding only one reasonable option.

"Actually, if we perform the shrinking hex on her. Then she'll have a real motivation to find a cure."

"You want me to shrink my mom?" Noire guessed, feeling her chest tense up.

"Please, Noire. You can watch over her yourself, but please help." Cordelia begged, "she already got my husband and my baby Morgan."

"I'll do it." Noire answered stiffly.

"Thank you, I don't know how I could ever repay you."

The group left the tent, heading back towards where Tharja was captured. Fortunately, the sorceress was still bound in place, albeit still struggling. Severa stood off to the side, keeping a steel lance pointed at the dark mage.

"Mother! You're back... With Noire."

"Don't worry, Severa. Noire's here to help." Cordelia answered calmly, noticing the tension in her daughter's tone.

"You Dastards!" Tharja screamed, "turning my own daughter against me. That's a new low."

"Look who's talking." Severa spat, restraining the urge to kick the bound woman.

Noire kneeled by her mother's side, reaching for the spell book off to the side and finding the page with the shrinking hex.

"Noire! My sweet daughter. Release me!"

"No, Mother. I'm standing up for myself. It was fine when you tested your hexes on me, but you can't do it to my friends."

Though she was an archer on the battlefield, Noire was familiar with dark magic thanks to her mother. She retired the words on the page, feeling a familiar energy run through her. The sorceress struggled harder, feeling the hex take place as her body began to reduce in size.

When it was all over, Noire towered over her inch tall mother. She held Tharja in her hands, feeling a sense of catharsis and responsibility as her mother felt completely fragile.

"I'm really sorry for what my mother did," Noire apologized, turning towards the family. "I promise that we'll find a cure. Even if it takes weeks, months, even years."

The archer walked off, closing her palms around her mother, effectively silencing her obscenities.

Cordelia looked down at the two figures in her palm. While she was concerned for her husband and daughter's well being, she couldn't help but feel that there was an odd charm to her tiny family. Maybe it was the way that Morgan excitedly bobbed in her hand. Still, the mother was glad that her eldest daughter was spared, stowing away the idea of a tiny, grumpy Severa with a light giggle.

The family found themselves inside Cordelia and Robin's tent, processing the events of the day. Somehow and thankfully, they were all in one piece, which was more than Cordelia expected.

Balling her hands into a tight fist, Severa paced around the room, muttering expletives under her breath. Her mother pretended not to hear, letting her daughter stew in her anger.

"This sucks!" Severa griped, crossing her arms in discontent. "What are we supposed to do, just sit here and wait for a cure!?"

"There's not much we could do." Robin answered blandly. "These kinds of things require patience to get through."

"I know but... UGH! I'm going to punch a tree or something."

"Ooh! Can I come?" Morgan chirped, jumping from her mother's palm.

"Uh, I don't think it's saf--," the mercenary excused, "sure, whatever."

She felt like she needed to clear her head and felt it was best to do it alone... up until her sister had asked to come along. Although her self-shaming thoughts were often set aside by her younger sibling's lively attitude despite being an inch tall.

"Um, where are we going, Severa?" Morgan asked once she noticed that Severa had no intention of stopping.

"Just give it a minute, will you?" Severa snapped, closing her fist around her sister. Feeling a slight pang of regret, she loosened her grip but still kept her aloof expression while she brightened her strides.

The mercenary, after minutes of walking, stopped on the shoreline of a small lake. She sat just short of the water, opening her hand to grant her sister a view.

"Whoa! This would be a really cool place to set up camp."

"Which is exactly why I didn't tell Daddy about it when he sent us scouting for a place to settle. I needed a place to think, and the still water calms me down."

Sitting in silence, Severa placed her sister on the ground next to her. She stretched her legs out, making sure not to knock over Morgan.

Severa stood to her full height, towering over her tiny sister as she began to pull off her armor, nonchalantly dropping her clothes dangerously close to her sister. Smirking, she watched her shrunken sister dodge the incoming breastplate.

"What are you doing, sis!?" Morgan cried right before jumping out of the way of a falling boot. "I'm still down here!"

"I know," she answered cheekily, holding her hands against her hips. "I'm going for a dip, care to join?"

Morgan kicked at the dirt beneath her," um, I don't think this is a good--"

"Oh shut up. You wanted to come along, didn't you?"

"Well yeah, but--"

Before Morgan could even finish, she was scooped up in her sister's hand and lifted in front of Severa's face. she felt a slight tugging on her back just as her coat was ripped from her body and dropped onto Severa's clothes pile.

"Don't be such a baby, Morgan. A little water never hurt anyone."

Stepping into the icy water, Severa ignored her sister's protests, moving deeper until she was wading in the water on her back, her shrunken sister resting on her stomach.

"Come on, sis! This isn't funny! You know I can't swim."

"Oh, hush, dummy. I taught you myself, rememb--" Severa paused in thought, looking into the unamused look in Morgan's eyes. "Well I suppose I could teach you again."

The larger sister brought her hand closer to Morgan, curling her index finger behind her thumb. And in a split second, Morgan was sent flying throughout the air, landing with an audible splash. The red haired sister struggled for help, spitting out water and kicking to gain leverage.

"Severa! Stop! Help me!"

There was sigh off in the distance before a massive hand plucked the drowning girl from the water.

"Don't cry, Morgan. Your big sissy is here." Severa patronized. "Gawds, this lake is barely chest high, and you're already crying."

Exhaling reluctantly, Severa walked out of the lake before chuckling to herself.

"What?"

"The first time I taught you how to swim. It sorta happened a lot like that, too."

"Really? Come on tell me more."

"Pssh. It's not that interesting. You were six and I was eight, I think. Mom and Dad were out visiting the exalt, so I took you out to the lake by the town and just threw you in."

"You were always so gentle," Morgan quipped.

Severa laughed again before saying, "I had to buy you some candy just so you wouldn't tell Mom."

"Well it wouldn't hurt to take me out for some cake or something, Or else I'm telling."

Morgan stuck her tongue out at her sister, eliciting a giggle from Severa.

Staring into her sister's open mouth, Morgan screamed for help, feeling Severa's warm breath wash over her. Her heart raced, completely startled by Severa's display of power. She closed her eyes, shuddering as she drew near her older sister's lips.

Morgan kicked herself for not realizing the joke as Severa lightly kissed her younger sister on the head.

"You should've seen the look on your face." Severa teased, fighting to hold back her laughter.

Tharja clicked her teeth in frustration. Yet again her forced attempt at a cure for her new hex had failed. She'd been at this for a couple of hours now trying to make the potted plant in front of her grow while her treacherous daughter from the future, Noire stood over her.

She still could hardly believe that Noire had shrunk her with her own hex. Who knew the meek girl actually had a backbone? She would never admit it, but a small part of her was kind of proud that her daughter had stood up to her and used her own hex against her with hesitation.

But that didn't mean she was just going to forgive and forget. Noire had still crossed her and for that she had to pay. And Tharja would make sure to make Noire pay with interest. But for now though she would bide her time and look for a cure. After all she couldn't enjoy her sweet Robin the way she wanted if they were on even footing. Plus she still had a Pegasus knight and mercenary to repay.

"I-It didn't work a-again." Noire commented from her seat at her mother's desk. She watched the diminished drk mage try and fail yet again to grow the plant. Since she'd shrunken her down to size, finding a cure was proving to be more difficult. Tharja would have to yell up to her to get something or read book passages aloud as she couldn't at her size.

Admittedly Noire couldn't help but feel a slight sense of satisfaction at finally having the roles reversed for a change. She was now the stronger of the pair as her mother was now fragile. But she could still never shake off the ominous aura the woman projected. Even tiny, Tharja made her uneasy.

"Damn. Nothing is working." Tharja whispered. As much as she hated to admit it she needed help. She needed another practitioner of the dark arts. Someone who just as much about hex as she did. It killed her inside knowing she would have to ask that man for help.

"Maybe we should try something else?" Noire suggested.

"Maybe?" Tharja agreed as she eyed her spellbook. If only she could lift it, she'd make her daughter pay. But if she tried anything now without protection, she'd risk invoking the girl's much more agressive side. Despite the front she put up, Tharja had no desire to be squished. Noire's pinky alone could flatten her. A fact that annoyed her to no end.

"I'll dump this cauldron and we can start again." Noire then proceeded ofver to the boiling black pot of purple goop. Nothing they mixed in it worked so it only made sense to dump it and start from scratch. While Noire was distracted by this task, Tharja pulled a small coin purse from under her outfit and dropped it on the ground. Reciting her hex from memory she chanted it at the coin purse and looked on with anticipation. Sure enough it shrank away until it was 1inch tall (To her at least).

"Excellent." Tharja smiled. She then felt slightly dizzy after as she used her hex without her book. With the knowlege she can still shrink things the first idea that comes to mind is to shrink her spellbook and then punish Noire for her humiliation. But then again using the spell without her book had tired her out and there were no guarantees that at her size her spell would be enough to shrink Noire down, even with the book. At worst she'd be digging her own grave deeper.

Maybe it would be safer to just bide her time like she'd been doing? Maybe even call in a favor when she was all alone? While she pondered her options she could hear the telltale sound of her cauldron's contents being poured out on the ground outside.

Tharja bit her lip. What did she choose?

The blue haired tactician scurried across the floor, avoiding his massive sister's footfalls. Although, there was something entrancing about the way Lucina paced around the tent, mesmerizing, hypnotic.

It was too late by the time he realized his beloved big sister's blue leather was descending upon him.

Fortunately, the only injury he had sustained was a piercing headache as he was safely and conveniently tucked in the small lift between the boot's sole and heel with more than enough room to move around.

"Just how small am I?" Morgan asked himself. If he remembered correctly, the heels of her boots weren't even high, just a slight half inch lift.

Just then his sister's monolithic boot was lifted high into the air and dropped far off into the distance with a heavy, but nowhere near painful thud.

There was a loud creaking in the distance as he turned to see his sister sitting on her cot across from his own. Being siblings, the two shared a tent, unlike the other unwed Shepherds who were paired by gender. He didn't mind it as much since it provided him an opportunity to make up for lost time due to his amnesia.

He ultimately decided against climbing his sister, completely afraid of the risks involved.

Rushing in and scaling Lucina was something his reckless father Chrom would have done. No, he needed a bit more finesse, a more tactical approach. Something safe, yet effective.

He stared at his tactician coat for some inspiration until his eyes slowly landed on a bright yellow tome sticking out of one of its pockets. A smile crept along his face as an idea came into mind.

He rushed over to his coat, taking about a minute or two to finally reach his goal. He stopped at the base of the cloth before he slowly began traversing it.

"Morgan?" Lucina called. The shrunken boy's ears perked up at the sound of his name. "I swear he's just as sloppy as father."

Morgan's stomach dropped once he realized she was referring to the discarded tactician coat by her cot.

"Pig!" Lucina yelled at no one in particular, hoping to get a rise out of her little brother, but no response came, at least not one she could hear. Down below her brother ignored the obviously joking callout and opted to scream for his sister's attention, but he grew a little frustrated as she never caught his shouts.

Instead of being discouraged, Morgan kept climbing his coat, taking much longer to scale it than walk to it.

Luckily for him, Lucina seemed to be in no rush as she halfhazardly kicked off her boots, but unfortunately they were tossed in his general direction. The shrunken tactician let out a horrified scream as one of the ankle high boots soared over his head and the other landing directly in front of him, pressing into the coat.

The heat hit him first, and then the smell followed as Lucina's left boot forced his eyes to water.

Morgan made a mental note not to ever mention this to his sister.

With the added terror used productively, Morgan finally reached the exposed tome. He dropped to his knees, letting the familiar electrical charge energize his body. It was a simple lightning tome thankfully, and if done correctly it should just register as a quick static shock.

"I'm really sorry, Luci," Morgan said under his breath, knowing that there was absolutely no chance of his sister hearing his apology.

He aimed for Lucina's bare feet, a little touch of payback for the earlier incident. And in a flash, a bolt was sent and Lucina jumped, letting out a surprised shout of pain.

She stood up, searching for the source, but she only found a half buried tome inside her younger brother's cloak. It struck her as odd, as she realized that tomes never discharge like that.

As it turned out she was right as there was an impossiblly small form on the tome itself. She kneeled over, granting the near speck a rather surreal view of her face. And on closer inspection, she quickly identified the source as her brother Morgan.

Her little brother.

"Mor-Morgan? Is that really you?"

Sheepishly, the tiny boy simply answered, "yeah."

Lucina claimed a plate of meat from the mess tent counter and took a seat at a bench, depositing the meal and Morgan in front of her. Morgan stared at the colossal pile of warm venison before him, mouth watering. The boy's stomach roared as he eyed the gigantic meal, until Lucina's voice broke him from his trance.

"Well? Dig in!"

As if a starting horn had blared, Morgan thrust himself toward the slab of meat and ripped a chunk off. Lacking utensils to fit his size, the hungry boy gnawed at the head-sized piece, meanwhile his sister took her silverware and cut off a clean segment for herself. Lucina watched silently as her little brother enthusiastically chowed down on his own tiny piece of the steak, savoring this little moment as well as the steak in her mouth. Finally, she swallowed and broke the silence between the two.

"So you're not mad about that little game, are you?" Lucina asked her brother, with the smallest amount of guilt in her voice. "Nah, not at all," Morgan said through a mouthful of meat, "Just don't make me do it again." Lucina laughed lightly. "Oh, it couldn't possibly have been THAT bad, could it?" Morgan frowned and pointed up at his sister's face. "You try running from two colossal giants! You should see yourself from this perspective, it's scary, sis!"

Lucina smiled coyly. "Afraid of your big sister, hm?" The princess reached out and grabbed her brother, much to his chagrin. Morgan in hand, she stood up from her seat and lowered the boy to the ground, setting him down between her feet. Morgan craned his neck upward as Lucina stood back up to full height, hands and her hips and meeting his gaze. "Are you scared, little guy?" Lucina spoke down to him teasingly. From so far away, her voice seemed to entirely surround Morgan, as if it was a goddess addressing him, and not his sister. Every instinct Morgan had was screaming at him to run in the direct opposite direction, but Lucina's massive presence was so oppressive, Morgan could bring himself to do nothing but stare in awe at her monumental figure.

Lucina's cold gaze on Morgan wavered, her smile turning from taunting to genuine. A light chuckle escaped her lips, which soon evolved into a full-stop laughing fit. Lucina held her stomach as her knees buckled, forcing her to take a seat. Morgan felt his heartbeat return to normal as the cold atmosphere melted around him. Between giggles, Lucina spoke to Morgan again. "Oh, I'm sorry, Morgan. You're just so cute all tiny and helpless like this." She wiped a tear from her eye, "I just had to tease you a little for it." Having calmed down, Lucina looked down once again at her brother, smiling sweetly. Morgan, however, was not laughing.

"Come on, Lucina. You think this is funny?" Morgan accused, angered at his sister's disregard for him. "Yes, actually." Lucina answered, still giggling softly at her tiny sibling's outburst. The girl leaned forward and hung her head directly over Morgan, watching him like a hawk.

“Y-You can’t do anything to me that would hurt me. Mom would kill you! And besides, I’ll only be small until we figure out a solution for my situation.”

“This is what I’m talking about Lucina! Who knows how long Morgan will stay tiny for? Even if he doesn’t get help from anyone today, he might start growing back to normal on his own anyway! We need to take advantage of the opportunity before it goes away!”

“Oh, so if it’s you messing with him it’s okay, but if it’s me it’s not allowed, is that it?”

Lucina attempted to refute Severa’s statement.
“N-No! That doesn’t have anything to do with it!”

Severa smirked, looking like a cat that had cornered a mouse.
“You have to let me put him on the spoon! It’s only fair. Otherwise your nothing but a hypocrite.”

Severa’s last point seemed to have struck home with Lucina.
“W-Well, I guess… Since I had my fun with him earlier, it’s only fair…”

Morgan was shocked, he couldn’t believe that Lucina would let Severa do this!
“Sis, no! Don’t let her put me on the spoon!”

Severa smirked, taking hold of Morgan and lifting him up so that he could stare into her face.
“Don’t be such a baby, shrimp! I’m not going to hurt you. And besides, it’s like Lucina said, this is only fair.”

With that, she proceeded over to the currently unoccupied cooking tent, Lucina trailing slightly behind, looking extremely regretful.

===============

Inside the tent, Severa went to work making a stew. It was just a simple thing, with potatoes, beef, and some vegetables, but it would soon have an additional ingredient…

As the stew warmed, Severa took a tasting spoon and scooped some of the broth out, and wasted no time in plopping Morgan onto the broth-laden spoon.
“Ack! It’s wet and sticky!” Morgan yelped.

“Duh, its soup. Of course it’s wet.”
Severa rolled her eyes and glanced at Lucina, who was viewing her and Morgan with an apprehensive look on her face.
“There, you’ve put him on the spoon! Now give him back!” Lucina stated, reaching out a hand towards the spoon.

Severa quickly snatched the spoon away, taking care not to throw Morgan off, and held it away from Lucina.
“Not so fast, princess. We have to taste the stew first! That’s the only way we’ll know if Morgan really does give my stew emotion!”

Morgan cried out in fear while Lucina gasped, looking horrified.
“Severa! I already told you that I wouldn’t let you eat my brother! You’re going to far!”

Severa did not relent.
“Sorry Lucina, but this is all part of the deal. If I remember correctly, you said that the game you played with Morgan earlier terrified him, so now you have to let me frighten him! Besides, I won’t hurt him, it’s not like I’m actually going to swallow him.”

Severa knew that the easiest way to beat Lucina in an argument was to attack her honor; she could see that she had beaten the future exalt.
“I-I… Alright, fine! But after this I’m making you help me find somebody who can help Morgan! After you taste him, we clean him up and then we’re done with this argument!”

Severa grinned, she was going to enjoy this!
“Great! But I’m feeling generous right now, and you seem really protective of Morgan, so I’ll let you decide who tastes the stew!”

Morgan couldn’t believe what he was hearing!
“Sis, please! You can’t be serious! You’re going to let her put me in one your mouth’s?”

Lucina just sighed dejectedly and looked down at Morgan.
“I’m sorry Morgan, Severa is right, this is only fair. I promise I’ll make this up to you later.”

With that, Lucina picked up the spoon that Morgan was crouching on, and looked between her and Severa.
“Alright, Severa, I think the one who tastes him will be…”

"Look, Lucina. Here's what we'll do. We can go find Miriel, she's probably the smartest mage in the camp. She's bound to have a solution, or at least be able to help us. She'll make things better." Severa tried to calm the shaken Lucina down.

"O-okay, we'll go to Miriel. We can't afford to waste any time, so we'd better find her as soon as possible."

"No worries there, Lucina. I know she'll still be in her tent at this time of day. We can head over there right now." With this said, Severa took her friend's hand and pulled her to the entrance of the tent.

---------------------

"Miriel! Miriel!"

Looking up from the tome she had been studying, Miriel saw Severa enter her tent, nearly dragging Lucina by the hand. Curiously, the blue haired girl had one hand laid almost protectively over her stomach.

"This is most unusual. Both of you are usually quite levelheaded. Clearly, something is ailing one of you. Lucina, is something the matter with your stomach?" Miriel inquired.

"I, uh... That is..." Both girls seemed to stumble over their words, before Severa spoke up.

"This is going to seem unusual, and very strange, but no matter what you absolutely can't tell anyone! I was playing a joke on Morgan and Lucina, and I might have been a bi--t to forceful and got carried away, and... long story short, Lucina ate Morgan." Severa rambled on before coming to a sharp halt.

Miriel raised her eyebrows and adjusted her glasses before responding.

“You ate him? Am I hearing you correctly, Sever?. Morgan, small as he is, is much too large to be consumed by a being of human stature. I have read a number of tomes that spoke of theories on consuming the spiritual essence of another, as well as absorbing magical properties—”

“No, no. That’s not what I meant. She accidentally swallowed him while he was shrunken. He’s—”

Miriel shot out of her seat and seized Severa by the shoulders. “You mean to tell me he was reduced in size?! Small enough to fit in his sister’s mouth?! Fascinating! I have never read any tomes that described the successful reduction of one’s physical mass. Why, this is a wonderful opportunity. Your brother’s state could tell me so much I…”

Miriel stopped as she noticed Lucina start to shake. The blue-haired girl had her arms wrapped around herself and seemed to be lost in despair.

“My apologies, Lucina. I lost myself for a moment and didn’t adequately consider your feelings. Clearly, as you have notified me of this event and no one else, I understand that you wish for me to lend you all the aid I can. As I said earlier, there is no existing work beyond mere theories on size-reduction, so my help will be limited to what I have gleaned from my studies.”

After constantly letting Severa speak for her, Lucina sighed and closed her eyes. After a moment, she opened them and began to speak.
“Thank you, Dame Miriel. I greatly appreciate your help and I… Huh?!” Lucina jerked as Miriel abruptly jerked up her tunic, gazing at Lucina’s pale, toned stomach in thought. Severa squeaked and watched the two with wide eyes.

“If I am to help the three of you, I must run some simple tests. I believe detect life should suffice here. Ah, there we go.” The mage exclaimed as she ran a now glowing hand over Lucina’s bare belly, making the girl shiver at the contact.

Lowering the girl's tunic, Miriel turned her attention back to the two young women in her tent.

“Well, this simple scan has told me several things. First of all, Morgan is alive and currently well. The heat and smell don’t seem to be a threat towards him, but there is a matter that we must address immediately.

“What is it?”

“What’s gonna happen?” Both Lucina and Severa spoke at the exact same time. Pausing, Severa gave Lucina a nod to speak.
“You said there was a problem? Please do whatever you need to do to fix it! Just keep my brother safe!” Lucina pleaded with the solemn mage.

The mage lowered Lucina’s tunic down, covering the girl’s stomach once more before straightening up and answering the worried sister.

“Of course, dear. That goes without saying. I merely meant that there would be a problem in the near future that we must resolve now to ensure that it does not hinder our efforts to safely retrieve little Morgan.” After saying this, she turned around and began to rummage through a chest full of books near her desk.

Severa spoke up, not wanting the scholarly mage to become distracted once more.

“Well, what is it? Is it something we can help with? Please don’t say that we have to go out and get help…” The twin-tailed girl groused, drawing Miriel’s attention once more.

“No, not at all. In fact I can take of the dilemma right now. I was simply making sure that I had an adequate tome of wind spells. It would be disastrous if the spell I used was underpowered, or Naga forbid, overpowered.”

Both Lucina and Severa realized where Miriel was going with her train of thought. Severa was once more the first to speak.

“Gods, you mean Morgan can’t breathe in there? Why can’t you just teleport him out or something?!”

Lucina looked horrified at the notion that her brother might asphyxiate inside of her, but answered Severa’s Miriel-directed question nonetheless.

“Mother explained it to me, as siblings there is a certain amount of overlap in our magical signatures, a rescue staff might not work on one of us if we were standing side by side. To work around the problem, it would have to be both of us together or neither at all,”

“Quite right, Lucina. You see girls, we must take the long way to solve this problem because I fear that attempting to teleport Morgan out using conventional means may be quite harmful to both of you. So instead, we are forced to simply configure Lucina’s stomach to allow him to survive until we have a better solution. I apologize, but on such short notice it is the only option to take. Severa, you should step back. Lucina, I have a few questions before I begin.”

Severa wisely stepped back, making more space for Lucina and Miriel, while the other girl answered the mage’s question.

“Hold on, configure my stomach? Wouldn’t that be harmful to me? I don’t want Morgan to be harmed, but if anything were to happen to me he may become un-retrievable,” the princess was already wary at the thought of foreign magic affecting her body, and not keen on allowing herself to end up as somebody's lab experiment.

“Not to worry princess. I merely intend to cast a spell that will effectively cast a safety net around your brother. This way, you won’t worry about starving, but Morgan won’t be at risk of digesting. My earlier test ensured me that your brother's innate magic resistance will keep your stomach acids from affecting him for the time being. Severa, would you assist me for a moment? I need you to expose Lucina’s stomach for me.”

Lucina and Severa blushed at the odd request, but nonetheless acquiesced to the mage’s demands. Severa moved directly behind Lucina and rolled the princess’s tunic up till it was just below her bra, exposing the entirety of her belly. Moving up to them, Miriel waved her arms over Lucina’s stomach, each hand glowing with power. Lucina started at this, nearly stepping back into Severa.

“My stomach… that was supposed to happen, right?”

Miriel nodded. “Not to worry, that was merely the safety net wrapping around your brother's signature. Food should be able to pass through like normal, but the passage of oxygen will be confined to what passes up and down your throat. The final measure I take is one that I would like your permission for. I have to, for lack of a better term, ‘puff’ your stomach up. Simply put, filling your stomach by constantly swallowing air would be too cumbersome and attention-grabbing to sustain. To this end I’ll use focused wind magic to create a reservoir of stored air inside your stomach that will constantly be in a state of replenishment and recycling. As I said, I require your permission for this step. The notion of altering another’s body without their explicit consent, even for good intentions, is something that I find quite repulsive.”

“Sooo, you’re going to be filling her stomach with air, remind me not to stand in front of her, she’s going to belching louder than Vaike,” sniped Severa, adjusting her arms and rolling her shoulders to bring feeling back into her arms. Lucina frowned and snapped back at Severa.

“Severa! That’s not funny! Please, Miriel, you have my full permission for whatever you need. Just keep Morgan safe!”

Miriel’s eyes softened and she nodded.

“Very well. Princess, I want you to know that I find your determination and worry over your younger brother to be quite moving. I am touched that you came to me for assistance.” Miriel said as she opened a green tome, flipping through the pages. Eventually, her hands came to a stop…

"You're ok with that, really? Me hooking up with your stalker's daughter? Won't that give her an excuse to get close to you?"

"My stalker? What are you talking about?"

"Tharja, mom. You know? The one wh-."

"Only kidding dear. Don't worry about Tharja. I'll manage her.. somehow."

Morgan did not overlook the slight shudder his mother.

"Sweetie? Mind if I see something?"

"Sure mother."

Robin suddenly picked Morgan up between her fingers again and lowered him to the floor of the tent.

"Mother, what are you doing?" He exclaimed quite alarmed.

"Sorry honey, I just want to see something."

Morgan then looked up as his mother towered over him at full height. His mouth opened in awe as he stared at the immense colossus. So familiar, and yet so alien from this perspective.

"My god. You are tiny. I can barely make you out down there. Even my boots dwarf you."

Morgan continued to stare up at his mother who herself looked down at him from full height.

He knew he shouldn't be afraid. This was his mother after all. But seeing her from this perspective. So far above him, looking down like a goddess from on high...

"Mother," he gulped, "wha- what are you doing?"

She smiled kindly down at him.

"Don't worry Morgan," she assured him, "I was just curious how it looked from this perspective. I've held you in my hand of course, but seeing you like this... it really drives home the problem here.

Morgan nodded in agreement, unable to tear his eyes away from his towering mother.

"You aren't afraid of me, are you Morgan?"

"What? No, of course not!"

She smiled. "I'm glad to hear it. I know these last few days must have shaken you up a lot. But you know you can always trust me. I'll protect you no matter how long it takes. Oh, and don't worry. I assure you I won't tell Noire about your secret. But like I said, when you get back to normal, you'd better man up and tell her the truth, ok?"

Morgan nodded.

"Well," said Robin as she leaned down, "I'd say it's dinner time. Shall I get some food and bring it back for you?"

"Yes, mother. I'd appreciate it."

She smiled and put her hand down for him to step on.

"It's ok mother. I can get up to your desk myself."

She raised her eyebrows at this unusual statement.

"No, really. It's fine! I'd like to try and maintain some independence. Even at this size."

She looked back to her desk the back down to him.

"Are you sure?"

Yes, I'll be fine. You'll see"

Robin smiled and rubbed her son's head.

"Well if you're sure, I believe you. I'll be back soon, hun."

With this, she stood back to her full height and stared down at her son for a little bit. She blew him a kiss, and then raised her massive leg up.

Morgan watched in awe as her pillars went over his head and landed on the other side with a trembling sound. She continued towards the exit, her footsteps causing the ground to quake.

Despite the reassuring talk he'd just had, Morgan found he was in fact unable to get back up to the top of the desk by himself. Despite his strength of will, the tiny boy found he just didn't have the strength to pull it off.

"Well so much for my independence," he thought. "I can't wait to see mom's smirk when she finds me still on the ground."

As if on cue, he began to hear the ground shake again with the footsteps of a giant (aka normal-sized person).

Who was it?

It seemed like the worst things possible happen the moment Morgan lets his guard down. He sat cross legged on the table top, shuddering every time his mother lifted another spoonful of Severa's stew. He took a deep breath, letting his off beat heart calm down to a steadier rhythm.

Of course his heart rate sky rocketed the second he spotted his giant crush walking into the tent. Panicking, Morgan dove behind the bowl of stew, hoping Noire would leave quickly.

"R-Robin," Noire called, her voice low in volume, half worried about the possibility of being heard.
"Oh, Noire. Is something wrong? Are you still upset over the whole mother situation?"
"N-no, well, a little... but--"

"Yes?"
"I was trying to think of ways I might grow a bit...sturdier. So lately I've been watching the other girls and trying to identify the differences."

Robin held back on revealing Morgan even though she knew where the conversation was heading. "And have you found any?"

"Well, the others are healthier, obviously, and their bodies seem more resilient. Also, their figures are a bit more...robust."

At this point, Robin knew it was too late to bring out Morgan, knowing that Noire would probably die of embarrassment.

"Er, and I suppose you would be on the... slight side?"
"Slight? Ha! I'm skin and bone! I fall over in a stiff breeze.They're all so full of energy; it's like staring into the sun... They make me feel like a troll... Er, if trolls were scrawny."

Robin looked over Noire's figure, finding nothing wrong with her other than blatant self esteem issues.

"Nonsense, Noire. You're not a troll. You're just perfect the way you are."
"INSOLENCE! HOW DARE YOU GIVE ME FALSE INFORMATION! NO MALE HAS EVER GAZED UPON ME AS THEY HAVE WITH OTHER WOMEN!"

"So is that what it's about? You 're feeling a little ignored by boys?"
"NO MERE MAN COULD EVER HANDLE-- Er... um yes, basically."
"Well, for starters I think I know someone who would definitely be interested."

Upon hearing his mother speak, Morgan broke out in a cold sweat.

"Who!?" Noire chirped, hoping for a straight answer.
"Unfortunately, I can't say, but I'll make sure he builds the courage to make the first move."
"Well, I trust your judgement if you think he's good for me."

"Of course he is. Though he's a little shy," Robin purposefully emphasized the word little, "I practically had to pry the fact that he had a little crush on you."
"Oh, thank you, Mo-- Erm, Robin," Noire corrected, lunging into the tactician for a hug tight enough to cause back pain. "I don't think I could thank you enough!"

Morgan could have sworn his heart dropped when Noire began bouncing away from the tent.

"Hmm," Robin hummed, "if all goes well, she won't have to correct herself anymore."

"MOOOM, please..." Morgan groaned, both embarrassed and horrified at the turn of events. "You promised!"
"And I kept it, sweetie. It's up to you to tell her you like her."
"But--but!"

"Listen, I know women, especially at your size, seem intimidating, but you shouldn't be afraid. Noire's a nice girl. Plus you're really helping out with her confidence issues. It says a lot that someone as fragile as you is placing complete trust in her."

"But, mother..."

"It's up to you, but you're not going to get a better chance than this."

1351121111122121111112222121121111111111.content:
As Noire carried him back to her tent, Morgan found himself deep in thought.

On one hand, he was glad to spend time with her by himself. On the other hand, hi smother was the only one who he felt truly safe around, and with her gone, he felt a lot more vulnerable. He knew there was Lucina, but he did not have the same confidence in her. Partly due to almost being eaten by her.

And then there was Noire herself. He had no way to defend himself if her other side manifested itself. He could only hope he was able to calm her down before she left any permanent damage.

Noire went into her tent and looked at her bunkmate's bed, noticing they were out for the moment. She sat down on her cot and tilted her hand letting Morgan roll out onto the mattress.

"Well, alone at last," she leaned on her stomach, her chin in her hands and stared at her lover.

"Right. Alone at last. Before, we do anything, we should set a few ground rules."

"Oooh, rules. And what if I don't follow those rules?" She leaned in close smirking. "Will you punish me little man?"

This confidence from Noire was not something Morgan was used to. He never would have seen it at his normal height. Honestly, he wasn't sure how to deal with it. It made him feel more uncomfortable.

"Ok, not rules. More like requests."

At this, Noire's smirk faded and she nodded in understanding.

"Most of the camp knows by now about my condition. But I'd like to keep interaction to a minimum."

"A recluse huh? Just like Lucina."

"My sister is not a recluse! She just has a lousy sense of humor. I don't want to shut myself out. But I find when I'm around lots of people, my chance for misfortune increases." He thought back to Lissa, Miriel and Severa, shuddering at what they put him through.

"Well that's fine," Noire smiled lifting Morgan up by the back of his coat. "More time I have you to myself then." She held him in front of her face and stared at him for a while. Then suddenly she opened her mouth and threw him in.

"Noire, what the hell!?" She giggled at his panic and to add insult to injury started to swish him around.

For Morgan, it was far less pleasant however. He couldn't tell which way was up or down and he was getting soaked in her saliva.

Fortunately, for him she soon tired and spat him out into her hand. She pulled a cloth from her bedside table and wiped him down with it.

"Have fun?"

Morgan glared at her.

"Ok another ru- er request. I know you probably didn't mean anything by that, but could you please not do it again.?"

Noire frowned. "What, you're telling me you didn't enjoy that at all?"

Morgan's glare turned to one of confusion. "No I did not! How could you think that?"

Noire shrugged. "I just thought it might bring us closer together."

"Not that close! Please Noire. Don't"

She paused for a moment, then smiled. "I'm not sure I can promise that. After all, I am the one in charge and if you're ever naughty boy, well." She winked.

"Besides, I don't truly believe that some part of you didn't enjoy that."

Morgan opened his mouth to retort, but stopped. He knew he wasn't going to change her mind on this.

"Fine, but just give me a heads up next time, ok?"

"Ah, but that's the fun! You never expect it!"

Seeing that he had no further response, Noire leaned forward and kissed him on the head. She then leaned on her back and placed him on her chest. She moved the covers up to cover him.

"Just so my roommate doesn't see you immediately and try to steal you from me! Then I'd have to punish her, and really eat you!" She said it in a joking manner, but there was steel in her eyes that said otherwise.

As she leaned back, Morgan suddenly thought of another even more serious problem.

"Noire?"

"Mm?"

"Could I ask one more request?" He paused. "Don't show me to your mother."

At this, she went quiet for a time. "I doubt I can keep you totally hidden. She probably knows I have you. But I can at least keep interaction to a minimum."

He would have preferred no interaction, but he knew there was little Noire could do when it came to her mother.

"Well, I'd say that's enough for one day. Thank you for making me the happiest girl in the world, little one."

Morgan lay awake for a while, watching his girlfriend, his goddess, sleep, still amazed he'd managed to win her over. Even so, he still was uncertain about their future together between his height, and her increasing dominance, it would be a challenge.

Finally he closed his eyes, lulled to sleep by the rhythm of the giant's rising and falling chest.

"So this is your hobby? Dissecting bugs?"

"What? No, wait..."

Morgan's eyelids raised a tad. He looked up from where he was lying down to see a flat plain of stomach. Tilting his head up slowly, he saw a familiar face with a headful of dark and bluish hair. He then lost his hold and fell into unconsciousness.
