135321121122.content:
Severa smiled slyly when she finally reached a conclusion. If Chrom wouldn't let her back on the front lines then she would have no choice but to put her new size to good use and show him just how wrong he was. Slowly she rose from her "seat" as she was again gawked at by her fellow soldiers. They still couldn't get over the initial shock of how big Severa had gotten. She ignored them and they cleared a path as she headed off into the woods.

Someone would report her no doubt but she didn't care, once she came back victorious, Chrom would be begging her to be front and center for the next battle. Just the thought of the blue-haired leader begging her for anything brought a genuine smile to her face. All she had to now was find a group of brigands to squash. That shouldn't be too hard, right?

-----

"Alright! Hand over everything ya gots." A brigand spat.

"P-please don't hurt us." A woman cried.

"We don't have anything." Another man added.

This only served to piss the brigand leader off. He backhanded the man to the floor, much to the shock and horror of the woman. "Don't you lot know who I am" I'm the all mighty Groh and I said hand over everything ya got!"

The woman was crying now as she tended to her companion. "Please! We really don't have anything!"

"Lier!" Groh roared as he kicked the woman down. "No one makes a fool outta me. Got nothing my ass! You got a ring don't ya? Ya got earrings, don't ya? Hand em' over!"

"Have mercy." The man begged.

"Mercy?" Groh laughed. "This isn't a fairytale boy, this is the real world. Mercy a joke." he then moved in closer, pressing waving his knife dangerously. "Now hand over everything."

Before the couple could comply, a dark shadow fell over the area. The pair's eyes widened as the brigand leader remain ignorant.

"Oi! Who turned off the sun!?"

Groh slowly turned his head... Then he wished he hadn't. While he was frozen in a state of shock the odd couple took this time to run away. The brigand leader still couldn't believe what he was seeing. A woman, a giant woman. A titan! He thought they were just a story to scare little kids.

Groh gulped nervously. This wasn't good.

-----

Severa stared down at the insignificant man with a scowl on her face and her hands on her hips. She'd been wandering around the forest for ages until she stumbled upon this sight. Needless to say she wasn't happy. Severa hated bandits, especially the ones that got off on harming the innocent. This guy was lower than dirt in her eyes.

No one would care if he suddenly disappeared under her foot.

"So..." Severa addressed the "bug" at her feet. "What are you going to do now?"
135321121122.title: Severa's Plan

Robin trusts Chrom's decision and reprimands Severa
1353211211223.content:
Robin sighed as she continued her trek through the forest. Apparently Severa had decided to go wandering off while she and Chrom discussed the possible merits of Ricken's growth formula. Needles to say, the grandmaster of Ylisse was anything but pleased. This is exactly what she was worried would happen, Severa going off and doing whatever with her new size. Hopefully she didn't wind up in any trouble.

For now all Robin could do was fallow the footprints the angry giant left behind. They were honestly big enough and deep enough to put a hot spring in. They also helped to put the larger woman's scale into perspective. At her size she could probably take out whole squads of enemy units in one go. Robin wouldn't envy anyone unfortunate enough to wind up under her heel.

While the master tactician continued to think over Severa's new set of skills, a small tremor seemed to rock the ground. It caused her to stumble a bit but she still remained standing. "What on earth was that? Could it have been Severa?" the snow haired woman wondered. There was only one sure way to find out. Scanning the area intently, Robin spied what appeared to be smoke rising in the distance. Robin eyed the trail she was fallowing and it led right to that area. Severa no doubt.

Not wanting to waste anymore time, Robin broke out in a sprint. The tremors began to grow more frequent and powerful. It sounded as if a battle was taking place, and those were definitely the cries of screams and rage. The rage coming from a very familiar source. The now fifty foot Severa who appeared to be dominating a large force of bandits.

Robin took cover behind a shrub and watched in both awe and slight terror as Severa literally stomped a group of brigands flat. This wasn't even really a battle as far as Robin could tell... this was a massacre. Did these fools have no sense of self preservation? Clearly not as they continued to charge at their much larger opponent. Severa either stomped them or flicked them away with her fingers. This was insane.

Robin's eyes analyzed everything she saw. The battle applications of having a fifty foot titan where just too much to ignore. The tactician could already picture a number of scenarios in her mind. All the ways she could unleash Severa on flying units, ground forces, and even large battleships. So caught up in her thoughts was she, she almost failed to notice the screams had stopped. The battle was over. Severa was victorious.

Robin couldn't believe it. It was one thing to talk about a giant in action, it was another thing to witness it. That large group of idiots never stood a chance. Granted they were most likely weak, but still there was strength in numbers. Numbers that mattered very little in the face or at the feet of a giant. Robin bit her bottom lip. She was torn. After a display like that could she really leave Severa on the sidelines? Maybe she could override Chrom and revoke her suspension?

Whilst Robin wrestled with her thought's, Severa was more occupied whipping her feet against the ground. Defeating those bandits may have been easy, but it sure was messy. More messy then running a sword through one of them. "This is seriously gross." she muttered. It was then that she sat down for a minute to collect herself. She'd done what she set out to do and crushed an enemy group by all by her lonesome... literally. All she needed to do now was find proof of her victory.

She was about to start looking until she felt something poking her foot. Looking down she instantly recognized the dark cloak of the Shephard's chief tactician. Instantly she felt her mood sour, had Robin come to reprimand her?

"Hey." Severa greeted plainly.

Robin fixed her with an unreadable expression. "We need to talk."
1353211211223.title: Tactical Applications

13532112112231.content:
Severa couldn't help but sigh, the moment she saw Robin she knew something like this would happen. She would reprimand her and send her back to camp where her parents and Prince Chrom were no doubt waiting to give her an ear full.

"Let me guess, I'm in trouble for sneaking off, right?"

Robin noticed the tone of her voice and noted how annoyed she sounded. Then again, from what little interactions the two shared she knew Severa always sounded like this. She was probably expecting to be reprimanded, granted she would be later on, but for now that could wait.

"I noticed you were missing after my meeting with Chrom and came looking for you. I half expected to find you all by your lonesome, but to my surprise I instead find you engaged in battle against a group of brigands."

Severa eyes widened a fraction. Robin had seen her battle? If that was the case then just maybe... "S-so what did you think?"

Robin gave the giant a small smile. "I can't deny that I was indeed impressed."

Severa's head nearly spun. Not only had Robin not reprimanded her so far, but she'd seen her battle and was... impressed. Gods, she'd impressed the Grandmaster of Ylisse! "Then does that mean...?"

"I can't speak for Chrom, but I will push to have your suspension revoked." Robin answered. With that display of power, Severa would be more of use on the front lines then hanging back around camp.

"Are you serious!?" Severa asked with hope in her voice. Was this really happening? Had her plan really worked? If Robin could get her suspension revoked then this war was as good as theirs. "Ha, take that Prince! I told him I could be out winning wars!"

Robin rolled her eyes at the disrespect. "Don't go getting too excited now. I still need to talk to him first."

"That's more than enough for me!" Severa grinned at her small victory.

Robin pinched the bridge of her nose. "Anyway. From what I saw of your battle you completely dominated those bandits. They were a large uncoordinated force and yet you rendered their numbers moot."

Now it was Severa's turn to roll her eyes. "No duh. I'm like fifty feet tall and their not. They couldn't even wound me, let alone knock me down."

Robin listen closely to her words and for a brief moment thanked the gods above that Severa was on their side. She might need to look into a contingency plan later though, just in case. "Interesting. You seemed to be able to take on other humans with very little effort. So how well would you fair against risen?"

That gave the giant pause as she thought over the question. Humans were smart and easy. Risen were essentially dumb undead, except for the generals. "Hn. Risen would be no problem for me."

"Really now?"

"Really." Severa assured.

Robin thought it over. Maybe they should test this theory?

"I guess that will have to do. Come, let's head back to camp so I can talk to Chrom." The Grandmaster ordered, although she really did want to see how Severa would fare against the armies of the undead now.

Perhaps they would run into some when the Shepherds got moving again. Trouble always did seem to find them.

"Yeah, yeah." Severa grinned before slowly rising to her fell height. Despite already having stood close to the girl, this would still take some serious getting used to.

"Note to self, speak to Ricken as soon as possible." Robin whispered to herself. Despite being an ally and the power display earlier, Severa still had her issues and a temper to boot. It would be in the tactician's best interest to get some of that growth formula soon,

Noting that Robin wasn't moving and just staring at her, Severa decided to comment. "What?"

"Nothing." Robin answered. "I'm still just getting used to the new you is all."

Severa nodded. That was understandable, though it still annoyed her a bit. But then again that feeling wasn't anything new. "You want a lift?"

"Pardon?"

"You said you were still trying to get used to the new me, so how about a lift back to camp. It'll be a lot quicker if I do the walking." Severa explained.

Robin placed a hand to her chin in thought. The very idea of Severa carrying her anywhere made her feel uneasy, and yet at the same time she found herself curious. What would riding on a titan back to camp be like? Would it be pleasant or would it be hell? She wasn't really sure.

This needed to be tested. Despite herself, Robin would answering, "Alright. I accept your request."

Severa smiled, "Good." Things were going great. She hadn't been reprimanded, Robin was going to talk to Chrom about getting her back on the front lines, and she was about to impress the army's tactician personally with her new stature.

Why didn't things swing this way for her all the time?

She crouched down to the normal sized woman and extended her palm to the ground. "Hop on."

Robin was slightly hesitant but complied all the same. Needless to say it was beyond bizarre to stand in the palm of another human being. Severa slowly rose to her feet as to not jostle her precious cargo. Just like with Robin this was quite the bizarre experience. Ricken didn't count because she was blinded by fury.

After readjusting herself a bit to the new atmosphere, Robin noticed she could see over the trees and saw the forest extend for what seemed like miles. She could even see camp off in the distance. "Wow." she breathed in awe.

The giantess giggled. "I know right. So lets find a secure place for you to ride."

1353311.content:
Miriel flipped through the pages of the tome, looking through its contents to see exactly what it was capable of. The pages were a worn yellow with ink that had browned over the years, Miriel took note of its age as she turned each page, making a mental memo to publish a revised edition the next time her hands were free. The words were as common magic speak as regular tomes such as Elfire or Arcthunder boasted, but the symbols in the book appeared to be different, the usual triangular and circular shapes inside the text containing what appeared to be drawings of a person diminishing in size as the circles were viewed clockwise.

"Fascinating..." Miriel mused while rubbing her chin, "This appears to be some sort of shrinking tome judging by the symbols and title. What exactly could its purpose be, I wonder?" Miriel looked at the cover again and rubbed her finger across the book's leather - White, a color normally unseen in the army's usual library of tomes. "Size manipulation would fall more in line with a hex from the dark arts, and yet, this book is not bound by any tint nor shade of purple. How intriguing..." As she focused on the book, a small black speck entered Miriel's vision, a spider, hanging from a thread on her hat. With quick thought, she gently removed the arachnid from its thread with her finger and placed it upon her desk; she got up and begun to wield the tome, fixing her glasses to focus on the insect and aiming her palm at it. Reading the ancient texts, Miriel shot an orb of bright white from thin air at the spider; the light was absorbed into the insect and it quickly begun to dwindle in size, completely disappearing from sight on the candlelit oak and further piquing Miriel's interests.

"How curious." She grabbed a magnifying glass from her nearby nightstand and sat again at her desk, aiming her sight at where the spider once stood. It took a bit of effort, but she had found the insect, a now-smaller black speck upon the desk, no bigger than a speck of dust as it tried to panic and run, but only managing a small speed. Miriel had immediately jotted down the effects of the tome within a journal at her side, before her focus was bought to the journal itself rather than the contents. Preparing the spell again, Miriel cast it upon the journal, expecting an effect, but instead of absorbing itself into the journal, the light dispersed into particles and disappeared. Jotting down another piece of info in the unaffected journal, Miriel sat down the tome on her desk and sat rigid in her chair, tapping a foot upon the ground and massaging her chin.

"It doesn't work on inanimate objects, but rather on living creatures." she thought aloud, churning thoughts about the tome around her head. "I would assume its application would be that of capture, to take a singular creature for transport, or perhaps it was made for a purpose of assassination? Perhaps for hiding or escape?" Miriel shook her head. "No, no, that would be illogical to assume if the caster cannot change themselves back, they would not even be able to wield this tome at a diminutive size. Furthermore, it is unknown if the subject can even grow again; I will have to test the theory on that spider." Miriel lifted the tome and reached for her magnifying glass again, intending to find the spider; it was only after a minute she had found a speck of blue upon her desk, remnants of hemocyanin from the crushed insect.

"How disappointing." Miriel spoke over the spider's demise, "I'll have to find another subject, one of the Shepherds should do since we have the benefit of human communication skills. Perhaps I should start with a male, or would a female be more willing?" Miriel's eyes found themselves affixed to a mirror as she tried to leave her tent, and she soon found herself examining her frame in the mirror as she adjusted her glasses. "Or rather, perhaps I should shrink myself and examine the tome's effects from that perspective? That way, I could better ascertain the thoughts of whomever wrote this tome themselves; after all, the thought of self-experimentation must have crossed their mind at one point or another..." Miriel sat back down again and closed her eyes, tapping the tip of her chin as she thought what her next option should be.

135331112.content:
Ricken sat in his tent, taking a moment of rest from his work to read a book Sumia had lended him. It was a long day of potion-brewing he had partaken in, not wanting to let down the Shepherds when Robin had tasked him with chemistry work as part of a camp-wide movement in magical studies for the Shepherd benefit. Just as he was nearing the end of his chapter, he had looked up to see the familiar figure of a red-haired mage staring down at him, startling the boy and sending him tumbling out of his cot. The young mage massaged his slightly aching forehead and stood up, turning around to address his familiar.

"Owww, what a shock..." complained Ricken, still trying to shake off his small fall. "Sorry Miriel, you just startled me a bit is all. What brings you here?" The red-haired mage fixed her glasses in response, gathering her thoughts as to explain her plan to young Ricken.

"Ricken," she began, "There is another experiment I require your assistance in. I was wondering if you would wish to participate."

"Another 'natural truths'-type thing? Well sure, what do you need? A second hand for tome-work?" Miriel simply shook her head in response.

"Nothing like that, this experiment would be considered more of the 'combat application' you previously inquired about. At least, I suppose that was the intent of this tome." From her robes, Miriel produced the white-bound book and showcased its cover to Ricken. "This tome, titled 'World Enlarger', is used in application to shrink an animate creature. I have no idea who created it, nor when it was created, yet I can't help but feel it will further enhance our combat abilities as an army if used properly against our enemies." Ricken had a slight twinkle in his eyes, entranced by Miriel's description of the tome.

"A size-changing tome? That does sound like it'd be cool on the field! Just imagine if we could write an entire library of those things!" Quickly though, Ricken's enthusiasm had changed to worry as he begun to register the implications of Miriel's visit. "Wait...If you need my assistance, then does that mean..."

"Yes, I wish to test this tome out on you." Ricken threw his arms up and waved them around, making a wildly expressive attempt to deny Miriel's request.

"Nu-uh! Absolutely not!" the boy protested, ruffling his robes the more he moved around. "Miriel, I spent my whole life trying to make myself a little taller so I could fight, why would I want to do the opposite of that?! Can't you try it out on someone else?"

"I have considered that possibility," Miriel replied, "However, I feel none could match the enthusiasm towards both magic and science that you have exhibited with me in our continued experiments, and you would be far more cool and collected in this experiment than any of the other Shepherds." Ricken felt Miriel's words buttering his ego, and he stroked his chin with a blush upon cheeks.

"I'm cool, huh? Well, I suppose I am pretty enthusiastic when it comes to magic..."

"I assumed you would be completely willing to cooperate with me on this experiment. I suppose I'll just ask Robin instead." As Miriel attempted to make her leave, Ricken stopped her, fully entranced by her words.

"Wait Miriel! I guess I overreacted a bit back there, I'd be happy to help you out with your experiment if you'd let me." Miriel fixed her glasses in self-satisfaction, stroking Ricken's ego had seemed to work in her favor as she had assumed. She turned around and faced the young mage.

"Fantastic. We will proceed with the experiment in here, and I shall transport you back to my tent for further planning and experimentation." Miriel produced the tome and prepared to work its magic on Ricken, but the young mage shuddered a small bit in response, not exactly looking forward to the tome's magic.

"Uh, Miriel?" he inquired, "This isn't going to hurt, is it?"

"I assure you it is most salubrious, the spider I had tested this on showed no signs of visible harm, just a small panic when observed." Miriel opened the leather-bound book and begun to cast its magic on Ricken, the white orb of light producing in her palm as she used the bound paper to fix her glasses. "Of course, I do not know if there's a remedy to the shrinking spell in this tome."

"Wait what-" Ricken had no time to finish his thought as the ball of light shot him square in the face, absorbing into his body. Miriel watched as Ricken quickly disappeared into his clothes, leaving a heap of cloth where he once stood. Miriel got to her knees to look for the small boy, and watched as a lump shifted around in the blue robes on the floor of the tent; Ricken removed himself from the heap of cloth and looked up at the giant face of Miriel looking down at him, her signature glasses adjustment responding to the recent turn of events. "Wow Miriel, you're so big! I guess that tome really does work!"

"Indeed," the mage replied, "Your frame appears to have completely shrunk in the same proportions as your usual size. Your physique appears not to have dwindled either."

"My physique?" Ricken looked down for a moment trying to understand what Miriel meant, seeing his decently-built arms, his slim torso, and his- "HOLY SMOKES!" Ricken gripped a piece of cloth and wrapped it around himself like a blanket to cover his nudity, his face completely red as he attempted to hide himself from Miriel. "M-Miriel! You didn't tell me this wouldn't work on clothes! I can't be seen like this!"

"I assumed you would've known based upon my explanation of how this only works on animate objects. However, there is no need to worry." Miriel produced a small set of clothes from her robes, hanging from a small wooden hangar. "Libra was more than happy to provide me with a set of doll clothes he sewed for the orphanage children's toys. I did not explain to him this experiment for I felt no need, but I'm pleased to note his kindness comes without reason needed." Ricken wanted to be thankful, but he couldn't help but bob his head in confusion.

"Uh, Miriel?" he asked.

"Yes Ricken?"

"You...You do realize those are clothes meant for a girl's doll, right?"

"Yes. It was all Libra could provide me with. Why? Is there a problem with these?"

"Of course there's a problem, you realize I'm a...You know what, forget it, just give me the dress." Miriel passed Ricken the pink and white frilly noblewoman dress and stood up, turning around.

"I will allow you a moment of privacy to dress yourself, and then we'll proceed to my tent." Miriel begun looking at Ricken's bookshelf, admiring his collection of tomes, while the small boy sighed and begun to put on the dress, distressed at the situation he found himself in.

Cynthia was up early in the morning, practicing both her lance skills and her heroic poses. The nations were at peace, with every present threat been defeated and Grima laid to rest, yet there would always be a need for soldiers, possibly even heroes, like the one she aspired to be.

She had gone outside so that she could be alone, as others were prone to judge her. Cynthia twirled her lance through the air and thrusted.

“HI-YA!” She pushed her lance forward and struck a pose. “Evil doers, face the wrath of my lance!”

Cynthia paused to consider her words. Was that too cheesy? Others thought her words actions strange, but she tried to shrug it off.

Cynthia sighed, suddenly feeling fatigue from her training session. Even heroes needed to take breaks. Cynthia sat down and tried to relax.

Wait.. was there something glistening over there? She approached it and picked it up. It appeared to be a kind of stone, glowing with a strange light. It was like nothing she had seen before but looked quite pretty.

Cynthia looked around. There didn’t seem to be any sign of a possible owner, someone must have dropped it here, if she could find whoever it could be. She bent down and picked it up and as she did, she felt a strange prickly sensation that quickly passed.

What happened? Cynthia tried to shake it off. Why did her clothes and armor suddenly feel tighter?

I can't have put on weight! I've been eating so healthily!

She checked her stomach, it looked the same as she always remembered it.

Ohh maybe I developed some arms. Eat your heart out Kjelle!

She checked her arms, but those to seemed the same as she remembered them.

What's up with that? Cynthia thought to herself, before shaking the thoughts away.
1353321.title: I'm not the best at beginnings

choices: Cynthia falls over and begins growing right then and there
Cynthia stops growing for the moment and reaches Sumia
13533211.content:
Feeling the need for some food, water, and general R&R, Cynthia retreated into the barracks, looking for a seat she could freely eat some bear jerky on. As she walked, she spoke softly, touching her fingers to her chin and putting very little attention into where she was going. "Now," she thought aloud, "How should I make my entrance into battle? Flower petals? Nope, too redundant. Smoke bombs? Nah, that's the same as the last one; come on Cynthia, think!" She walked and continued to mull the simple-minded thought, before snapping her fingers and shouting with jubilance. "I got it! I'll set the enemy in front of a mirror, and then I'll just walk through it, and while they're all freaked out, POOF! It was really the great hero Cynthia! ...Wait, no, I'll need to learn magic to do that. Ugh, back to the drawing board..." She continued spouting her rather loud thoughts, paying no attention to where she was going, until...

*SMACK!*

"Ow, ow, owww!" Down to the floor both Cynthia and whatever she crashed into went. The girl clutched her forehead in pain, gritting her teeth and closing her eyes in reaction. "That really smarts!"

"Hey, Cynthia? Are you alright?" The girl opened her eyes slowly and saw the image of a green-armored hand reaching out to her; she recognized it immediately, but let her eyes travel up the arm to confirm her suspicions; it was Stahl, her fellow Shepherd, clutching his forehead as Cynthia did.

"Oh my gosh!" Cynthia cried, gripping Stahl's hand and working herself up in turn. "Stahl, I'm soooo sorry! I didn't watch where I was going and-" The green-clad cavalier laughed softly and waved his hand in front of her.

"It's fine, I'm just glad none of us broke anything in all of this gear!" Both parties stopped clutching their foreheads and shifted into a more casual conversation. "From the sound of things, you were thinking up more heroic entrances, right?"

"Mm-hmm!" Nodded Cynthia. "I really want to do something to strike fear into the hearts of our enemies and joy into the hearts of innocents worldwide, something with a 'BAM, POW, WOO!'-feel to it, but that's no excuse to not pay attention to where I'm going..."

"Cynthia, I told you it's fine." Stahl took a slight glance at Cynthia and noticed the wet stains on her attire. "From all that sweat, I suppose you must've been doing a lot of combat training, am I right?"

"Yup! Gotta keep my lance-hand strong, you know? You never know when an enemy will strike!"

"Not anytime soon I hope," Stahl replied, "Thankfully we're in a perfect moment of peacetime here, so the need for us Shepherds is in lack for now. Your mother definitely makes a great Queen Cynthia, but I would've thought you'd rather try being more of a princess now since you never got to in the future." Cynthia shook her head.

"Nah, I feel much happier being a heroic knight and knowing my skills could rescue somebody in peril rather than just doing those boring war council meetings and wine-tasting parties and those really boring operas, you know? Better off leaving the princess stuff to Baby Cynthia and Baby Lucina, I'm gonna make sure they get to grow up in a peaceful world to enjoy all that crazy royal stuff!"

"Well, you have the drive for a hero, that part is down perfect! If you ever need any help in your training, just call on me and I'll take as many lance strikes as you need me too!" Cynthia bobbed her head in joy. Stahl looked at Cynthia one final time and noticed something odd about her.

"Hey, Cynthia?" He begun, "You're looking a little strange today, are you feeling alright?"

"Right as rain, why?"

"It might be my imagination, but I always thought you were shorter than me, and right now, it looks like we're about the same height." Cynthia moved closer to Stahl and moved her hand to the top of her head, slowly moving it towards Stahl's to compare heights; she was beat by about an inch.

"Nope, still looks like you're taller than me, I dunno what you're talking about. I probably might have gained an inch or two when we fought Grima back then." Stahl's face reddened a little as he continued to inspect Cynthia, noticing her clothes.

"And, uh, *ahem*, your, uh, clothes are a little, um..." Cynthia looked down and noticed a huge tear in her combat dress, exposing her stomach. Face reddening, she moved her arms down to cover her navel and buckled her knees a bit to prevent any further damage to her attire.

"Oh Pegasus poo!" she shouted, "I just got Mother to fix this the other day! She's not gonna be happy about this!" Cynthia turned around, intending to retreat into Castle Ylisstol and go see Sumia. "I gotta go Stahl, I'm so sorry about the headbutt, bye!" As Cynthia ran, Stahl noticed slight tears forming in Cynthia's skirt, slightly exposing her underwear and causing the green-clad knight to cover his face in embarrassment. Cynthia ran and ran, reaching the courtyard & front door, before feeling a small tingling sensation once again. "There's that weird feeling again," she thought, "Is this just a bad day for me, or some sort of enemy attack?"

Cynthia tugged at her skirt, trying to figure out just what was going on.

The enemy must be after my clothes!

She quickly looked around then dashed away, holding onto her clothes to avoid another wardrobe malfunction. She couldn't see any enemies around, and mercifully no allies who would see her in this predicament.

Wait, why would any enemy be after my clothes? Despite the situation, she took a moment to think about it and gasped. They must be trying to attack my moral! Or the Justice Cabal's!

She felt that prickiling sensation again, reminding her that she had no time to waste. She sped towards the throne room, tightening her grip on her tearing cloth, and crouching slightly to avoid giving anymore views.

Cytnhia's cheeks flushed.

1353321122.content:
A few hours had passed into the night time and Cynthia hadn't noticed any more growth spurts since, luckily for her. Unluckily, however, was the situation about her clothes; her combat attire was torn and damaged, any of her other wardrobe wasn't going to fit, and her sister Lucina, only being roughly the size of Sumia, didn't exactly have any clothes to match her stature - Cynthia wished she were a Feroxian, there must've been something in Kahn Flavia's wardrobe that could've suited her. Cynthia stood in front of the wooden frame of her door, pigtails untied, wearing Lucina's tightly-hugging pajamas that looked far too small for her, brandishing a small letter opener; slowly, she stood with her back to the door and etched into the frame with the letter opener just above her head, a habit she's been doing every week since she permanently moved into the castle after the war. She put the small knife to the side and picked up a ruler, sticking it to the mark she applied last week and slowly following the tickers; to her surprise, she had to shift up the wooden tool once just to reach the other etching.

"Holy crap!" she cried. Sumia, just outside the door at that moment, literally tumbled in and hit the floor, the clothes she carried spilling all over the place.

"What is it Cynthia?!" Sumia cried, a little too panicked. Cynthia helped her mother off the floor and helped to pick up the pile of clothes she dropped, which she noted was her combat dress by the color and the newly-added stitchings.

"Sorry Mother!" Cynthia replied, feeling bad about startling her. "But look-" Cynthia pointed at the door frame. "That etching last week read 5'6", and that new one reads 6'11"! The ruler doesn't lie!" Sumia looked at the etchings with a small murmur of worry in her heart, afraid of what would happen if her daughter kept on growing.

"That is worrying..." Sumia mused with a frown on her face.

"Well, I mean, I don't think it's worrying," Cynthia responded while rubbing the back of her head, "It's just a little unexpected, you know? Like BAM! When you get hit by a carriage after helping an old lady cross the street."

"Cynthia, I don't think this is a laughing matter." Sumia replied, "I've never seen anything like this before, and I have a feeling that rock had something to do with it. Why, if your Father were home right now..."

"Come on Mother, cheer up! I just got a little taller is all!" Cynthia sat down on her bed, and both her and Sumia were startled by the slight creaking noise the bed made upon her seating. "Oookaaay, maybe that is a little worrying...But still, I haven't felt any different in the past 4 hours or so, maybe this whole thing is done."

"Still Cynthia, rocks don't just make people change like this." Sumia put a finger to her lips in thought. "Well, except maybe Panne and Nowi, but they aren't 100% human...Either way, I feel a right to worry as your mother."

"Gosh, if I had a bullion for every time I heard that one..." Cynthia thought it over for a bit before spouting out her words. "I mean, I did have this thought that this could all be a very calculated enemy attack, but I don't get the point in trying to make me bigger...Oooh, unless they're trying to turn me into a monster! Yeah! I'd be all 'Rawr! Grrr! Crush the buildings! Eat the townsfolk! Shoot fire breath!' That'd be neato!" Sumia didn't like the twinkle going on in Cynthia's eyes, she always seemed so fired up over the most childish of fantasies!

"Cynthia, please!" Sumia pleaded, trying to get her daughter back to reality.

"Oh, whoops! Sorry about that, got a little carried away there!" Cynthia cleared her throat a bit and shifted the tone of her words. "I'm sure that whatever's happened to me is nothing like that. Probably. And anyways, Father and Lucina are away on that trip to Valm, right? The way I see it, we got about a week to figure this out, it's nothing that some good ol' knights of the sky can't handle!" Sumia let out a sigh and broke into a small smile.

"I suppose your right sweetie, but just promise you'll come find me the moment something happens, okay? It's not like we can exactly keep this a secret with all the guards running about, so be sure to talk to them and send them to fetch me, alright?"

"Roger!"

"Good." Sumia patted her daughter's head and moved to the door, placing her hand on the stack of clothes on the dresser. "Anyways, your clothes are right here, I managed to sew up the big tears, but don't try to put them on again, okay? I don't want to have to sew an entire dress back together piece-by-piece."

"Sure thing Mother, thanks again." Sumia prepared to exit the room and blew a kiss towards Cynthia's direction.

"Goodnight Cynthia, sweet dreams!" The door gently shut and Cynthia could hear a crash from outside her room. Upon further inspection, a piece of Sumia's dress was caught in the door; Cynthia watched her mother open the door again and pull the piece of cloth from the door frame before shutting the door once more. With that out of the way, Cynthia slowly laid down on the bed, trying not to break it in two as it creaked and shifted.

"Alright Cynthia," she thought, "This is a whole new chapter in your hero epic, you just gotta outsmart the situation at hand and aim for the happy ending! In fact, this could be the heroic power up happy ending!" Cynthia felt a hard binding pain in her chest and quickly identified it as the pajamas she wore, the top only buttoned once as that was as much as she could manage. She tugged hard to try and get her pajamas comfy and felt the single button snap away from the cloth as she made repeated, jerky tugs; the button recoiled off the ceiling and hit Cynthia square in the forehead, she clutched it in pain. "Okay, definitely not a happy ending! I'm gonna need some serious coin for a tailor at this rate!" Feeling the urge for sleep, Cynthia closed her eyes and let her mind adrift, taking the sheets of the bed and throwing it over herself quite sloppily. "Welp, you can worry about it in the morning Cynthia, but for now, there's a village of unicorns that needs to be defended from some evil nightmare knights; nighty-night..." In just a few seconds, Cynthia completely fell asleep and begun to loudly snore her cares away all throughout the night; as she slept, small tears began to form in her pajamas, and her frame shifted atop the bed slowly.

13533211221.content:
Cynthia was awoken by a loud crack and she suddenly dropped down to the ground with a thud. Her bed had collapsed and her legs and body stretched far beyond it.

Cynthia took a moment to take this all in. Her pyjamas were torn to shreds thought the bedsheets would just about cover her vulnerable areas but she still didn't want anyone to see her this way.

Just how big am I going to get? As big as the castle? As a big as a dragon? Cynthia suddenly had the mental image of her slamming down a dragon with some awesome wrestling technique. The thought made her smile and she found herself bobbing up and down.

"Yeah!" She pumped a fist into the air. "Super giant dragon slammer Cynthia!" She let the sound hang in the air. "Hmm... I should probably work on that name...."

The haze of fantasy passed for a second. Cynthia wondered what she could wear. A hero could hardly go around butt naked after all. But if these spurts kept happening she could hardly ask her to keep redoing her clothes every few hours. She could try waiting it out. but how long would that take and what if it never ended?!

That wasn't possible, surely? I mean no stone could make her grow and grow until she was bigger than the planet or something? Then again how did a rock do this to her in the first place?

Cynthia breath quickened at those thoughts. No, she had friends and family who wouldn't let that happen to her. She steered her mind away , and back onto thought about being a giant hero and the poses and quips she would need to make. On the other hand, she would also need to find something to wear. Clothes weren't going to cut it, and bedsheets were barely doing the job as is, and if she had another growth sprut they would go kaput! But what else could she wear?

Drapes! That was it! She might still outgrow those, but it would at least buy her some time.

Cynthia tried to stand up, noticing one obvious problem with her size and instead settled on crawling through her room. She hoped if there were any enemies for her to fight, they would be courteous enough to fight her outdoors.

She took the drapes and wrapped it around her body and thighs, before tying the back in a knot. It was far from perfect, Sumia would probably have done a much better job but it would keep her covered for now.

She crawled towards the door and tried to squeeze through.

Ugh they really don't build these things for giants!
13533211221.title: Wake up its a beautiful morning

choices: Cynthia feels another growth spurt oncoming
Frederick returns with Sumia and the two try to get her unstuck from the door
135332112211.content:
Cynthia got her body halfway through the door before reaching a problem. "Uh oh." she thought as she could feel something was wrong; her rear end was stuck in the doorway, keeping her from moving in the wooden frame. She grunted and wiggled to try and get through the door, but couldn't no matter how hard she tried, there just wasn't enough force her hips generated to bend the frame. "Oh come on now!" Cynthia inwardly thought, "I can't get bested by a door! There's no folk tales about heroes whose arch-enemies were doors! I mean, unless the story was about a thief." Suddenly, Cynthia blushed a bit, realizing the gravity of her situation - there she was, freakishly huge, half naked, and with her body stuck inside of a door frame; it truly wasn't one of her finer moments in a long list of blunders and pratfalls on her quest to become a hero. "This just feels so embarrassing right now, I hope that nobody comes along and sees this..."

Cynthia's thought was interrupted by the sound of spat-out coffee flying through the air, some of the liquid hitting her arm and bringing a chilly sensation over it. Cursing her awful luck, Cynthia turned her head to the side and saw Frederick, free of his armor and wearing his usual butler's garb rarely seen by many. The knight captain looked shocked, like he didn't know what to make of the situation, it's no wonder Chrom dubbed him "Frederick the Wary"; Cynthia could hear him gulp and clear his throat as he tried to speak.

"L-Lady Cynthia," he spoke softly, "Is that you?"

"Mornin' Frederick!" Cynthia replied, nervously giggling, "Wow, that was one heck of an overnight growth spurt, am I right?" Frederick seemed further calmed hearing the princess-by-birthright's voice; Cynthia could only imagine this meant he saw her as some sort of monster, but she couldn't blame Frederick, he only wants to protect the kingdom, she remembered stories told to her of the animosity he showed Robin, Henry, and Tharja at first, wary of Plegia. Frederick took a breath and regained his composure, unfurling a handkerchief from his breast pocket and coming closer to Cynthia.

"Forgive me, milady," he spoke as he began wiping the coffee from Cynthia's arm, "I don't know what came over me, it's shameful to call myself a servant of the Ylissean royal family and act in that manner towards you."

"Nah, it's fine! I'd probably do the same in your situation."

"And how, pray tell, did this happen?"

"See, now that's what I'm trying to figure out." Cynthia shifted her arm to rest her chin on her palm. "One moment I'm cute little Cynthia, and the next moment, I'm turning into a giant. Mother's starting to think it's this weird rock I found, but I still think there's an enemy mage out there who forced me into a growth spurt for some nefarious purpose. Not that I'm complaining, once I get out of this door, I'll be all 'Hi-yah!', 'Bam!', 'Pow!', I'll be the incredible Super Cynthia, bringing smiles to the innocent masses and capturing no-good evil-doers in no time!"

"I'm assuming your lack of clothes is directly related to this 'growth spurt'?" Cynthia immediately moved her arms to cover as much skin as she could, her face was as red as a tomato upon Frederick's words.

"Jeez, don't make it weird Frederick! It's already embarrassing enough that I'm stuck in this door, I don't want people seeing me in my makeshift smallclothes either!"

"Ah, yes, forgive me milady." Frederick responded, not realizing how blunt he could be sometimes. He looked at the door frame closely and could see Cynthia's hips stuck behind the wood, part of her body tightly wedged between the frame, meaning she wasn't going anywhere without renovating the castle. "I can now see what the problem is milady, shall I go fetch my axe and bust down the door frame?" Cynthia panicked a little, images of a bloodbath flashing through her mind if Frederick missed.

"Nononono! That's alright! If, uh, you could get someone else to help though, that'd be real neato! Oh please get someone else..."

"Understood, I shall go fetch for the finest carpenters in Ylisse." Then Cynthia started getting flashbacks of the looks she got yesterday from the guards, and she'd rather not have a squad of burly carpenters oogling her as she died from embarrassment.

"That doesn't sound like a good idea either," Cynthia replied, "I've already had some guards give me looks yesterday when my clothes were coming undone, I don't want to have a bunch of strangers doing the same." Frederick raised an eyebrow.

"'Looks', you say? Which guards? I'll send them out for squat-jumps around the castle walls for that."

"Well, there was Stahl in the barracks who first told me my dress was tearing, and then as I went by, there was Blake, Adam, and Holm...Wait, no, way off-topic here! Could you just fetch Mother for me? She'll know what to do!"

"Understood milady, I'll get Queen Sumia immediately. On my way, I'll fetch some jam from the kitchen, lubrication could get you unstuck." As Frederick began to leave, mental images of her hips getting covered in strawberry jam flashed through Cynthia's mind, and the thought skeeved her out a bit. She wiggled around and reached out her arm towards Frederick as he jogged down the hall.

"Wait Frederick, scratch that last part! Just Mother, no jam- and he's gone." Cynthia flopped to the floor and pouted a bit at her misfortune, another in a collection of unlucky moments the young hero-in-training has gone through in life; it wasn't a great way to start the morning off. "Man, why does all this really kooky misfortune keep happening to me?"

1353321122111.content:
Faced with no other choice, Cynthia lay there and waited, her bordem broken only by a worry and curiosity of what methods Frederick and Sumia would use to free her, what kind of enemy or circumstance could have caused to happen, and the ever so passing fantasy of her self as a giant.

Cynthia listened out. Silence. How long would it be before Frederick returned? How long what it be before someone came along and found her this way?

"How long am I going to be stuck here anyway?"

Cynthia suddenly felt like she had to act. Both hands against the door frame she tried to get herself out but to no avail. She tried and tired again and soon felt a dreadfully familiar prickle and suddenly found herself growing rapidly.

The force of her efforts combined with her growth spurt snapped the door and finally let her crawl out, for all the good it did. She could feel her shoulders ripping through her makeshift outfit and the hall was becoming so tight she could scarcely correct this.

With her body rapidly growing body, even the hall was fast becoming too tight for her and she found herself legs then arms cramped against the wall even as she continued to grow larger.

As flustered as she was, Cynthia gazed down around her.

"Whatever evil doer is doing this to me come out!" Cynthia shouted down, surprised at how loud she sounded.
That quite voice inner voice she didn't listen to often enough to told her that maybe drawing further attention to herself wasn't a good idea. Too late to worry about that now, the walls and ceiling were closing in on her and she wasn't sure if she would crush them or they would crush her.

"It can't end like this!" For the first time in a while, Cynthia felt mortal terror, but this wasn't different to being on the battlefield, she had time to consider it and see her life flash before her eyes. "I still have so much to do.. mother..." She thought of that other timeline and shivered. A tear formed in her eyes and she flashed back to when she was but a helpless little girl. Cynthia shook her head. "No, I can't think that way! I will get through this!"

With what little mobility she had left, she tried to make herself as small as she could manage and prayed this strange growth spurt would end.

As her growth continued, she realized she had a choice. She could continue lying back in her predicament, hoping it would end or someone would come save her or she could make a desperate move to save herself.

She could feel her legs being pushed against the wall and gnashed her teeth in pain. Gritting her teeth she stood up as much as she could, pushing against the ceiling with all her strength. Seeing the combined might of her spurt and her own strength free her from the door way she hoped she could achieve the same result here. Maybe the ceiling was less heavily fortified, or maybe she was just that strong but to her relief she forced a hole and was able to climb out and down to the ground below. It was only when her feet were back on the ground did she realize how little of her outfit was left and the sight she might cause.

They think I’m some kind of monster! This is no way for a hero to be!

Cynthia raised a hand, still keeping a hold on the casltle.

“W-wait don’t fire! It’s me, Cynthia! Don’t you recognise me?”

Cynthia was pretty sure she stood out during training, though not for the reasons she hoped.

Some of the guards lowered their weapons or at least hesitated, however others kept their bows or javelins on hand and awaited a signal. Cynthia tensed up knowing she was vulnerable at this size and in this position.

I don’t suppose the arrows would bounce off me cause I’m a giant or something? She tried to convince herself but couldn’t buy it. Still it would be better if she talked her way out of this.

“Hey come on! You can’t think I’m a monster just because I’m really big! Didn’t anyone tell you it’s what’s underneath that counts? I mean just because I am big it doesn’t mean I’m going to be all ME SQUISH HUMANS NOW RAWR! ”

That quiet voice in her head came to life again, telling her that maybe this wasn’t the best time to mention squishing people.

“Uh I mean- please don’t make me into a pincushion!”

The archers looked confused, looking to their leader for directions. He didn't seem sure what to make of this strange giant.

Well… at least no one was attacking but the air was awfully tense.

“So.. are we good?” She asked. She thought of jumping down, but the instant she did that she would be fired upon. Fortunately someone familiar was coming her way.

“Cynthia?! What happened to you?” Stahl shouted up to her, simultaneously in disbelief yet flustered.

“I don’t know, I just got really big! Can you tell these guards to back off so I can get down from here?!”

For a second, Cynthia did not understand why he was flustered, then finally remembered the obvious.

“Oh uh-” Cynthia did her best to cover her with her free hand the bit of the castle she had to work with.

“Stahl!” One of the guard said, and the attention of several others were drawn to him. While Stahl did not stand out among the Shepards, many of the guards knew he was one of those who fought along side Chrom, though in what role they weren't sure. “What should we do about this giant? We found her on the roofs.”

“At ease, this is Lady Cynthia, she wouldn't hurt a fly no matter how big she was.”

“So she really is-” “Forgive us Lady Cynthia!”

“It’s alight, just let me pass and get Mother. Oh and give me a little privacy please.”

They promptly complied.

“And.. thanks Stahl, you’re a life saver!”

He smiled, thoug still avoidied looking directly at her, a red line visible on his face.

“Think nothing of it.”

Cynthia looked for a place where she wouldn't be exposed, but still within easy reach of everyone. She settled for a clearing outside the castle, believing her mother would find her easily enough.

Now no longer worrying about the guards or peepers Cythia’s thoughts drifted back to taking notice of her size.

Just how big am I going to get? She had some terrifying mental images of her towering over Ylisse. Well I’m not feeling that thing I felt before I grew, maybe its done for now? She really hoped so. Maybe I can finally get some clothes that I wont tear to shreds and then I can be giant hero Cynthia!

The thought shook her out of her fears

Her stomach growled, and she realized that with all the excitement she hadn't eaten. Oh man, what am I going to eat like this? I bet I’m going to need like a ton of throat or a bunch of boars or bears or something!

135332112211121.content:
Sumia was a little rusty at flying her Pegasus ever since peacetime had hit Ylisse, she had no need to ride once again, or rather, no time with her full-time duties as Queen taking over her life, and personal chauffeurs taking her around everywhere at Frederick's request had inhibited her ability of free travel - Sumia was far too nice of a girl to turn them down, and she was always sure to tip them as generously as possible. Even with her busy schedule, Sumia found enough time in her life to make periodic visits down to the stables and personally care for the Pegasi, out of kindness and duty to keep the animals happy and healthy. When the call had come in from her guards that her daughter had grown again and required her help, Sumia was worried, yet ecstatic, for she could use hiding the knowledge of her daughter's gigantism as an excuse to get away from the cushy chauffeur travel and ride the wind once more; Sumia saddled up her personal Pegasus, the same she had cared for those 3 years ago, and took to the skies in her riding gear, bound to the forest clearing, glad to feel the old armor bound her shape once more.

"W-Woah! Careful there girl! Let's just go- ah!" Sumia's movements weren't as graceful and controlled as they used to be, her Pegasus going a little wild now that she had action again after so long a break; still, the two were in sync with each other, and though the flight wasn't as short as expected, it still remained a good refresher course for Ylisse's Queen in the art of flight. Touching down on the forest floor, Sumia tied her Pegasus' reins to a small, but sturdy tree, and walked for a short while to reach her daughter. Once in sight, Sumia now understood the urgency in her guard's words; the once petit daughter she had come to love, with vibrant blue pigtails that brightened everyone's mood, was now a towering giantess with her hair undone and unkempt, completely naked with her legs hugged tightly together and to her chest, a hand full of leaves and berries, and evidently a mouth full of them too. "My, my," the Queen spoke calmly, "I didn't think things would get this out of hand. What happened to you Cynthia? And why are you holding all those leaves?"

"Oh, these?" Cynhtia replied, "Well, I first tried to make some smallclothes out of them for comfort, but they didn't want to stay together, so I just started eating them to try and keep my belly full. Preeeetty sure they're poisonous though, they taste like soap..." Sumia sighed a little and sat herself on a log, wanting to get to the bottom of this quickly.

"Alright Cynthia," she spoke, "I want you to walk me through this as detailed and carefully as you can. What happened between the time I last saw you to now?"

"Well, I woke up larger and naked after bed last night, and then right after Frederick came along, I got big again, and I wrecked part of the castle. Which reminds me, sorry about that, and the drapes."

"It's fine, continue."

"So anyways, me and Stahl had to talk the guards down from shooting me silly, and then I came down over here and just waited for you to show up."

"I see..." Sumia looked over her daughter once more, observing the scale Cynthia now stood at. "How you've grown this much in just two growth spurts is a little worrying..."

"Actually, three." Cynthia corrected, looking a little flustered, "I got a teensy bit bigger while waiting for you, but I didn't break anything that time, so I didn't think it was important."

"Regardless Cynthia, you're now almost half the size of the castle, and I don't know if this is going to stop any time soon. We're going to have to do something before this gets out of hand. Hmmm, if only Chrom were here now..." Suddenly, lightbulbs went off in Cynthia's head.

"Oooh, oooh, oooh! What if you got Robin to help us out?!" Sumia looked up at the ecstatic face of her daughter.

"Robin?"

"Yeah! Robin's great at all this tactical stuff, if anybody can figure out why I got so big or how we can stop it, Robin definitely can!" Sumia rubbed her chin for a bit and mulled the thought over; she didn't exactly like the idea of letting more people know about Cynthia's predicament more than she had to, but it's true that Robin could give them a clear advantage in understanding the nature of this problem. Sumia shook her head in agreement and let out a smile.

"Alright, I got you Cynthia, I'll go fetch Robin and bring them back here. But I can't make any promises about fixing this, or how quickly we could do so."

"It's fine Mother!" Cynthia replied with her usual cheer, "A hero needs to keep grinning through even the worst of situations! No dumb rock's going to break this girl's smile, that's for sure!" Just then, Cynthia felt her tummy rumble a bit, bringing a small blush over her face as she felt the naked flesh of her stomach rub over her legs. "But uh, if you could bring back a little bit of food, like some meat or something, and a really big cloth I could blanket myself in, that'd be super-duper..." Sumia giggled a bit in response.

"Okay, I hear you, I'm sure I can find something in the kitchen and storage rooms for you to use." Sumia worked herself up from the log and dusted off the skirt of her armor, getting ready to ride once more. "Alright, I'm going to be gone for a few hours, so I want you to stay put, okay? No confronting strangers, don't freak out if you start growing again, and please stop eating those leaves if you think they're poisonous, okay?" In response, Cynthia immediately dropped the leaves and saluted her Mother.

"You got it!"

"Alright then, I'm heading into town then. We're lucky Robin's so local, else this could be an issue." Sumia turned around and slowly walked back to her Pegasus in the woods. "Stay safe Cynthia!" Sumia waved as she left, disappearing into the cool shade of the trees. Cynthia waved back until her mother disappeared from her sight.

"By Mother, happy flying!" Once gone, Cynthia was left to her own thoughts, alone in a quiet forest. "Alright, gotta pass the time until Mother gets back, what to do? Are there any tales of giants having fun while they wait for the hero to fight them?" Cynthia looked up at the sky, hoping to count clouds, but was instead met with the clear blue sky and bright, shiny sun. "Well, that's disappointing..." In her disappointment though, Cynthia felt the rays of the sun beat down on her head, and then she remembered that Ylisstol was currently in the middle of the summer season. "Though while I'm here and unclothed, I guess I could work on a tan..." Cynthia uncurled herself from her sitting position and flopped over on her belly, letting the sun shine down on her backside; she hummed in pleasure as she felt the warmth hit her spine, and smiled wide as she got in a relaxing position. "Oh yeah! Let the sun shine down on where the sun don't shine! This isn't so bad of a situation after all! Maybe I should take a vacation with Father, Mother, and Lucina to the Hotrealms before I get back to normal!" In her relaxation, Cynthia shut her eyes and drifted off into a small nap, letting the sun tan her body as she dreamed up some new fighting poses and lines to say.

1353321122111211.content:
Sumia knew it would be a simple matter to take some food from the castle, so she made her first prioty finding Robin. Fortunately Robin, her husband Priam and Morgan were training just a short distance from the castle

Sumia called to them, getting Robin’s attention, though Priam was too focused on righting Morgan’s sword swings. She lowered her Pegasus to the ground. Robin turned to greet her. Her posture drooped, clearly from fatigue, yet she was as cordial as always.

"Hello Sumia." Even though Sumia was a queen, she had insisted her friends still call her Sumia, though some of the knights we’re reluctant to do so. Robin suddenly became serious when she got a clear look at Sumia’s face. "I haven't seen you this worried since our battle with Grima, whats the matter?"

"Oh Robin, you always knew me so well! I- I'm really not sure how to explain it...."

"You can tell me everything, we've fought together through thick and thin."

Sumia hesitated for a second.

"Well… It's going to be very hard to believe."

Robin smiled.

"Chrom’s daughter travelled through time to try to save him from an ancient dragon possessing me, I'm sure it can't be stranger than that."

Sumia took a breath.

"It's about Cynthia... she's turned into a giant!"

Robin blinked and was momentarily lost for wards.

"I beg you're pardon?"

Morgan froze for a moment. In his moment of distraction, Priam knocked his wooden sword of his hands.

“Huh?

Priam turned his head, looking oddly intrigued.

"Hmmm... she must have a lot of Chi."

Sumia wasn't sure how to react to that.

Robin sighed.

"Don't mind him, hes still constantly thinking of swordplay and how to get stronger."

Priam almost smiled.

"And you my love."
Robin smiled back at him for just a second before facing Sumia again.

"Anyway did we hear you correctly?"

Sumia nodded.

"Yes. I know it sounds impossible but-"

Morgan’s eyes widened as he struggled to take it all in.. “That sounds like something out of a fairy tale.. then again so does time travel……”

Sumia explained everything that had happened and hoped desperately that Robin had some kind of answer. "Do you have any idea what could have caused this and how it might be undone?"

Robin took a few moments to think about it but shook her head.

"I've never heard or read about anything like this." She looked to her husband and daughter. "Have either of you?"

Priam shook his head.

"I have heard fanciful tales of giants, but none about a human becoming one."

Morgan did likewise.

“Yeah me to. Though I don’t even remember all the stuff I read…”

Sumia frowned.

"Oh I see....."

Robin placed a hand on Sumia’s shoulder.

"Take me to see Cynthia, maybe seeing her will spark a buried memory. Or failing that, we will devise a plan forward together."

Priam was also in thought.

"At that size, Cynthia must be stronger than any man. Though she would need to train carefully to direct that strength"

It was rare for Sumia to get angry.

"This really isn't the time for that kind of talk! My daughter needs help!"

"Cynthia has always desired to be a hero has she not? Though after the war those who knew of our exploits could consider us heroes but I can tell she is not the kind to be satisfied by that. She, like me seeks to continue to improve herself, to be the best she can be-"

Robin sighed having seen Priam go on a lecture more than a few times.

"Now you've done it"
Sumia tried again to cut him off.

"No! I mean I came to Robin for help returning Cynthia to normal size."

Robin gestured for Priam to cease and he did..

"Assuming such a thing is possible... I'll do my best but I can't guarantee anything..."

"Are you sure that is what she truly wants?” Priam asked. “Heedless as she was, she was one of the most spirited of the Shepards, I imagine she would-"

"She can't go through life like this!" Sumia said, accidently yelling. "I mean.. I need to get her some help before she grows any bigger."

Robin nodded.

"I understand, I'll come along right away."

"Thank you. Let me get some food from the castle, and then I’ll take you to see her.."

Priam and Morgan stepped forward.

"I'll come to." “Me to!”

"No!” Sumia said, sharper than she had intended. “I mean my pegasus can only hold two people at a time, especially if we're carrying supplies and...."

Robin immediately understood.

"-At her increasing size I imagine you have yet to find something for her to wear?"

Sumia turned away slightly.

"Y-yes."

Robin began to climb on Sumia’s Pegasus, it being familiar enough with her to aloow her to do so.

"Let's get the supplies and head out."

Priam turned back to Morgan, holding his sword.

"I'll continue training Morgan."

Morgan gulped, picking up his own sword while Sumia and Robin departed.

Sumia and Robin flew first to the castle larder.

"I'm sorry about that. Priam means well but he can be single minded."

"Yes. I'm just glad you're here to help."

Despite Sumia’s faith in her, Robin did not look confident.
"I'm not sure how much I can help, but I'll do what I can. Though as strange as it sounds, I think my husband may have a point."

Sumia froze, nearly dropping what she had been gathering. She was too shocked to speak. Robin was nto surprised to see her react that way and took advantage of Sumia's momentary silence.

"Of course I would not choose to inflict this on anyone, and I will do all I can to help Cynthia. I certainly do not know her like you do, but I know that she is someone who has always saught to use her strength to help others, and has been restless even during peace time."

"But-" Sumia still had trouble putting together what she wanted to say.

"Of course I have not worked out the logisitcs of it, and I do not yet understand what it is that's affecting her,, but it is unlikely such a magic effect could go on indefinitely, if I'm right her growth spurts will have to end sooner or later, then she can decide what to do."

"But how will we keep her fed?"

"I don't know, but I do know Ylisse has had an abundant harvest this year.".

"Let's just get back to Cynthia before she gets any larger!"

They finished gathering and departed as quickly as they could. Sumia feared for a second that they would be face with an even larger Cynthia towering over the castle, but fortunately that was not the case. Cynthia was lying there asleep, at the same size as before. Even Sumia and Robin landing did not disturb her slumber. Robin looked over Cynthia.

"Well?"

"Hmm.. I don't notice anything out of the ordinary, aside from the obvious. I'm not detecting any strange auras of magic around her."

"Does that mean whatever it was has died down?"

"Possibly, though I don't know everything about magic. You should probably have fetched Miriel."

"I see… I just find you easier to talk, and you've helped us overcome every other problem we've faced."

"I appreciate the confidence you have in me but this is no battlefield. Still.. you mentioned a rock causing all this? Could you show me where it is?"

"Uhhh...."

"Well, I mean," Sumia began, "Last Cynthia and I talked, while she was smaller, she had taken it back to her room with her before going to bed."

"Right," Robin replied, "So then it should be in that room also, correct?" Sumia looked off to the side and made a noise of sucking air through her teeth, clearly not knowing how to answer the question.

"Well, Cynthia went through a huge growth spurt this morning, and in that growth she kind of...wrecked the castle..." Robin groaned and rubbed the bridge of her nose between her eyes, causing Sumia to clasp her hands together and bow apologetically. "I'm sorry! I knew I should've kept better track of it!" Robin giggled at her friend and put a hand on her shoulder, working her back up to a standing position.

"Hey, hey, what are you apologizing for? You had no clue things would get to this level so quickly, you aren't at fault here." Robin gave a pat to Sumia's back, causing the Queen to blush and puff her cheeks, a little embarrassed of her apologetic nature. Robin folded her arms and went back into thinking mode. "Still, we can't exactly have this stone lying around where anyone could find it...What are the extent of damages to the castle?"

"An entire chunk of wall and ceiling on the upper east side have been broken down, and sections of the floor in Cynthia's room and hallway have fallen through to the halls below. Frederick's currently getting an estimate from the masonry; we're still in the process of thinking up a cover story to prevent panic in Ylisstol, but that's starting to seem unlikely with the gossiping Shepherds..."

"In that case, we'll have to go back to the castle and look through the rubble. Shall we depart?"

"Actually Robin," Sumia interjected, "I'd much prefer it if one of us could watch Cynthia, I don't like her being alone in the woods like this." Sumia fidgeted her legs around a bit. "I really hate to ask you, but could you stay here with her? I'll go look for the stone while you're here."

"I'd like this to be at least a two-person job," Robin responded, "But I'm not about to deny an order straight from Ylisse's Queen herself! I'll keep watch over Cynthia until you get back."

"Really? Thank you, Robin!"

"But look," Robin continued, " I want you to get Priam and Morgan to help you, alright? Priam's great at clearing rubble away safely, and Morgan's magic can help us extract this stone safely; if it did this to Cynthia on physical contact, who knows what it could do to you if you touched it..." The mental image of a super-sized Sumia tripping over and destroying Castle Ylisstol under her body entered Robin's mind - mean as it was, it caused her to giggle, and Sumia immediately picked up on it.

"Hey, that's rude! I'll have you know I'm not all that clumsy anymore, if that's what you're thinking! Olivia's been giving me dance lessons to keep my steps straight!"

"Sorry, sorry, it won't happen again." Calmed, Robin grabbed a corner of the large cheesecloth they brought with them and faced Sumia again. "Now then, before you go, should we drape this over Cynthia?" Sumia nodded and saddled up on her Pegasus again, gripping the other end of the cloth; she flew over Cynthia's rear with Robin as an anchor, forming an arc of cloth over the girl's backside, which slowly and gently inched up her back as the two women travelled the length of Cynthia's gargantuan body. With Cynthia fully blanketed, Sumia took to the skies once more, looking down at Robin before she left.

"I don't know how long I'll be, but I'll try to get back by nightfall. If I'm not back, then just grab one of the sleeping bags from the basket, okay? Thanks again Robin!" With that, Sumia took off into the sky, leaving Robin alone with the gigantic princess. Robin looked at the content, smiling face of the sleeping princess and blessed her innocent joy she carried, even through this seemingly scary experience. Robin walked off towards the basket of goods they bought and fumbled through it a bit, looking for some supplies she could use; she soon found the sleeping bag and unraveled it, inspecting it over.

"Well I'll be," Robin thought, "Sumia was really planning ahead with this, huh? She knows how to be cunning when she wants to, that's for certain." Robin set the sleeping bag down near a log and looked through the basket again, finding some assorted meats, vegetables, sauces, and spices in the basket, all of very high quality, fit for royalty, alongside some cookware. Taking a frying pan, a bottle of marinade, and some chunks of bear meat & cabbage, Robin made a flame with her Arcfire tome and sat on a log; she used her Elwind tome to chop apart the ingredients with quick precision and sent them into the pan, holding it above the fire and occasionally adding the marinade. "Cynthia always was a great meat-eater, and she must be hungry after this whole experience; if this recipe could get Priam to touch vegetables, it'll certainly do wonders for her!" Robin begun to jovially whistle a tune as she cooked, occasionally adding some sauce and spice when needed, and listened to the light noise of Cynthia's gentle snores in tandem with the chirping tune of birds in the distance.

Was it anything of this world? She had never seen or heard anything about this before, but there was plenty about magic she did not know of. Still if such magic was available, even if it were rare and difficult to acquire, Robin would have expected to have seen giant solders on the battlefield, though that would carry it owns logistical issues and make them a target for archers.

And what kind of stone could have done this? Was it anything of this world? She had never seen or heard anything about this before, but there was plenty about magic she did not know of. If it were

"Mmm I had a wonderful dream.... huh Robin? “ Cynthia bent over Robin. “What are you doing here?!"”

Robin winced slightly and sighed.

"Not so loud." She said. Cynthia was always loud and excitable, even at her normal size. The only thing that appeared to change was the giant Cynthia not being aware however powerful her vocal chords were “And keep the cheesecloth on.”.

It had fallen off when Cynthia sat up.

"Oh sorry!" Cynthia said, hastily covering herself..

Robin flinched again. Cynthia tried to be more quiet but was still too loud. Robin covered on ear.

"Your’re still a little too loud..”

“Sorry.” She said, quieter this time.

“Anyway, your mother came to me, hoping I would be able to help with your.. condition. She also realized the two of you had lost track of the stone and set out to find it, asking me to look out for you while she was gone"

"Don't tell me mom would-"

Robin smiled to herself, wondering if Cynthia had the same image of Sumia Robin had. Robin shook her head.

"Phew... though it would be less lonely with mom."

Robin gestured to the baskets of food she has prepared.

"I prepared you some food you must be starving."

"Oh umm.. thank you Robin."

Robin chuckled.

"Don't worry, I understand that after going through so many growth spurts and going without food you must be starving. I'm just glad you're enjoying my cooking."

Cynthia nodded enthusiastically, giving two thumbs up.

“Yeah it’s great!”

Robin stood straight, taking pride in her work.

"I wasn't completely sure you would go for this, since like Priam you prefer meat but-"
Cynthia paused,

"Well.. now that you mention some meat would be good...."

"Wow you really are a great chef."

Robin smiled

"Thank you, I've had a lot of time to practice as of late, and I knew I’d have to prepare something big to keep your going."


At the word “big” Cynthia looked as though she had been stricken.

"Do you think I'm going to get any bigger?"

"I can't be certain, but no I don't thin. As far I can tell there's no further magic effecting you."

"Do you think I'll ever be normal again?"

Robin stepped towards her.

"We will do everything we can to help you. If I cannot figure out the stone’s mysteries I will try to find someone who can.”

“But If worse comes to worse, we’ll help you adapt to your new size.”

“Ugh I really don’t want to be like this any longer! I wrecked the castle and nearly got shot at!”

“Oh yeah, Stahl recognized and even stood up for me!”

Robin nodded.

“Exactly, and you’re mom and me. I’m sure everyone in the Shepard’s and anyone who got to know you would feel the same way.”
