1353321122111211211111211121112.content:
Cynthia dashed past the walls of the castle, running through the countryside outside of town to cause as little damage as possible, but still being mindful of how she could get to the source of the yell quickly.

"Hold on, troubled citizen, I'm on my way!" Cynthia's feet pounded across the ground, leaving deep indents in the earth as she ran; small earthquakes shook up the surrounding area, sending those unlucky enough to the ground, usually on their rear. Eventually, Cynthia's eyes focused onto a small farm settlement, disconnected from much of the surrounding village, yells erupting in greater intensity from the house as she approached. "Found you!" Cynthia leapt from the ground, lunging forward towards the farmland property like a bird taking off from its nest. As she hit the ground, her heels dug into the earth, creating small canals as the velocity pushed her forward; Cynthia spread her legs apart and struck a fighting pose, ready for action. "Giant Hero Cynthia is at your service! No need to fear! Point me to the trouble and I'll help right out!"

"Oh, you wanna know where the trouble is?!" Cynthia looked down at the small family of three below her, a farmer, his wife, and their son; the farmer was pointing at Cynthia and his face looked positively steamed. "There it is! Right there! Look at what you done did to my farm!" Cynthia looked back towards the path she took; footprints marked the destroyed grass where she stepped, the ground was cracked and swollen with uprooted dirt and minerals, and Cynthia actually took notice of what her leap did to the famer's vegetable field.

"Ohhhh...Um, whoops..."

"Whoops ain't gonna cut it sweetie! Who's gonna fix my darn farm?! And for the love of Naga, close your legs up!" Cynthia looked down at the young boy staring up her makeshift dress; it suddenly occurred to her that she wasn't wearing any underwear, and she quickly clamped her legs shut and pulled down on her dress, trying to cover up as much as she could as her face bloomed into a blush.

"Omigosh! Omigosh!" Cynthia eventually kneeled down at the apex of her embarrassment, creating more indents in the farmland, and making the farmer angrier in turn. He stormed off into the barn, presumably to shout as loud as he could, leaving Cynthia to talk with the farmer's wife and child.

"Oh sweetie, don't mind him," the wife spoke, "Clerics in town say he's got high blood pressure, he does. You're one of them 'giant people' everyone in town's been talking about, ain't ya? Sorry ya had to get yelled at like that, it's gotta be bad for you since ya ain't normal and all." The words stung Cynthia a little, but she tried to stay positive.

"Ma, she sure is pretty." The child spoke up, erecting a blush from Cynthia, both of embarrassment and of joy towards the complement.

"I'm sorry about the farm Miss. But uh, what exactly was your husband yelling about before?"

"Oh nothin', some of the cattle just broke loose last night is all, there was talk about thieves stealing livestock for a while now, so he freaked out, but I just think they're out in the woods grazing, they usually come back all good like that."

"Well, I mean," Cynthia responded, "It could be brigands, couldn't it?"

"Well..." the wife retorted, holding her chin, "It always could be..." The woman shook her head. "But what are we supposed to do then? We ain't got weapons or nothing, and it's not like we can't just start milking the goats instead. We make a comfy enough living, and we could probably afford more cows this season."

"But if it is brigands, then they could just steal the cows again!" Cynthia slowly stood up, making sure the young child couldn't see under her dress again. "How's about I go into the woods and look for the cattle? If it really is a pack of thieves, at this size, I'll give them such a scare, so much that they'll never come back again!"

"Well, it'd be much obliged and all," the wife responded, "But my husband's right though, the vegetable fields are ruined; thankfully we didn't plant nothin', but how are we gonna till the soil in time for the season?"

"Well, I could do that too. I'm not familiar with it, but I could try." Cynthia started to feel bad about her accidental damages again and bended over apologetically, unknowingly letting the young child get a good look at her cleavage. "Sorry again about this! I promise I'll fix the farm and solve the case of the missing cattle."

"Thanks for that sweetie, it's good to know young people today take responsibility for their actions; you could be a big help." Cynthia perked up at the compliment, especially the use of the word "big" in the sentence. I'm gonna try and calm my husband down a bit, and I'll let you decide what to tackle; personally though, if you could take the farm first, that'd be a real fine help. Come along now." The woman tugged on her son's arm, trying to break his gaze from Cynthia's breasts as they retreated into the farmhouse. Cynthia stood tall and firm, fixed her dress, and turned around, staring at both the destruction she unintentionally caused and the woods the cattle disappeared into.

"Alright, do or die time!" Cynthia thought, "This is gonna be the make or break moment that makes me into a giant hero; I can't let the nice farmers down now that they're counting on me! Cynthia took takes at each focus, deciding what she should do; if she fixed the farm now, then the family would have a stable source of income sooner, but the cattle could potentially be long gone, either attacked by beasts or truly stolen by brigands - on the flipside, searching for the cattle could potentially lead to discovery of crime, which she could nip in the bud easily, and if she worked quick enough, she could easily come back and fix the farm over time. Cynthia thought long and hard about the effects of each decision she could possibly make, then quickly made her choice.

I really want to teach those bandits not to pick on farmers!

She looked over the damage she caused.

But I really should fix this.. She started to bend down, holding her dress to avoid another wardrobe malfunction. But if I don't chase the bandits now they could get away! I can always fix this latter.

She stood up, resolved, determined and kind of excited. She took another step, this time watching both her feet and the ground beneath her.

"I'll come back with your cows soon, I promise! Then I'll try and fix your farm."

Cynthia headed out, relieved when the village was behind her and she no longer had to watch her steps so carefully. Robin had warned her about the risk she posed to people or buildings, but she never thought she'd damage the land just by walking! She really had to watch her feet now, though she was sure she was getting better at it.

Her feet... hmm... were they always so small? Proportionally, obviously since at this size they were huge. She heard people comment on how small the Shepard's feet were, but assumed it was just idle complaining.. No time to worry about that now, she had bandits to find!

Cynthia had no idea where the bandits could be. Of course it was quite possible they were far away by now, but she hoped that wasn’t the case. At least her height gave her a great view of the forest, as she easily towered over just about every tree and her long legs let her cover a tremendous amount of ground. The trouble is, from this height much of the forest looked the same.

"Hmm... gonna have to think this one through. I've had to do that a lot more lately." Cynthia was used to acting on the first though that came into her head, but she realized now that was she was giant sized, every action, every movement could have terrible consequences. She still wasn't used to slowing down, but it gave her some new perspective. "I could charge around the forest but I might never find them and I'd probably do so much damage..... Hmm... if I were a bandit where would I put a hideout?"

Cynthia moved slowly across the forest now trying to look for any area that stood. Over there! That far away circle with no trees. It was almost certainly much too large to be natural, it could easily be bandit's encampment!

She wanted to run, but stopped herself. Aside from the damage she might cause to the forest, if she started running now, they would hear her footsteps and move themselves and the stolen cattle on before she could reach them. She could chase after them, but if the woods were dense enough her size could work against her. Besides it would be to much better effect if she slowly approached their camp, then when they knew she was coming for them she would pick up speed and be on them before they could escapes with the cows. If this was the encampment, then it was likely they had a makeshift pen to hold them.

Perfect! She couldn't help but smile, this was going to be great! She wondered if she'd have time to strike a good heroic pose. Maybe if she was quick.....

As she drew nearer she quickened her pace, breaking into a run. Those bandits were going to wet themselves when they saw a giant charging at them!

Taking a brief glance down she could they had spotted her and were suitably panicked. Excellent! She decided to add to the effect with a fierce battle cry, boosted by her size, suitably terrifying the bandits.

She stood over the encampment, taking another step so they could hear her loud stomp. She post quickly, stretching her arms out as she normally did, though without her lance her pose seemed incomplete.

"HALT BANDITS! IT IS I, GIANT HERO CYNTHIA! GIVE BACK THE CATTLE YOU STOLE!" Cynthia loved the way her voice carried across the forest. Her new size had some nice perks. She would have given a longer, more flowery speech but knew bandits were not the honourable sort who would stay and listen.

And naturally, after taking just a few seconds to gawk in terror at her, each and every bandit turned tail, there screams filling the air as they scattered. Well she wouldn't them all to deliver her message. With just a few steps she caught up with one trying to reach pen holding the cattle.

She grabbed him and dangled him in front of her face, letting him hang upside down. The bandit wriggled and squirmed, trying to free himself of Cynthia's grip, apparently fearing the fall less than her.

"D-don't eat me!"

Cynthia stuck her tongue out.

"Eat you? Bleh, I don't eat humans and I bet you taste terrible. The village sent me and you better leave them alone or next time I'll really make you regret, got it?"

The bandit nodded dumbly.

"Good, get going and tell the others!" She placed him and he ran as fast as his legs could carry him. Something occurred to Cynthia and she called after him. "And if you attack any other villages, I'll make you sorry!"

Cynthia beamed, taking a moment to bask in her work. She had just subdued an entire gang of bandits without needing to raise a weapon! Maybe she really could help people like this, maybe she could truly be a hero. A weapon.. she still didn't have a weapon, and wasn't sure where she might get one. She could try fighting at this size but it would leave her vulnerable. She wondered what would have happened if they hadn't been cowed into surrender. She was sure she could handle it but no matter how she was an axe would still hurt....

She put those thoughts to the back of her mind, remembering her objective. She bent down the pick up the cows who were mooing fearfully or trying to escape.

Guess being this big wouldn't just scare bandits.....

When it came to animals, Cynthia was not particularly gifted or practiced, having once neglected her own pegasus but she tried to calm them down, making soothing noises and stroking them. This had only minimals effect, so Cynthia scooped up as many as she could, carefully holding them in her arms. She could sense their anxiety.

"Don't worry, I'm not going to hurt you and you'll soon be back home."

She strode back, eager to return to the village, feeling at last like a real hero.

8 hours.

It took Cynthia 8 hours to get her job restoring the farm done. By that time, the sun began to set, and the sky became a creamy orange, a sight that relaxed Cynthia after a whole day of strenuous work. Cynthia wiped the sweat from her brow and fixed her dress, dyed with splotches of brown from the dirty earth; she waltzed over to the barn where the farming family were finishing dinner and rapped on the large door with her fist. The three came outside and looked up at Cynthia, awaiting the status report on her work.

"I tried my best sir!" she cried enthusiastically. Cynthia pointed to the farmland with her right hand and balled her left fist to the big smile on her face, waiting for praise. "Tell me how I did? Am I a farmland hero or what?" The farmer looked at the land, once previously destroyed, and observed the work Cynthia did. The land was hand-plowed with unaligned grooves of varying length and depth in the dirt, the fencing was bent in numerous places and equally unaligned, and the dirt looked dampened in some places, while bone-dry in the others; it was pure amateur work, very sloppy in a lot of areas, but it was better off than it was before. Out of the corner of his eye, he saw one of Cynthia's deeper footprints now filled with water, forming somewhat of a small lake, or rather, a large pond on his property. The farmer tried to look a little enthusiastic, but he couldn't help but feel a sense of disappointment at how good his farmland looked compared to Cynthia's work; he sighed and chose his words carefully.

"Well, it's not terrible, but..." Cynthia looked disappointed, her face beginning to contort into a pout. "Either way, it looks a lot better than that pile o' mess from before. I guess I can patch it up tomorrow. Thanks missy."

"You say that," Cynthia started, "But I just feel bad about making you work Mr. Farmer, especially after I ruined it in the first place."

"Nah, it's fine. If it wasn't the crops, it was gonna be looking for them darn cows. I'd say you've been a big help today with that, literally." Cynthia felt a little bit happier about the compliment towards her cattle-rescue, and her face cracked into a small smile once again. "In any case, we gotta reward you somehow."

"Oh, no thanks! A hero's just happy knowing she helps people out!"

"No, seriously, you're gonna want this, sugar." spoke the farmer's wife. She retreated into the barn with her son for a moment, and when they came back out, they both carried a huge, bunched up piece of burlap and set it to the ground in front of Cynthia.

"What's this?" Cynthia grabbed the burlap and unfolded it. When unfurled, the burlap made the shape of a triangle, with a hole in the top and two holes in the sides. Cynthia's face erupted into a blush after putting the clues together. "I-Is this what I think it is?!"

"Sure is," answered the wife, "We done took an old grain sack we weren't using anymore and cut a couple holes in it for ya. We figured it'd be so folks aren't looking at your-"

"I'm familiar with how smallclothes work!" Cynthia looked at the gift some more before turning back to the little family below her. "Do you, uh, mind if I duck behind the barn?"

"Sure thing sweetie, take your time." On that, Cynthia slowly walked behind the barn and looked around to make sure nobody could see her. Slowly, she fit her legs into the burlap and pulled up on the makeshift underwear, pulling them up to her hips and making sure they were tight. Cynthia twisted around, making sure they were comfy around her hips, and did a couple squats to make sure they'd stay together. Once satisfied, Cynthia stepped out from around the barn again, prompting the wife to speak up. "Well, how do they fit?"

"Well, uh..." Cynthia stammered, eyes focused on the young boy below, hoping she doesn't accidently embarrass herself further. "They're pretty comfy and all, I gotta say, and nothing's wrong with an extra degree of privacy. Thanks for making them Miss." Cynthia looked at the sky, making a judge of her time. "Well, it's getting dark, and a knight can never rest! Fiends do come out in higher rates during the night and all! Sorry again about the farmland, I hope I was a help with the cattle and fields!"

"Anytime sweetie. You ever wanna pop in again and lend a hand, come right on over." The farmer shot his wife a glare, not intending for another "heroic entrance".

"Alright then, justice awaits!" Cynthia spun around and made a stance, ready to bolt into town.

"Walk slowly!" shouted the farmer.

"R-Right..." On that, Cynthia calmly and slowly walked away from the farm, satisfied by her work, and made her way back into town. During her stride, she thought to herself. "Well, that could've gone better. But hey, at least I fixed the farm a bit, and stopped grand theft cattle while I was at it! Being huge rocks!" Cynthia stared up at the sky, the creamy orange began to turn a magenta color, and the moon began to show through all the clouds. "It's gonna get dark soon, Mother could be worried about me. I should probably get home soon." Cynthia stuck a finger to her lips and stopped her halt. "On the other hand, this could be a good opportunity to look for more trouble! There have been some reports about muggings during the night, imagine how safe the town could be if I knock 'em all out in one night!" Cynthia thought over her options a bit, weighing the consequences, before reaching a conclusion.

13533211221112112111112111211122111.content:
The thought of trapesing around Ylisse, single handily stopping all crime in one night filled Cynthia with glee. What could be more heroic than that?!

But she remembered the damage she caused to the farmland, and Robin’s words about the town folk being afraid of her. She still wasn’t completely used to her giant body, and she couldn’t see as well in the dark as she could during the day. It would be very easy to cause more unintended destruction, making the townsfolk even more afraid of not only her, but Sumia and Robin as well.

Cynthia sighed. She would have to put her heroic ambitions on hold at least for now.

She wondered if restrain was part of the hero’s way. Before being turned into a giant she never really had to worry. Though on the positive side, she could potentially help far more people now.

She stopped. If Robin had found a cure, she didn’t want it anymore. She could understand Robin and Sumia wanting to return to their normal lives, but after the war, she had become just another solider, albeit one with famous friends and family. She tried not to let it get to her, but whereas Chrom and Lucina were viewed as legends, she aware of those who viewed her as a joke, no matter how hard she trained. She had wondered if she would ever be like her sister Lucina, strong and confident, that people instinctively rallied behind.

Being big allowed her to help people on a scale she couldn’t before, but she had to admit she would likely never be a leader like Lucina or Chrom. Still as long as she could carve out her own niche and continue helping people and fighting evil could be happy.

Now she really didn’t want to be “cured”. Maybe if she asked nicely Robin and Sumia would let her stay like this… though that did assume Robin had found a cure. Could even someone like a Robin find a cure to something previously unknown so quickly? It didn’t seem likely.

Hmm... Where would Robin be? Cynthia’s first guess would be at Robin’s home or out training with her husband. But it was likely Robin would be spending less time in town, with the Ylisse being uncomfortable around her, and even Priam couldn’t train all day and night…. could he? Surely Robin was exaggerating about what she said before… right?

There was a good chance she was at the castle, and even if she wasn’t mother would be there. It was decided then, to the castle!

She walked through the night, almost as though she was on a casual evening stroll but she kept her eyes and ears open, not only to avoid any unintended harm, but also to listen out in case there were any muggings nearby. She wasn’t going to stomp around town, at least with things as they were, but if she came across any… woe betide that evil doer!

Cynthia was surprised how well she could hear at her size. Even with people appearing relatively fair away from her or talking quietly, she could hear them clearly. Was sharper hearing another perk of being a giant? All the easier to find those in trouble!

To Cynthia’s relief and disappointment, her journey to the castle was uneventful. As she approached, she held out her hands and announced her presences. The guards had started to recognise her again, though with Sumia and Robin being the only other giants it would be hard for them not to recognise her.

As Cynthia approached the castle, Sumia immediately stood up and spun to face her daughter.

“Cynthia where have you been?”

“Hey no need to worry, I’m a big girl!” Cynthia knew it was a bad joke, but she wanted to lighten the mood.

Sumia’s face creased.

“Cynthia..”

Cynthia became serious.

“I know mom, but it’s fine, I watched nearly every step I took but.. I may have stepped on some farmer’s farmland and spent the last couple of hours fixing it.”

“Cynthia you do remember what Robin told us?”

“I know and I tried! But the farmer’s cattle were also missing and I not only got them back, I scared the bandits so that they’d never come back again!”

“Well that is something….” Sumia was unusually cautious with her praise.

Cynthia did not pick up on her mother’s ill ease as she was so caught up telling her story.

“-And I promise I watched my feet the whole way back! Hey have you noticed we have really small feet?”

Sumia sighed.

“Yes dear, I’ve heard people point that out before.”

Cynthia spoke faster, almost too fast for Sumia to hear, certainly too fast for her to get any words out.

“So after I brought back the cows I worked really hard to fix the farm. The sun was high in the sky when I started and when I finished it was night. I didn’t do a perfect job, but I tried my best. And when I saw it was night I wanted to go after the muggers, but I knew the townsfolk were still afraid of me and you would be expecting me back.” Cynthia took a deep breath. “Hey where’s Robin? Did she find a cure?”

“Robin is with Priam. She kept trying to search for something but didn’t find anything. She thinks Tiki is our best hope, so we’re going to have to wait for the messengers to return.” Sumia couldn’t hide her sadness.

“Oh. Well I was thinking... even if a cure is found, maybe I could stay like this?”

Sumia gasped.

“Cynthia… but why?”

“I can help so many more people like this! And I’m getting better at moving around everyday, in no time at all I’ll be as nimble as before!”

“But were you always clumsy, like but less so. At our size that could put a lot of innocent lives in danger.”

“I’m being careful! I have to admit I’ve never had to be so careful in my life, but I think starting to get the hang of it!”

Sumia was silent for a moment.

135332112211121121111121112111221111.content:
"No, sweetie." Sumia shook her head disapprovingly. "The fact of the matter is that this condition is far from a blessing, even if it's not necessarily harmful. It might seem neat to be a giant for now, but people could get hurt with one wrong step, or even one nasty rumor."

"I'll be careful! I promise!" protested Cynthia.

"It's not you, Cynthia, I'm more worried about other people. Not everyone who lives in Ylisstol is a nice person, that I'm completely sure of, and even if you insist on being a big help to the citizens, some people could still hold resentment to you at this size, and you could be easily ostracized."

"Come on, Mother, I'm not so easily hurt by mean words! Besides, it's not like I haven't been ostracized before!" Sumia tilted her head.

"What do you mean?"

"Well, a lot of it was back in the future, but people always called me names and stuff for trying to be a hero, Severa especially. She still did it a bit when we met up again in this time."

"Really?" Sumia asked, concerned for her daughter's feelings. "But I thought you and Severa were friends?"

"We are, but she's kinda a bully between you and me, I think she got even a bit more bully in her when she came back from that long trip..." Cynthia shook her head. "But that's not the point! Point is that I'm used to mean names and hurtful words! Let 'em at me! I eat words for breakfast!" She stepped forward a bit to illustrate her intensity, and was met with the tap of a blade's hilt upon her foot. She looked down to see Sully and Peri, standing close to her foot, handling a small group of horses by their reins, leading them to the stalls.

"Could you watch where you're stepping?!" Sully barked, a little irritated. "You almost took my arm off there!" Cynthia stepped backwards and gasped.

"Omigosh! I'm so sorry Sully, Peri! It's super-lucky you two didn't get hurt! It won't happen again!"

"Gods, you're lucky you're Chrom's kid. If it was anyone else, I swear to Naga..." The two continued walking to the stables; Cynthia swore Peri shot her a glare before they left that carried a sense of murderous intent behind it, and it creeped her out as always.

"See, Cynthia? That's exactly what I'm talking about! I know you try, but it's hard to be careful when we're the size of buildings, someone could get accidentally hurt without your knowledge." Sumia stepped closer and put her hands to her hips, making a commanding face. "We're going to ask Tiki about this, and once we find a cure, I want you to go back to normal along with Robin and I, okay?"

"But Mother-!"

"No 'but's!" Cynthia looked defeated, and shuffled her feet around the floor of the courtyard as she looked down at them.

"Fiiiine..." Sumia relaxed her face into a smile and shook her head in approval.

"Good. I promise you Cynthia, this is for your own good." Sumia outreached her arms towards her daughter. "Now, could I get a hug?" Cynthia waited a bit without saying anything, eventually moving into a hug with her mother; Sumia rubbed her cheek against Cynthia's affectionately, happy that she got through to her daughter. The hug was shortly broken and Sumia followed up with a light yawn. "Anyways, I'm feeling sleepy, so I'm going to get to bed early. Is there anything else you want to talk about?"

"No..."

"Alright, but wake me if you need me for anything. Goodnight sweetie!" Sumia turned backwards and walked off slowly to the courtyard barn, taking care not to trip and break something. Once her mother was out of sight, Cynthia sat down and leaned her back against the castle walls, and thought to herself about the interaction with her mother.

"Darn it Mom!" Cynthia thought, "You just don't get it! Being a giantess is what makes me a super-special hero like Lucina, without it I'm just a run-of-the-mill soldier!" Cynthia balled up her fist and started beating her cranium with it. "Gah! Stupid, stupid Cynthia! Why didn't you just tell her all this stuff?! Stop thinking up smart rebuttals after the conversation's over!" Cynthia stopped beating herself and sighed. She shook her head and looked up at the sky; judging by the position of the moon, it was nearing the late night, not midnight, but about two paces from it - she had to be well-rested, or else she couldn't be the best hero she could be. "Welp, better hit the hay too. Just another day before we get the cure and I gotta stop being big..." Cynthia got up and prepared to walk off to the barn to join Sumia.

"Wait a second." Cynthia stopped as she put the words together in her mind. A nasty thought had sprouted in her mind, one so brilliant that someone could even call her an evil genius. "What if that cure never comes? Like, if I just got rid of the rock before Robin can do something about it?" A big goofy grin came over Cynthia's face as she continued thinking over the nasty plot. "Yeah! And then while I'm at it, I can make a whole bunch of people grow too, so we don't accidentally step on them, and we can make a big force to make the townsfolk accept us!" Cynthia bobbed up and down, shaking the earth a bit as she moved around in excitement. "Oh Cynthia, you are a friggin' genius! Let's see, who should I grow? Maybe Severa, Kjelle, Miss Cordelia, definitely Luci, aaannnddd..."

Cynthia's excitement stopped for a moment as Sumia and Robin flashed in her mind, her smile dwindled as she thought about them. Was it really right to do something so devious and throw away the stone? Sumia and Robin obviously didn't like being big as much as she did, and seem very intent on finding a cure. Furthermore, what about all the people she forced growth upon? If they didn't want to be big, then would it really be right to rob them of their lives? Cynthia figured they could all create a new kingdom of giant women if push came to shove and then ally under Ylisstol, but then she'd have to think up how to run the culture of the race, and that took a whole lot of thought-work she didn't want to devote time into. Cynthia rethought over her nasty plan, and internally debated with her morals and her desires.

1353321122111211211111211121112211111.content:
What am I thinking? I can’t force this on anyone! And I can’t make mom stay like this if its making her miserable. Maybe this stone is corrupting me!

That can’t be it, if it were I’d be stomping on buildings or something really out of character like that. Cythia sighed. Maybe I’m just lonely? I won’t force the stone on anyone, but I bet there are others who want to be big to. Like Kjelle! She’s all about getting stronger, and what’s stronger than this? And I bet sis could enjoy it, at least if I talked her into it and maybe and Severa.. wait I don’t think a giant Severa would be a good idea.

There’s no way mom would let me use the stone on them but maybe if I asked Tiki or got Robin’s permission… Robin would never… unless she thought it was a tactical advantage or something! Hey maybe Robin could stay big and we’d hang out together again!

Hmm.. a voluntary force of giants. Her mom would never approve of the idea, but if Robin truly though the realm was still in danger maybe she could sell the idea to her, and if that were the case it would be easy to convince Chrom and maybe Luci!


The thought filled her with excitement and she instinctively wanted to clap again, but quickly checked her surroundings. All was clear. Having to watch her every moment had been tough at first, but Cynthia was getting used to it, and the way slowing down had changed the way she thought.

The excitement suddenly drained out of Cyntha. She realized her time as a giant could be ending. For all she knew the messengers could be back the very next day with a cure, which would be great for her mom and maybe Robin but Cynthia could be back to begin a normal soldier and back to being a joke.

She had to act before it was too late! Cynthia leaped to her feet, inadvertently rousing Sumia.

“Cynthia where are you going?”

“Oh uh...” Cynthia was not good at thinking up lies, especially not too quickly. “I just want to go for a walk.”

Sumia narrowed her eyes for a second.

“Really?” She paused. “Well, be careful Cynthia.”

“I will.”

She daintily stepped over the castle wall.

Where could Robin have got to? She tried to remember where Priam liked to train. Or would Robin at her home? Or staying elsewhere? This could be tougher than she anticipated. Pausing to gather her thoughts, Cynthia still thought walking through Ylisse at night could be risky, and there was a good chance Robin wouldn’t be there. Cynthia recalled there was a particular spot some-way Priam liked to train. It was semi remote, so Robin may have gone there if she wished to avoid others at size.

Cynthia set off, hoping her hunch was right. She thought of making a grand entrance, but realised the tactician would not be amused if one of Cynthia’s heroic poses woke up her family.

She tread carefully towards where she hoped they were, almost tiptoeing. Sure enough as she drew near she could see Robin lying down in the distance.

She approached carefully, struggling to keep cool. Was Robin asleep? It looked that way, as she came closer she could see Robin holding Priam and Morgan agaisnt her chest.

“Robin?” Cynthia called to her as quietly as she could.

Robin’s eyes flickered open.

“Cynthia?” She whispered “What brings you here this late?”

Cynthia held out her hands and stepped back.

“Oh sorry! I didn’t wake you, did I?”

Robin shook her head. She did not rise, turned ever so slowly, keeping watch of Priam and Morgan.

“No. I was just doing some thinking before I went to sleep.” She smiled and looked at her husband and son. “These two were tuckered out from the days training. Grima could come roaring by and I doubt they’d wake.”

“That’s good… I think.”

“So why are you here at this hour?”

Cynthia pursued her lips.

“You haven’t found a cure yet, have you?”

“No. This is beyond anything even they know of. Tomorrow we will send a message to Tiki."

Cynthia held her fingers together.

“I was thinking… when you find a cure could you not cure me?”

“I still don’t know if our condition can be reversed, but do you really wish to life your life as a giant? I’m sure you have noticed how lonely it can be.”

“But without this I’m just a normal soldier! Except people think I’m a joke….”

Robin stood up and placed her other arm on Cynthia’s shoulder.

“You are a capable fighter and a hard worker. Perhaps you spend too much time with your… flourishes.”

Cynthia quickly corrected her.

“Heroic poses!”

Robin ignored this.

“But you were fine soldier and an asset to the Shepards.”

Cynthia smiled.

“Well I know how to swing a lance.” She motioned as though she holding a lance, even adding approite battle cries before Robin cut her off with a sharp glare.

“Please don’t wake my husband and child.”

“-But you said not even Grima could wake them.”

“It was a figure of speech. Though at this size you could give a run for his money.”

“Really? I guess I could try grabbing his neck and-”

Robin raised her voice ever so slightly, but enough to make her disapproval clear.

“I wasn’t being literal.”

Cynthia stopped and stood rigidly straight, as though Frederick had told her to stand in line.

“Sorry.”

“As I was saying, you were a fine soldier, even if it seemed you didn’t take battle as seriously as you should have.”

Cynthia raised her fists, though not in a threatening way.

“Hey! I gave it my all out there!”

“Not so loud. And I do not doubt that, but when you are on the battlefield the slightest move can make the difference between life and death. That is why I did not always appreciate your heoric poses.”

“But they help keep everyone’s spirit up, especially my own.” Cynthia shivered a little. “When we were in the future I needed something to keep us fighting when everything seemed hopeless….”

“I understand. I believe you’re learning to strike a balance. You are quite capable of protecting and inspiring people even at your normal size.”

Cynthia brightened a little.

“I guess but...”

“But?”

“No matter how much I train, they’ll always be people better than me like Luci. She’s way better at inspiring people and a better hero and no one ever thinks she’s a joke!”

“We all do what we can, Cynthia. When I make battle-plans, I do so knowing that every soldier will have a role on the battlefield, and that includes you.”

“I can do so much more like this, inspire and protect so many more people. You said that we would always need soldiers!”

Robin rubbed her chin.

“That is true… though I hope humanity one reaches point when it isn’t.”

Cynthia stood taller, looking her dead in the eyes.

“But as long as there are bad people out there who would hurt the innocent the world will always need heroes.”

Robin nodded.

“Yes I agree.”

“But Mom thinks that when you find a cure, I should shrink down because I might be dangerous to everyone. Could you tell her that maybe it’s ok if I stay big?”

Robin was silent for a moment, looking at Cynthia with those analytical eyes.

“A few days ago I would have agreed with her. You are headstrong and prone to rushing in, and at this size, that is very dangerous. But I see you are doing your best to improve. Keep practising, continue approving yoru awareness and balance and I will speak with Sumia. Though you should have talked it out with her rather than gone behind her back.”

Cynthia blushed.

“I tried but she wouldn’t listen! I just thought it would be easier to talk to her if I had you in my corner.”

“I see. Was there anything else?”

“Well I was also thinking...” Cynthia hesitated, though only for a second. “If this giant thing isn’t so bad, how about we get others involved?”

“Cynthia-” Robin started to say, but Cynthia was speaking very quickly know.

“I don’t mean using the stone on anyone who doesn’t want it! W-would I think of anything like that? I mean enlarging other people who would help protect Ylisse like Sis or Kjelle… I mean if they wanted it! We could make a special defense cabal or something!”

Robin drew in a deep breath and exhaled, carefully considering what Cynthia said.

“A bold suggestion. Not something we can rush into carelessly, it would require planning and I would have to talk it over with Chrom and Sumia but..”

Cynthia’s eyes grew starry.

“You like the idea?!”

Robin smiled lightly.

“It has a certain appeal. Though we would need to make sure we have the logistics to support giant soldiers, and that they would be both willing and not prone to abuse their new statures, so likely soldiers we already know.”

“Like the other Shepards!”

“Perhaps...” Robin yawned. “I am more tired than I realised, was their anything else?”

“No I’m good. Thanks Robin!”

“Good Night Cynthia.” Robin lay down again

“Night Robin! Thanks for the talk!”

Feeling as though a weight had been lifted from her, Cynthia returned to the castle and slept outside it.

13533211221112112111112111211122111112.content:
The sky was a bleak dusk, dark and shadowless as the dawn prepared itself to surface. The pitch-black sky was the perfect cover for a small group of wyverns & a few Pegasi to sift through the sky with, all carrying upon them bandits of varying genders. The leader at the head of the pack was a rugged-looking, yet gangly man, clearly up to no good; he looked forward whilst addressing his caravan.

"So, run this by me again:" he spoke, "My men were scared off by some giant lass near Ylisstol, right in the middle of the livestock smuggling operation?" He glanced a bit back, taking care to keep one eye on the skies, and gazed upon a bandit, shaking a tad and face coated in a thin layer of sweat.

"That's right Boss." he responded.

"Hmph." The bandit leader faced forward again. "With such a crazy tale, anyone would've thought you'd be throwing back a couple pints of ale."

"I'm serious Boss, I'll never forget how that lass dangled me from such a height, high enough to kill me; why, she could've swallowed me whole right on the spot she could've!"

"I could've had your head rolling on the floor of our hideout if I'd wished it for a tale like that. You're lucky I'm such a believing man, what with all them zombies popping up around here from 3 years back." The burly man looked back at a female upon a Pegasus, armor a striking red like all deviant Pegasi riders. "You got the goods?"

"Sir!" she cried, holding up a bag of staves. The leader gave a smirk.

"Good. Then let's look for this 'little lady' and get back to our work." They flew for a while with the bandit leader hard at work looking across the land with a telescope. It took a bit of focus in the dark, but he took notice of a set of footprints pointed towards a farm. He traced them back into the walls of Castle Ylisstol, and eventually took note of the gigantic Cynthia, sleeping along the side of the castle; the sight surprised the bandit a bit, but he quickly shrugged off the surprise. "Bingo, that really is a huge lass! Guess I had you sissies pegged wrong, but she should be no match for us." He took note of the sentries along the wall, noting how they were sleeping or lazing around, seemingly a product of peacetime in the halidom.

"Go." he commanded as he pointed towards a forest enclosure near the castle walls, prompting his group to touch down, hidden by the trees. The leader climbed skyward with his wyvern and whispered a command in its ear, before leaping from its back and watching it fly the way it came from. The bandit unfurled a layer of cloth from his person as he fell; it formed a parachute when it fully went spread, and slowed the man's descent exponentially, allowing him to touch down within the castle walls, shrouded by the darkness. Quietly and swiftly, he made his way towards the border wall and knocked a brick, resonating a sound through the cement; in response, his crew had teleported in next to him with the use of a staff, fully joining the small band once again.

"Man, those Rewarp staves do wonders! I ain't never seen anything like that on this continent!" cried one of the lesser bandits. Immediately, the leader slugged him across the face.

"Hush, do you want to get the blasted guard on us?!" he whispered quite irritated. The lesser bandit bowed as the leader grunted. "Alright now, let's take this freak out. Maybe while we're here, we can take some of the riches in the castle, that'll be a damned fine retirement plan." The group made their way towards Cynthia, hugging the wall and using the palpable darkness to their advantage. When they finally reached her, the group stood in awe at the scale of the girl, admiring for a short moment how a human could get so big in the first place; one bandit stood next to Cynthia's foot and rubbed his hand against it, admiring the softness of her skin in some sick show of pleasure. "Stop screwing around!" the leader softly barked, prompting the man to get back in formation. "Now, use it."

The woman of the group nodded, and protruded a staff from her satchel. She pointed it skyward and yelped, bathing Cynthia's titanic frame in a soft white and blue light, a cold breeze coming from the magical discharge. Cynthia woke up upon feeling the freezing feeling, a little groggy; she tried to get up and stretch, but found she was unable to move her arms or legs.

"H-Huh? I can't move...!"

"Yell, and we'll scale you and cut your jugular." Cynthia's eyes shot open at the unfamiliar voices, and she found the group of thugs standing in front of her, weapons drawn in case anything went wrong. "It's called a Freeze staff, it's from a foreign land lost long ago by time. They stop your movements in place and make you completely helpless; powerful stuff, but it's rare, so we made sure to stock up - never once did we think we'd be using our stockpile on this though." Cynthia took notice of one of the bandits before her, remembering him from the cattle rescue she pulled off earlier in the day.

"You!" she cried, trying to lurch forward, "You're that thief who was taking the cows!"

"Good eye," spoke the leader, "He's the guy in charge of the cattle rustling operation, one of my many money-making pet projects on this continent. And I'm his boss, the guy you screwed a good chunk of gold out of."

"What do you want, fiend?!" Cynthia asked, trying to wriggle around, "Your actions were hurting a farming family's finances! You better not go back to doing such dastardly deeds, or I'll-"

"What? Squash us to a pulp? In case you haven't noticed lass, you're not exactly in a position to threaten us." The boss saw Cynthia's fingers starting to twitch, and he lifted his head in response, prompting his female comrade to use the Freeze staff again, locking Cynthia in place once more. "And honestly, the cattle rustling is the thing you're most upset about? I'd have thought by our weapons and grouping, you'd have had us pegged for murderers and organized criminals already."

"All crime, no matter how small, is crime I can't ignore! A hero solves everyone's problems with a smile!"

"Well, that's gonna suck for the city, cause they're gonna be out one hero." The boss turned to his other comrades. "Raid the palace, take everything that's shiny and valuable, don't kill anyone, else you're gonna get the whole royal guard on our asses." The bandits nodded and ran off into the backdoor behind Cynthia, carrying some staves in tow. The boss faced Cynthia again, with a look of anger on her face. "You could probably already tell, but we're going to kill you, far away from this castle with some warping staves we got; your body's gonna be quite a feast for the little beasties in the woods."

"They'll know I'm gone! And when Father finds out, he's gonna shove Falchion so far up your rear, you're gonna be throwing up Naga's blessing!" The man's ears piqued with interest.

"Woah woah, back up; Falchion? As in the one the Exalt carries?" A smug smirk came over the man. "Well, that changes things, now does it? To think a freak like you is a princess! You're gonna make fine bank on the slave trade, that you are! Hell, I could probably find some guys who'd love to get a closer look at that chest of yours!" Cynthia was getting angrier the more the bandit spoke, and spat back at the man with fury, her intent being to get as loud as she could without them noticing.

"Oh yeah? You think you're so clever?" Cynthia asked. "Well guess what: I'm not the only giant girl in this army! There's more of me, and we can easily get more giants too!"

"You got big somehow, I don't disbelieve you..." The man gave a smug smirk. "But frankly, I think you're bluffing me lass."

"Just try me!"

"So here's how it's going to go: You tell me how you got so big in the first place, and then we'll be on our way, off to your new home. Sound good?" Cynthia scoffed at the bandit.

"I don't negotiate with villains! This hero's lips are sealed!" In response, the bandit shot an arrow into Cynthia's pinky toe. "Augghhh!!" Cynthia tried to grab her foot, moving her hands forward a bit, and was quickly refrozen in response.

"Try it again missy, and you'll get another arrow. I hate damaging merchandise, so work with me here, or else we're going to go back to the whole 'killing you' plan."

"When I get my hands on you, I'm gonna-!" Another arrow hit her toe. "Aaaahhhh!" Cynthia clenched her teeth tight. "I'm not gonna talk, evil people like you deserve a nice, cold jail cell to reflect on your actions!" Another arrow, another scream.

"Come on girly, the dawn's gonna come up soon. Eventually, you're gonna get so many arrows in you that even a healing staff won't fix the ton of puncture wounds." Cynthia literally spat at the bandit, drenching him in a blob of saliva. His eye twitched in anger, he turned and faced his crew. "Draw your bows and nail her. Three of you get the Freeze staves and keep watch with me for guards." On command, the small group started firing a massive volley of arrows at Cynthia, puncturing her skin in various places, deliberately missing her vitals in a torture-like manner. Cynthia felt tears begin to well in her eyes as she endured the pain, she knew that if she screamed loud enough, she'd be dead in an instant; she had to do something, but with the Freeze staff's effects on her, nothing could be done. All she could do is endure and hope her previous cries alerted someone.

"Please Naga, send me some help! I need a miracle!" Cynthia continued to endure the volley of arrow stings for what seemed like forever, waiting for help to come.

At Cynthia's first yell, Sumia tossed and turned in her sleep. On some level she knew something was wrong but for all she knew it could have been a bad dream. Soon after she jolted awake.

Sumia immediately got up and looked to where Cynthia was supposed to be sleeping, hoping it was just a nightmare.

"Cynthia?!" Sumia yelled out, forgetting about the sleeping people around her. Guard's and sentries were roused at the sight and sound of their giant queen, but Sumia was too focused to care.

Cynthia was gone. She gasped, almost screaming and nearly lost her balance, causing her to trip again, though stopped herself at the last minute. She placed a hand on her chest, trying to slow and stabilise her breathing.

Maybe she's awoken early and has gone off to train or play hero.... no. I definitely heard something!

Sumia concentrated, harder than any time in her life, desperate to pinpoint where the sound could have come from. She couldn't pin down the exact location but it was definitely towards the forest. She ran towards it, heedless of anything else.

"CYNTHIA!" She yelled, before running closer and trying again. "CYNTHIA WHERE ARE YOU?"

Well before Sumia reached the bandits they could see her towering figure running in their direction, gaping up at her.

"Is that...... the Queen?!" One of them sputtered out

Cynthia smiled triumphantly.

"See! I told you there were more of us! You better let me go before sh- I mean we crush you all to pulp."

The bandit leader folded his arms.

"I doubt that. If there were truly an army of you, they wouldn't have sent just your mother to look for you."

Cynthia arched her eyebrows.

"-Urk she's still going to squash you flat!"

The bandit leader sniffed, almost snorting at her boast.

"Not likely. We brought you down we can do the same again!"

The Bandit leader looked to his goons.

"Keep your weapons on her throat if she says anything-"

"No mo-" Cynthia felt the prick of metal against the nape of her neck and shut herself up just in time. She bit her tongue to avoid yelling out. If she made the slightest movement she knew what would happen. She hated being in this situation, but right now it was all up to her mom

Sumia drew closer, unaware of the lurking danger, continuing to call for her daughter.

"Cynthia!" She now see her daughter and vaguely make out the men at her daughter's throat.. She did not see those who hide closer to her and was struck in the knee by several arrows. She lost her balance and fell.

"Now!"

Sumia felt a deathly chill, like the harshest winter of and suddenly couldn’t move. She tried to fight it but to no avail. The bandit leader took a step towards Sumia, though still kept his distance.

"What do we have here? The queen herself!"

Sumia tried to stand up but could only move her head.

"What did you do to Cynthia?!"

"Nothing yet, though that will change if you don't cooperate."

Sumia's scrunched up as she continued struggling against the staff.

"Don't bother struggling, this is a freeze staff, I bet you've never seen it before it, as you can guess it freezes you in the spot, so no matter how big you you're helpless! Someone get to her throat."

Sumia’s mouth opened.

"What do you want from us?!"

The bandit leader smiled, enjoying his power over the giants.

"Well for starters, whatever made you so big. And you'll tell us or the princess gets it!"

Sumia gritted her teeth. She couldn’t let the stone fall in their hands, but she couldn’t let Sumia die either.

1353321122111211211111211121112211111211.content:
Sumia was between a rock and a hard place.

“What made us big?” Sumia said, as though she was confused.

The bandit narrowed his eyes.

“Yeah and no stalling!”

Sumia’s mouth opened, as she tried to choose between the impossible. Cynthia forgot about the danger she was in, she couldn’t let mom give them the stone no matter what!

“Mom no- AHHH!” She felt the prick of a spear.

Sumia flinched, as though she herself had been stabbed. She tried to run but was still being held in place.

“Stop it please!”

The bandit leader was starting to lose his patience.

“Tell me!”

Sumia hesitated just a second long, before seeming to accept the terrible situation.

“A secret weapon. A magic stone.”

“NO!” Cynthia yelled, getting another poke.

Sumia looked pained.

“I entrusted it to our Tactician Robin. She’ll know where it is, to get it you’ll have to see her.”

The leader looked at her suspiciously, reading her face for any sign of trickery.

“A magic rock? You expect me to believe that?”

“Would I really lie with my daughter’s life on the line?” Though I might stretch the truth…

He scrutinized her for a few seconds longer, before seeming to accept.

“And where is this Tactician of yours?

“She should be at the clearing half a mile from Ylisse.”

“I think I know the one. Good, let’s go.”

He gave the orders and everyone was teleported there. As the rewarp stave was raised Sumia gasped.

“Rewarp stave? I thought those were lost to history!”

“Well we found them again.”

As the light from the staff cleared, they found themselves in the clearing. In front of them was another giant woman. The bandits gasped.

“She’s a giant to?! How many do you have?””

Their leader cut the silence off with a wave of his hand.

“Enough. Get some people on her neck then wake her, If this queen is telling the truth, only she will know where its kept. And if she’s not the crowd will have some food.”

A few of his goons nodded and approached, weapon raised, only to be suddenly grabbed. The sleeping Robin awoke, and with just the slightest movement of her hand, so to did Priam and Morgan. Morgan was groggy eyed, but Priam looked ready for battle, immediately drawing Ragnell.

The bandit leader was surprised, but seemed amused rather than scared.

“So the Tactician awakens!”

Robin grasped her would would be attackers and stood up slowly, allowing the her stature to sink into their minds. She glared down at them.

“Remove those blades from your queen and Princess or I will crush these men like a handful of grapes.”

The bandit leader shrugged.

“You can do what you like, I’ve got plenty of men, but you’ve only got one queen.”

Priam pointed Ragnell at him, looking ready to jump off Robin and charge. The effect might unnerve most men but the leader remained calm, meeting Priam’s steely gaze.

“Any of you move they get it.”

Robin looked at her husband.

“Stand down.”

Priam turned to her.

“But these villains they-”

“I said stand down.” She turned to the leader. “What are your terms and what are you after?”

“Your queen here told me you have some kind of magic stone that turned you into giants. Give it to me and I might let the queen go.”

Robin tried to appear as calm as she could.

“I see. I do not carry it on my person for this very reason but I can retrieve it.”

“Good, go get it now! But I warn you if you try anything your Princess and Queen are going to get it.”

Robin barely reacted.

“First I will inspect the Queen and Princess.” This was not a request. She placed Morgan and Priam on the ground, while still holding the men she had captured and walked towards Sumia and Cynthia. The bandits cleared out of her path, like a parting sea. Priam and Morgan followed behind her.

Their leader flinched for just a second, but tried to keep control of the situation.

“If you try anything they’ll get it.”

Robin sharpened and focused her best glare.

“And if you do anything to either of them I will wipe you out to the last man.”

The bandits quivered, even the leader. Though he tried to maintain his poise Robin walked slowly towards the prone royals,. observing the effects each of her steps had on the bandits. She glanced almost casually at the men on their neck, then looked at Morgan for just a split second. She said nothing, continuing to look around the area and at the royals.

The leader huffed.

“See? They are alive and if you want to keep them that way you’ll bring me the stone now.”

Robin could see the marks on Cynthia’s neck.

“What did you do to Cynthia?!”

“We told her not to scream and she didn’t listen. She still breathes.”

Robin was silent. She gave Morgan and Priam another quick look then turned to the prone royals.

The leader was losing his patience, and could sense some kind of trickery brewing.

“Hurry up!”

“Fine.”

Robin took a step towards the castle, then flung the bandits in her at hand at the goons on Cynthia’s neck, knocking them over like bowling pins.

All eyes were on Robin, but she, Priam and even Morgan had been ready.

Priam unleashed a shockwave from his blade while Morgan immediacy chanted something, holding a book he had kept concealed, sending a blast of wind at towards Sumia. Both attacks slammed the goon at Sumia’s neck, knocking them back.

“Now!” Robin yelled.

That was enough for everyone. Sumia and Cynthia sat up, Cynthia eager to grab her earlier captors, while Sumia swatted at hers. Morgan chanted again and Priam gleefully charged into combat. Lacking a weapon, Robin made the best used of her size, stomping her way through the bandits, crushing as many as she could with each step.

It was obvious to even the most dim witted that they were outmatched, and their freeze staves could not hold them all at bay.

“Get us out of here!” The leader yelled, running towards his staff users. Others followed, wishing to escapes the tide of destruction trying to make sure they were in the staves range.

Despite their victory, Robin hissed as they got away.

“Tsssk… I wanted to get their leader. If they have any sense they’ll abandon their hideout but this may not be the last we hear of them.”

“I got some!” Cynthia said, holding up some squirming bandits.”

Robin smiled.

“Good.”

Sumia ran to her daughter as fast she could, tripping in front of her.

“Cynthia are you alright?”

Cynthia rubbed the wounds and tried to smile.

“I’m fine they just they just poked my neck a bit. Nothing some staves can’t fix.”

Sumia got to her feet, inspecting her daughters wounds. Once the initial worry subsided, Sumia eyes narrowed.

“Those bandits… were those the ones you told me about?”

“Yes. I had no idea this would happen!”

Robin bent down to Cynthia,.

“This is why we do not let bandits flee.”

“But I put the fear of Nagi into them! Was I really supposed to stomp them flat? I mean sure there villains, but what about those ones who turn to it cause they can’t find anything else?”

Robin looked her in the eyes.

“At the very least you should capture them and bring them to the proper authorities, especially any of their leaders.”

Sumia placed a hand on Cynthia.

“Cynthia dear, I’m not sure these heroics of yours are such a good idea. We both could have been killed.”

Cynthia raised her fists, holding them towards herself.

“But it’s all I have! I just got unlucky I scared away a group of bandits with so many staves! And if I hadn’t helped that village, they’d still be terrorising people!”

1353321122111211211111211121112211111211.content:
The two girls walked back to the barracks slowly together, the air thick with tension that anyone could see they were going to break through talking. The bandits Cynthia held stopped squirming, pacified by the fear Cynthia would mash them flat like their comrades, or do even worse to them. After what felt like a long moment of silence, only laced with the sounds of the giant women's feet lightly stamping the ground, Sumia spoke up to her daughter.

"Honestly Cynthia," she began, "What were you thinking?"

"I was ambushed!" Cynthia retorted, feeling a little offended, "It happens to the best of us! Yell at the guards if you're going to yell at someone!"

"I'm not raising my voice at you, nor am I talking about before. I refer more to the cattle incident from this morning. Robin was right in saying the bandits should've been captured, as fearful as it may have made them."

"That's just it, I don't want to strike fear into the hearts of evil! Well, not totally, but I want to inspire justice!" Ironically enough, while Cynthia ranted, she shook her caged hand around wildly, causing the captured bandits to fear more for their lives and one of them to hurl out the open end of Cynthia's bars of fingers. "It's like, do you remember the story of Nohr you used to read to me? Well, future-you and present-baby-me? The princess Elise who got some evil pirates to change their lives? I want to be like her, that's a real hero right there, that she can inspire everyone through kindness of her heart and justice of her actions!"

"Well, Chrom's coming back tomorrow, so I'll let him know that when I talk to him. Keep in mind, he might still punish you, though lightly since we're at this size, for now at least, but we'll be normal soon with the ships back in port." Cynthia stopped moving, surprising Sumia as she tried to drag her daughter's hand. "Cynthia?"

"Mom, you still don't get it, I don't want to be normal again, I want to stay like this!" Sumia shook her head, feeling weary of the repeat talk.

"Cynthia-"

"Nu-uh! Don't you 'Cynthia' me! I can really help people like this! I can do things no other man or woman in the army can do! If I stay like this, I really think that I can make Ylisse a happier & safer place to be - evil will be no match when the monolithic figure of Cynthia stands guard!" Sumia was a little surprised Cynthia acted more abraisive in this talk, but she was ready to fire back like an overprotective mother.

"And then what, Cynthia? Say you become a hero to Ylisse and an enemy to evil, then what do you do? Not everyone is nice in the halidom, I'm sorry, but that's just true; there's still prejudice against those who are different, there are those greedy who would seek to be like you, and then there are others like that bandit leader who could easily control you, or worse! It's just, I..." Sumia tilted her head back and took a deep breath through her nostrils. "I don't want to lose you! I don't care if you aren't truly my child of this time, you're still family! And it would break my heart to lose you! I just..." Sumia was stopped by Cynthia's free hand touching her shoulder, stopping the waterworks Sumia almost unleashed. Sumia could see a fire lit in Cynthia's eyes, a bold courage, a look of a woman who made her choice and was going to stick with it - the natural borm eyes of a leader, the bloodline of the Exalted.

"Mother, I want this. I can do this. Please, believe in me." Sumia shook to her very core at these words, it was the same fiery determination and born leadership that made her fall in love with Chrom all those years ago. The air was silent, then broken by a giggle from Sumia's lips. "Mom?"

"Heh, sorry, it's just...That determination is another thing you inherited from Chrom. It's funny how eugenics work sometimes." Sumia broke Cynthia's grip and bowed her head. "Okay, you win, I'll allow you to stay like this, Ylisse's first giantess."

"Really? Yes! Woo-hoo!" Cynthia jumped and pumped her fists, putting more fear in the bandits as they screamed at the velocity.

"We're all gonna die!" a lanky one yelled. Cynthia scratched her forehead with her free finger and giggled.

"Oh, uh, clumsy me, hehe! Sorry about that!" She turned back to her mother, who continued to address her.

"But I don't want you going at this alone, so I will join with you as a giantess." Cynthia looked shocked, and immediately waved her free hand in disapproval.

"Woah, woah, no no no no no! You have a family at home to raise Mother! A big long life ahead of you! How are you going to tend to the animals and hug your children at this size?"

"Well, I suppose I'll have to find a way to-"

"No no, nuh-uh! Either you're getting small again or I'll, uh..." Cynthia thought about it for a bit, she couldn't exactly use "become small again" as a threat; eventually, she snapped her fingers and pointed at Sumia. "I'll go on a mad growing spree, making all the women I can huge, and then I'll punt the rock into the ocean!" Sumia gasped at the devious plan.

"You wouldn't!"

"I would and I will!" Sumia looked flabbergasted, but after a while, shook off the feeling.

"Well...Alright, no big me. I'll see if Robin feels fit to-"

"No Robin either! She doesn't want this at all!" Sumia bowed in response.

"It was an accident! I swear!" After realizing Robin wasn't there and she had basically embarassed herself to her daughter, Sumia cleared her throat. "Yes, well, I still want to assign you a partner, so..." Sumia thought it over for a bit, Cynthia joining in too, thinking about someone who wouldn't mind being huge. "I suppose I'll just have to ask a favor from Cordelia, as a friend to a friend." Cynthia looked taken back.

"Miss Cordelia?!" she cried, "Are you sure she'd be fine with that?!"

"Absolutely. She's your Captain, right? You look up to her as a mentor just like she sees you as a student and a friend, so I'm sure that she'd be willing to do this for you."

"Won't that screw up her family life though?"

"Cordelia has given birth to Severa quite a while back, she's almost as old as present-Lucina is now, I'm sure that it'll be easier for her to cuddle and play with her child than it would be me to the you of this time." Sumia leaned in close to whisper, despite no one around to hear them. "Between you and me: Cordelia feels sort of a complex about being considered perfect, and she always wished she could've been a little taller, at least to put off her 'perfect stature'. I'm sure she'd sing & dance at the chance to become a giant, call it my intuition." The mental image of Cordelia dancing & singing while growing & bursting out of her clothes entered Cynthia's mind, and it caused her to laugh.

"The Captain? No way! I couldn't see her doing something so goofy like that!" Sumia winked.

"We've been friends for a long time dear, believe me when I say I know some of her darkest secrets!" Sumia clutched Cynthia's hand again with both palms, and held it up to her face. "In any case, I'll let you live the way you wish, I won't stand in your way any longer. Just promise to me that you'll be safe." Cynthia shook her head.

"I promise, now and always! Thanks Mom!" The touching moment was ruined by the bandits in Cynthia's hand, yelling and screaming.

"That's great and all, but could you birds bring us into town already?! Some of us are freezing our knickers off out here!" Cynthia bought her caged fist to her face and spoke gruff & commanding.

"That's enough out of you, you criminals! You're going right to jail as soon as we get back! Hopefully there, you'll learn something about respect & kindness to your fellow man!" Cynthia looked fierce for a while, then turned her head to Sumia. "...How was that?"

"Beautiful, honey." Sumia replied.

"Yeah, like a knife on a chalkboard..." In response to the bandit's comment, Cynthia shook her fist up and down in frustration, like a child throwing a tantrum, causing the bandits to yell and grow sick. Sumia was quick to stop the arm from shaking, lest one of the bandits slip out and fall to their demise.

"Now, sweetie, let's just get these men & women into a jail cell, okay?"

"Alright, if I got to deal with these guys anymore, I'll just...Well, I dunno what I'll do, but it won't be pretty!" With that, the two girls continued the walk back into Ylisstol, feeling a breakthrough achieved in Cynthia's ambition.

Sumia and Cynthia headed back, first making sure the captured bandits were securely locked up, then checking Cynthia's injuries again.

"Are you sure you want to stay like this mom? I mean I don't want you to mess up your life just for me."

Sumia smiled and placed a hand on Cynthia, as she continued to inspect her.

"There’s no doubt in my mind. Someone needs to watch over you, and I’m sure when things settle down my life won’t be so different. But I want you to be careful. No matter how big you are, you aren't invincible and there are dangerous people out there."

Cynthia lowered her head.

"Yeah I get that now….”

They were silent for a few seconds, until Sumia giggled expectantly. Cynthia looked up.
“Huh? What’s so funny?”

"Chrom and Lucina are going to be in for quite a surprise when they see us.”

Cynthia laughed, forgetting her worries

"Haha yeah!”

Cynthia clapped her hands together as inspiration struck her. Were she not a giant, she would bounce on the spot, but she took more notice of the area around her.

"Hey do you think sis will want to join us? That would be great!"

Sumia glared.

"We are not forcing this on anyone."

"Hey I didn't say anything about forcing! We'll ask her. If she says yes, then that's great! If she say's no..." Cynthia's smiled widened. "Then I'LL get to be the big sister!"

Sumia relaxed.

"That's a one way of looking at it."

They were quiet again before Cynthia grew restless.

"So what do we now?"

"I'm still going to send a messenger to Tiki, for Robin's sake. Apart from that, all we can do is wait for Chrom and Lucina to return, though in the meantime I will attend my duty for queen."

Cynthia wrinkled her nose.

"What should I do?"

"I don't know. Since we can't be sure when Chrom will return and the remaining bandits may search for you again, It's best you stay near the castle for now."

"But Mommmm"

"No but's. It might even be best if you rest, but you could practice your training drills. I'm sure Robin will be around later."

Cynthia thought about arguing, but she suddenly realized how tired she was. She had been through a lot, and even after being healed by staves her body still ached. Some rest would do her good . She lay down and relaxed, her eyes growing heavy.

1353321122111211211111211121112211111211.content:
As Sumia predicted, Robin came to join them after her round of morning training. She was initially worried about Cynthia, but soon saw that she was fine.

Robin figured it would be a good idea if she were here to great Chrom and help explain the situation, while Cynthia was happy to spend more time with her.

They did not have to wait long.

Chrom and Lucina came riding back, initially stopping and staring at the sight before them. They then bursting into a gallop at the sight of the giants. Even when they reached the castle they were still in shock.

Lucina had trouble finding her words, so Chrom spoke.

“Sumia? Cynthia? Robin?! What happened?”

Robin sighed and gestured for Chrom to calm down.

“It’s a long story.”

“How long?”

Chrom frowned.

“About 44 chapters.”

“Give me a summary. Start from the beginning.”

“Very well. Cynthia found a strange rock while training and…”

Robin was as concise as she could manage, though told them of all the major events, including their run in with the bandits.
Lucina straightened herself.

“Stones turning people in giants… staves that can freeze anyone in place, it’s hard to believe.”

Robin rolled her eyes.

“Says the time traveller to the mortal host of Grima.”

Chrom nodded, seeming to accept the bizarre situation.

“It is true we have seen stranger things than this..” Chrom stared up at his giant wife and daughter.

“Though we will still need some time to adjust to this.”

“It’s been hard for us to.”

Cynthia smiled.

“Well it was tough at first, but now I like it!”

Chrom turned Cynthia, now acting the stern father.

“That’s another thing, Cynthia you have been far too reckless, I don’t know what would have happened to you were it not for Sumia and Robin.”

Cynthia lowered her head. Even though she towered over him, Chrom still had those fierce eyes. His ability to scold was almost on par with Fredrick.

“I know.. I just wanted to help but I promise I’ll be more careful.”

“I talked to her about it to, dear. She’ll be careful, and I’ll be here to watch over her, as will Coredlia.”

“Cordelia?” Chrom shook his head. “Never mind that. Is there any kind of cure?”

Cynthia looked horrified.

““I don’t want to be cured!”

Robin spoke just before Chrom could object.

“I, along with Miriel and Laurent look into but have found nothing. We aren’t even sure this magic is of this world, it is like nothing we have seen.”
Sumia added:

“I have sent a messenger to Tiki. If anyone can find an answer, it’s her.”

Chrom nodded.

“Good.”

Cynthia raised her fists.

“But I want to stay like this! I can do so much more at this size!”

“No! Cynthia you already put yourself in danger once, it could happen again.”

“I’m being careful now!”

Sumia placed an arm on her daughter and shuffled closer to her.

“I’ll be here to.”

Chrom shook his head.

“Sumia I can’t let you.”

Cynthia twitched.

“You don’t have a choice!”

Sumia turned and scolded her

“Cynthia!”

“Sorry.”

Chrom looked satisfied until Sumia said more.

“But she’s right. We’re both adults, we’ve thought about this and we aren’t rushing into it.”

“But what about you’re..” Chrom stumbled, trying to think of the politest way of saying it in front of everyone.

Sumia knew exactly what he was referring to.

“I know what you were going to say! And I’ve been working on it.”

Robin nodded.

“Indeed. I have been teaching both Sumia and Cynthia to be aware of their enviroments. They have been practicing and have both made remarkable progress.”

“Uh huh! They key is to take it slow.”

Chrom relaxed a little but was still uneasy.

“And tell me, as our tactician do you think this is a good idea?”

“I believe it is feasible, and I respect Sumia and Cynthia’s choice. I believe they can do this, and we are not even sure a cure is even an option. Plus it will be good for
the realm’s defence.””

“Then I suppose I’ll have no choice but to accept. I can tell you will not be swayed, and if Robin is involved I trust your judgement.”

Cynthia pumped her fist in the ai and cheered.

“Yay!”

Then leaned over to Lucina.

“Hey you wanna join us?””

Lucina blinked, still in a state of shock.

“What?”

Like, how would the kingdom react when they learn that over half of the royal family is 60ft tall? Plus, I wish to carry Falchion around in case something comes our way." Cynthia thought about Lucina's concerns, but she is interrupted when Lucina spoke again.

"But I'll make a deal with you Cynthia. If Cordelia's growth process goes smoothly, then I'll join in. Does that sound fair?" Cynthia grew ecstatic with Lucina's promise.

"Of course, sis, cause if not, then I guess that means I'll have to be BIG sister from now on!" She grinned and began to bob up and down.

Cordelia brushed her pegasus and fed her after she was done training. It was until her steed began to freak out that she turned around.

"AAAHH," she screamed as she is confronted with not just Robin, but also Sumia and Cynthia, "You weren't kidding when you said I may be surprised, Robin!"
